We now offer \n\ncore business and new initiatives. I am pleased to share that \n\ncommercial grade Chrome OS products which are more rug-\n\nour efforts and achievements in 2018 concluded with growth \n\ngedized  in  design  and  built  very  differently  from  consumer \n\nin  both  revenue  and  profitability.  Acer\'s  2018  consolidated \n\ndevices. \n\nrevenues reached NT$242.27 billion with 2.1 percent growth \n\nyear-over-year; Net income reached NT$3.06 billion, up 8.7 \n\npercent  year-over-year;  and  earnings  per  share  (EPS)  were \n\nNT$1.01, the highest in eight years.  \n\nAcer\'s participation in esports games has been action-packed. \n\nWe were the official monitor provider of the 2018 League of \n\nLegends World Championships. In the third quarter, we kicked \n\noff our second Asia Pacific Predator league tournament where \n\nWhile  Acer\'s  gaming  business  achieved  substantial  revenue \n\n3,530 teams competed over five months and battled for the \n\ngrowth, in the latter part of the year, our operations were im-\n\nleague championship. Through such events, Acer will engage \n\npacted  by  global  CPU  supply  shortages  for  PCs.  Meanwhile, \n\nnew audiences while continuing to bring technologies, inno-\n\nwe  are  excited  to  see  other  products  and  businesses  show-\n\nvations and game-changing designs first to market.\n\ning growth, such as AOPEN, Weblink International, Acer Cyber \n\nSecurity,  digital  displays  and  gadgets.  We  will  continue  the \n\npursuit of technological innovation and leading-edge design, \n\nbroaden  our  business  boundaries  from  PCs  to  new  markets, \n\nand create multiple growth engines. \n\nFor  AI-based  technology,  servers  by  our  subsidiary,  Altos \n\nComputing,  which  integrate  other  software  and  services  to \n\nprovide a variety of solutions have won a dozen major high-\n\nperformance computing (HPC) tenders globally in 2018. In the \n\nrealm of smart cities, Acer ITS successfully initiated Taiwan\'s \n\nUnderscoring  the  importance we  place  on  research  and  de-\n\nfirst roadside Smart Parking Meter BOT project in collabora-\n\nvelopment, in 2018 Acer ranked among the top three in the \n\ntion  with  the  Tainan  city  government,  with  parking  meters \n\nnumber  of  Taiwan  patent  applications  with  476  filings,  up \n\nimplemented along a total of 2,000 spaces across the city.\n\n25 percent from the previous year. Among these patents, we \n\nhave innovative and breakthrough technologies such as our \n\nadvanced thermal solutions that enable Acer products to run \n\nat peak performance without overheating; these include our \n\nAeroBlade 3D metal fans applied in gaming notebooks, and \n\nIceTunnel  cooling  system  for  gaming  desktops.  Acer\'s  thin-\n\nand-light notebooks, gaming and education lines all captured \n\nattention with multiple industry and media awards. Further-\n\nmore, we are innovating in other aspects of designs that com-\n\nplete  the  total  user  experience,  such  as  software  and  pack-\n\naging, which were  recognized  and  awarded  by  the  iF  Design \n\nAwards of Germany. \n\nIn  the  Chrome  OS  segment,  Acer  ranked  No.  1  for  Chrome-\n\nbooks worldwide  in  Q4  2018 with  31  percent  market  share. \n\nWe offer the most complete selection of screen sizes and form \n\nfactors for a variety of usage needs. Acer is also strengthen-\n\nVenturing into technology for the future, Acer\'s Value Lab has \n\ncollaborated  with  one  of  Taiwan\'s  top  automakers,  Luxgen, \n\nto  showcase  the  vision  of  artificial  intelligence  (AI)  and  au-\n\ntonomous driving technology with a level 4-ready self-driving \n\nconcept car. Acer is stepping up the development further by \n\ncooperating  with  the  National  Yang-Ming  University  School \n\nof Medicine to improve the passenger experience, where the \n\nphysiological state of passengers during the technology de-\n\nvelopment  stage  is  monitored  to  improve  comfortability  of \n\nthe ride even during unexpected situations. On top of these, \n\nthere are many other exciting initiatives being developed.\n\nFor long-term business sustainability, Acer\'s pursuit to make \n\na positive impact to our society and environment has made \n\nsignificant headway in 2018. In addition to the on-going en-\n\ngagement with our partners and suppliers to act responsibly, \n\n50 percent of electricity consumption from Acer\'s global op-\n\nAcer Incorporated 2018 Annual ReportBusiness ReportAcer Incorporated 2018 Annual ReportBusiness Report\x0c6\n\n7\n\nerations  comes  from  green  energy. We  also  initiated  several \n\nprograms to encourage global employees to take part in car-\n\ning for our environment. With sustainable development em-\n\nbedded  in  the  company  culture,  and  the  determination  to \n\ninnovate  in  all  aspects  of  our  technology,  management  and \n\noperations, we persist in giving back to our communities and \n\nexceling in our corporate social responsibilities (CSR). More-\n\nover, to put into clearer perspective of Acer\'s impact on the \n\nenvironment  and  society,  we  continued  to  adopt  the  True \n\nValue methodology that quantifies in financial terms the costs \n\nand benefits. This serves as a guidance on taking the relevant \n\nrisk control measures and weighing business opportunities. \n\nWe have made significant strides in the past year, and we are \n\nalready moving full-steam ahead to explore and conquer new \n\nchallenges. On behalf of all Acer employees, allow me to ex-\n\npress  our  deepest  appreciation  to  our  shareholders  for your \n\nsupport. I look forward to planting the seeds for new opportu-\n\nnities in another fruitful year together!\n\nSincerely,\n\nJason Chen\n\nChairman and CEO\n\n1.1 Acer\'s Core Values\n\nAcer continues its transformation to become a \xe2\x80\x9chardware + software + services\xe2\x80\x9d company. Based on the Wangdao philosophy of \naltruism, Acer is working with partners to create value, and build an ecosystem that balances all stakeholders\' interests. In the \nprocess of transition, the company\'s core values will be practiced to strengthen the core competencies needed to ensure a stronger \nAcer for the future.\n\nAcer\'s six core values are: Passion, User-centric, Innovation, Teamwork, Balance of Interests, and Integrity.\n\nCore Value\n\nRational Meaning\n\nEmotional Meaning\n\nPassion\n\nBe ready to change the \nworld with a positive, \nenthusiastic, dare-to-\ndream and determined \nattitude. \n\nUser-centric\n\nNever forget that we \nare here to create \nvalue for end-users. \nAlways think about the \nbenefits we can bring \nthem in everything you \ndo.\n\nInnovation\n\nCreate unique \ncompetitive \nadvantages and \nlook for value-\nbased innovations in \neverything you do.\n\nTeamwork\n\nBalance of \nInterests\n\nCommunicate, create \nconsensus and \ncollaborate as one \nteam. Place the groups\' \ninterests above the \nindividual\'s interests \nand work toward a \ncommon goal.\n\nWork together to \ncreate value, overcome \ndifficulties and \nconstruct a model that \nbalances the interests \nof all stakeholders.\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2  Serve as a bridge between people and technology. Be open to try new ideas, \n\nmethods, and applications.\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2  Endeavor to face challenges, break through bottlenecks and create value.\n\xe2\x80\xa2  Sharpen professionalism to pursue excellence with dedication and enjoyment \n\nin work to keep one step ahead of our competitors.\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2  Care for, delegate to, and support people.\n\xe2\x80\xa2  Influence people through a positive attitude.\n\xe2\x80\xa2  Face up to difficulties and solve them in innovative and realistic ways. \n\n\xe2\x80\xa2  Explore users\' habits and requirements by putting yourself in their position, \nand using the knowledge gained to design impressive products and services. \n\n\xe2\x80\xa2  Base your decisions on sound research into users\' requirements. \n\xe2\x80\xa2  Listen to customers and understand the market trends from their point-of-\n\nview.\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2  Create systems for evaluating users\' needs and experience. \n\xe2\x80\xa2  Build up a mechanism for developing products and services that meet global \n\nneeds. \n\n\xe2\x80\xa2  When engaged with product or service innovation, always consider users\' needs \n\nand what they value to assure customer stickiness. \n\n\xe2\x80\xa2  Remain curious and aggressive in the course of innovation. If you have \n\ncriticism, make sure it is constructive. \n\n\xe2\x80\xa2  Consider the commercial value of your proposed innovations or improvements. \n\xe2\x80\xa2  Give equal consideration to cost, quality and the value that the innovation will \n\ndeliver to end users. \n\n\xe2\x80\xa2  Collaborate with strategic partners, and share cutting-edge knowledge to \n\ncreate value. \n\n\xe2\x80\xa2  Use the five 5Cs (Communication x3, Consensus, Commitment) to enhance \n\ncommunication and collaboration. \n\n\xe2\x80\xa2  Specify performance indicators that are mutually agreed by the teams, and \n\nthen devote all team-members\' efforts to achieve the goals. \n\n\xe2\x80\xa2  Put the team\'s interests above an individual\'s interests. \n\xe2\x80\xa2  Enhance interactions, respect and trust between teams. \n\xe2\x80\xa2  Focus on the value chain as the highest priority in collaboration for maximizing \n\ncustomer value. \n\n\xe2\x80\xa2  Keep promises and build trust-based relationships with stakeholders. Make an \n\neffort to overcome difficulties and construct a model that balances different \nparties\' interests. \n\n\xe2\x80\xa2  Form collaborative relationships that balance the six aspect values: tangible \n\nversus intangible; direct versus indirect; present versus future. \n\n\xe2\x80\xa2  Value the balance among associated groups (environment, social, and \n\ncultural). \n\n\xe2\x80\xa2  Motivate employees and partners and establish long-term partnerships. \n\nAcer Incorporated 2018 Annual ReportBusiness ReportAcer Incorporated 2018 Annual ReportBusiness Report\x0c8\n\n9\n\nCore Value\n\nRational Meaning\n\nEmotional Meaning\n\nIntegrity\n\nAbide by corporate \ngovernance, \nregulations and \nstandards of business \nconduct not because \nwe are required to, but \nbecause it is the right \nthing to do.\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2  Follow the codes of conduct or social norms when performing duties and \n\nalways serve as a role model for others. \n\n\xe2\x80\xa2  Never appropriate public resources for private use. \n\xe2\x80\xa2  Never reveal or leak confidential information when inappropriate. \n\xe2\x80\xa2  Be aware of and stop any behavior that may violate regulations or social codes. \n\n1.2 2018 Operating Report\n\n1.2.1 Operating Results and Earning Abilities\n\nFinancial Information (Consolidated)\n\nOperating Results\n\nEarning Abilities\n\nItem\n\n Operating revenue \n\n Gross profit \n\nNet income (loss) attributable to \nshareholders of the Company\n\n Return on assets (%) \n\n Return on equity (%)  \n\n Net income ratio (%) \n\n EPS (NTD)\n\n2017\n\n2018\n\nUnit: NTD Thousands\n\n 237,274,883\n\n 25,361,234\n\n2,815,587\n\n1.85\n\n4.84\n\n1.18\n\n0.93\n\n 242,270,406\n\n 25,828,199\n\n3,060,429\n\n1.95\n\n4.96\n\n1.20\n\n1.01\n\nIn 2018, operating revenue was NT$242.3 billion with 2.11% growth year-over-year. Gross profit was NT$25.8 billion with 1.84% \ngrowth year-over-year. Net income reached 3.1 billion up 8.70% year-over-year. In 2018, EPS was NT$1.01, an increase NT$0.08 \nfrom the 2017 level of NT$0.93 Due to growth in both revenue and profitability, return on assets, return on equity and net income \nratio were all growth in 2018.\n\n1.2.2. Budget Expenditure in 2019\n\nNot applicable\n\n1.3 2019 Business Plan\n\n1.3.1 Business Strategy\n\nA.  Focus on the gaming PC market with industry-leading thermal technologies and powerful performance to elevate brand pre-\n\nmium.\n\nB.  Create a portfolio of products tailored for different market preferences and needs; in addition to gaming PCs, focus on ultra-\n\nthin & light notebooks, Chromebooks, and all-in-one PCs.\n\nC.  Become a corporate group with multiple-growth engines, with subsidiaries going public to foster entrepreneurship as an im-\n\nD. \n\nportant step to achieving the goal, and exploring new realms and partnerships.\nIntegrate cloud services with software and hardware solutions for enterprise customers. Provide AI-ready solutions that lever-\nage big data analytics, and target businesses regarding the Internet of Things (IoT), such as digital signage, smart transporta-\ntion and smart health.\n\nE.  Efficiently utilize resources within company and among subsidiaries, enhance internal communications on Company\'s global \n\nefforts in bridging the digital divide and environmental sustainability. \n\n1.3.2 Business Goals\n\nA.  Enhance brand premium by focusing on high-value and high-margin market segments.\nB.  Evolve with the PC landscape, focus on niche areas with high growth potential and that are profitable, and create differentiation \n\nand value to fulfill and exceed people\'s needs.\n\nC.  Explore new market domains to broaden our business boundaries in the traditional PC business and beyond.\nD. \nE. \n\n Enable enterprise customers to build their own secure, managed, scalable and hybrid cloud services.\nIncrease operating income, build sustainable operations, promote the interests of shareholders, and strengthen corporate \nsocial responsibility.\n\n1.3.3 Business Planning and Marketing Strategy\n\nA.  Provide a comprehensive gaming portfolio with PCs for hardcore to casual gamers, complete with  peripherals and gadgets. \n\nEngage with world-class e-sports events as well as host own events of regional scale promoting the Predator gaming brand.\n\nB.  Be first-to-market with new technologies, develop leading and world-firsts in design innovations, such as the world\'s thinnest \n\nand lightest notebooks, world\'s first curved screen gaming laptop, as examples.\n\nC.  Through both in-house research and partnerships, explore and expand to different verticals where there is synergy with our \n\ncore competencies. \n\nD.  For the cloud business, focus efforts on optimizing key products and accelerating the development of innovative services for \n\nthe enterprise segment.\n\nE.  Enhance corporate social responsibility, create value, and pursue sustainable operations, in collaboration with the supply chain \n\nand customers.\n\n1.3.4 Future Development Strategy\n\nA.  Develop gaming PCs, gadgets, content, and artificial intelligence (AI).\nB.  Expand the gaming segment with new gadgets and technology innovations like the metal-blade AeroBlade 3D fans that help \n\nPCs stay cool, as well as incorporating latest industry technology to deliver best-in-class user experiences.\n\nC.  Seek opportunities in the commercial market, providing products and solutions to meet the rigid demands from different mar-\n\nkets; the current commercial business portfolio includes Chromebooks, servers, and cloud solutions.\n\nD.  Continue transforming from a PC-oriented company to a sustainable technology group through new developments in areas \n\nsuch as AI and the cloud.\n\nE.  Uphold corporate social responsibilities, realize a sustainable business mindset, and give back to society and shareholders.\n\nAcer Incorporated 2018 Annual ReportBusiness ReportAcer Incorporated 2018 Annual ReportBusiness Report\x0c10\n\n11\n\n1.3.5 Impact on Company Due to Competition, Governmental \n\nRegulations and Overall Macro Market \n\nA. \n\n Respect international laws and regulations on information privacy and security, such as GDPR, especially in the realms of AI and \ncloud services.\n\nB.  Step up IT security and preparedness in the event of cyber security risks, which have become prevalent in the growing digitiza-\n\ntion of business operations and consumer user habits.\n\nC.  Observe the China-US trade war impacts and follow all local regulations including the US Trade Act 301. Continue to monitor \n\nsocioeconomic situations, and dynamically adjust regional business strategies according to local developments.\n\nD.  Closely observe the currency fluctuation of emerging markets and remain watchful over the global financial market dynamics, \n\nin addition to foreign exchange hedging to minimize related risks. \n\nE.  Keep abreast with the evolving digital infrastructure developments brought about by the combination of AI and blockchain, \n\nand the new applications, opportunities and challenges this brings across industries.\n\nCompany In \n\nGeneral 2\n\nAcer Incorporated 2018 Annual ReportCompany In GeneralAcer Incorporated 2018 Annual ReportBusiness Report\x0c12\n\n13\n\n2.1 Founded date: August 1, 1976\n\n2.2 Brief Account of the Company\n\n1976 \xe2\x80\x93 1986\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2  Commercialized microprocessor technology\n\n1987 \xe2\x80\x93 2000\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2  Created the Acer brand name and went global\n\n2001 \xe2\x80\x93 2007\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2  Transformed from manufacturing to a marketing and \n\nsales company\n\n2008 \xe2\x80\x93 2013\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2  Enhanced  worldwide  presence  with  a  multi-brand \n\nstrategy\n\n2014 \xe2\x80\x93 Beyond\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2  Transforming into a \xe2\x80\x9chardware + software + services\xe2\x80\x9d \n\ncompany\n\n1976\n\n1980\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2  Designed the Dragon Computer Terminal, the Chinese lan-\n\nguage adaptation for computers.\n\n1981\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2  Established  its  manufacturing  operations  at  the  Hsinchu \n\nScience-based Industrial Park in Taiwan.\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2  Debuted  the  MicroProfessor-I  as  the  Company\'s  first \n\nbranded product.\n\ncomputer.\n\n1984\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2  First company to promote 16-bit PC products in Taiwan.\n\n1984\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2  Established Acer Peripherals, Inc. (now BenQ Corp.) .\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2  Founded  under  the  name  \xe2\x80\x9cMultitech\xe2\x80\x9d  with  NT$1  million \n(US$25,000) in capital, focusing on trade, product design, \nand consultancy in the use of microprocessor technologies. \n(Aug. 1, 1976).\n\n1985\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2  Founded  AcerLand,  Taiwan\'s  first  and  largest  franchised \n\ncomputer retail chain.\n\n1978\n\n1986\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2  Established  the  Microprocessor  Training  Centre,  training \n\n3,000 engineers for Taiwan\'s information industry.\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2  Beat IBM to offer 32-bit PCs.\n\n1979\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2  Expanded the business to central and southern Taiwan.\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2  Designed  Taiwan\'s  first  mass-produced  computer  for  ex-\n\nport.\n\n1987\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2  Created the \xe2\x80\x9cAcer\xe2\x80\x9d name.\n\n1988\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2  Completed Acer Inc. initial public offering (April 1988)\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2 \n\nIntroduced the MegaMicro e-Enabling services, an e-busi-\nness model that integrates IT equipment, network, man-\nagement  platforms,  and  application  software  to  create  a \nMega e-Infrastructure and Micro e-services.\n\n1989\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2  Formed the TI-Acer DRAM joint venture with Texas Instru-\n\n2002\n\nments.\n\n1990\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2  Launched Acer\'s first notebook.\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2 \n\nInaugurated the Product Value Labs to enhance Acer\'s cus-\ntomer-centric focus and integrated technologies that add \nvalue to people\'s lives.\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2  TravelMate C100 was the first convertible Tablet PC avail-\n\nable in the worldwide market with pen input.\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2  Acquired  Altos  Computer  Systems,  a  manufacturer  of \nmulti-user  and  networked  systems  for  commercial  mar-\nkets.\n\n2004\n\n1991\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2 Procedures and arrangement relating to corporate governance shall ensure that, in exercising its author-\nity, the board of directors will comply with laws, regulations, articles of incorporation, and the resolutions of shareholders meetings \nof the Company.\n\nRegarding the structure of the board of directors, the Company shall determine an appropriate number of board members not \nless than five persons, in consideration of its business scale, the shareholding of its major shareholders and practical operational \nneeds.\n\nThe composition of the board of directors shall be determined by taking diversity into consideration. It is advisable that directors \nconcurrently serving as company officers not exceed one-third of the total number of the board members, and that an appropriate \npolicy on diversity based on the Company\'s business operations, operating dynamics, and development needs be formulated and \ninclude, without being limited to, the following two general standards:\n\n1.  Basic requirements and values: Gender, age, nationality, and culture.\n\n2.  Professional knowledge and skills: A professional background (e.g., law, accounting, industry, finance, marketing, and technol-\n\nogy), professional skills, and industry experience.\n\nAll members of the board shall have the necessary knowledge, skill, and experience to perform their duties. To achieve the ideal \ngoal of corporate governance, the board of directors shall possess the following abilities:\n\n1.  Ability to make operational judgment.\n\n2.  Ability to perform accounting and financial analysis.\n\n3.  Ability to conduct management administration.\n\n4.  Ability to conduct crisis management.\n\n5. \n\nIndustrial knowledge.\n\n6. \n\nInternational market perspective.\n\n7.  Ability to lead.\n\n8.  Ability to make decisions.\n\nThis Policy may make the Board function be more effective. The nomination and selection of board members of the Company is in \naccordance with the Company\'s Articles. In addition, there is nomination system to ensure the diversity and independence of the \nboard members. The Company expects to invite and nominate one or more female candidates in the next board election (will be \nheld in 2020), and to select directors with different professional knowledge, for providing different perspectives and contributions \nto facilitate the Board function.\n\nThe implement of the BOD Diversity Policy:\n\n1.  The proportion of the directors who also acting as employees is 22.22%; the proportion of the directors who also acting as \n\nIndependent Directors is 44.44%; and the proportion of the female directors is 11.11%.\n\n2.  Director specializing in operation and sales of Global brand products and services: Jason Chen\n\n3.  Director who be devoted in innovation, public and social services: Stan Shih\n\n4.  Director specializing in e-business and having successfully promoted the business\'s transformation: George Huang\n\n5.  Director who be devoted in human education, public and social services: Carolyn Yeh\n\n6.  Director having the professional financial background in business and investment: Philip Peng\n\n7.  Director specializing in semiconductor industry and devoted in education, public and social activities: F.C. Tseng\n\n8.  Director specializing in strategic organization and business management: Ji-Ren Lee\n\n9.  Director specializing in information security and operation of national business, and who had been Premier of Taiwan: San-\n\nCheng Chang\n\n10.  Director specializing in semiconductor industry and having outstanding contribution on the R&D to non-volatile semiconduc-\n\ntor component: Ching-Hsiang Hsu\n\nThe backgrounds of current Directors:\n\nThe Diversities and abilities to the Board of Director\n\nJason Chen\n\nMale\n\nOperational Judgment, Management Administration, Crisis Management, Industrial \nKnowledge of the Company, International Market Perspective, and Ability to Lead and \nDecisions-Making.\n\nStan Shih\n\nMale\n\nOperational Judgment, Management Administration, Crisis Management, Industrial \nKnowledge of the Company, International Market Perspective, and Ability to Lead and \nDecisions-Making.\n\nGeorge Huang\n\nMale\n\nOperational Judgment, Accounting and Finance, Management Administration, Crisis \nManagement, Industrial Knowledge of the Company, International Market Perspective, \nand Ability to Lead and Decisions-Making.\n\nCarolyn Yeh  \n\n(Representative of Hung \nRouan Investment Corp.)\n\nFemale\n\nOperational Judgment, Accounting and Finance, Management Administration, Crisis \nManagement, Industrial Knowledge of the Company, International Market Perspective, \nand Ability to Lead and Decisions-Making.\n\nPhilip Peng  \n\n(Representative of Smart \n\nMale\n\nCapital Corp.)\n\nOperational Judgment, Accounting and Finance, Management Administration, Crisis \nManagement, Industrial Knowledge of the Company, International Market Perspective, \nand Ability to Lead and Decisions-Making.\n\nF.C. Not an employee of the Company or any of its affiliates.\n2.  Not a director or supervisor of the Company or any of its affiliates. The same does not apply, however, in cases where the person is an \nindependent director of the Company, its parent company, or any subsidiary in which the Company holds, directly or indirectly, more \nthan 50% of the voting shares.\n\n3.  Not a natural-person shareholder who holds shares, together with those held by the person\'s spouse, minor children, or held by the \nperson under others\' names, in an aggregate amount of 1% or more of the total number of outstanding shares of the Company or rank-\ning in the top 10 in holdings.\n\n4.  Not a spouse, relative within the second degree of kinship, or lineal relative within the fifth degree of kinship, of any of the persons in \n\nthe preceding three subparagraphs.\n\n5.  Not a director, supervisor, or employee of a corporate shareholder that directly holds 5% or more of the total number of outstanding \n\nshares of the Company or that holds shares ranking in the top five in holdings.\n\n6.  Not a director, supervisor, officer, or shareholder holding 5% or more of the share, of a specified company or institution that has a finan-\n\ncial or business relationship with the Company.\n\n7.  Not a professional individual who, or an owner, partner, director, supervisor, or officer of a sole proprietorship, partnership, company, \nor institution that, provides commercial, legal, financial, accounting services or consultation to the Company or to any affiliate of the \nCompany, or a spouse thereof.\n\n8.  Not having a marital relationship, or a relative within the second degree of kinship to any other director of the Company.\n9.  Not been a person of any conditions defined in Article 30 of the Company Law.\n10.  Not a governmental, juridical person or its representative as defined in Article 27 of the Company Law.\n\nAcer Incorporated 2018 Annual ReportCorporate Governance ReportAcer Incorporated 2018 Annual ReportCorporate Governance Report\x0c28\n\n29\n\n3.2.2 Key Managers (April 16, 2019)\n\nTitle\n\nNationality \n\nor \n\nRegistration\n\nName\n\nGender\n\nDate of \nAccession\n\nShares Held Directly\n\nShares Held by Spouse & \n\nMinors\n\nShares Held by the Other\'s \n\nNumber\n\nPercentage\n\nNumber\n\nPercentage\n\nNumber\n\nPercentage\n\nEducation\n\nCurrent Position(s) in Other \n\nCompanies\n\nSpouse or Immediate Family \n\nHolding Position as President or \n\nVice President\n\nTitle\n\nName\n\nRelationship\n\nChairman & \n\nCEO\n\nR.O.C\n\nJason Chen\n\nMale\n\n01/01/2014\n\n2,633,480\n\n0.09\n\n0\n\nCo-COO\n\nR.O.C\n\nTiffany Huang\n\nFemale\n\n01/01/2013\n\n280,817\n\n0.01\n\n90\n\nCo-COO\n\nR.O.C\n\nJerry Kao\n\nMale\n\n12/01/2014\n\n343,375\n\n0.01\n\nCorp.VP & \nPresident\n\nFrance\n\nEmmanuel \nFromont\n\nMale\n\n01/01/2011\n\n190,000\n\n0.01\n\nPresident\n\nR.O.C\n\nBen Wan\n\nMale\n\n05/16/2002\n\n146,388\n\n0\n\n0\n\n0\n\n0\n\n0\n\n0\n\n0\n\n0\n\n0\n\nPresident\n\nR.O.C\n\nMaverick Shih\n\nMale\n\n01/24/2014\n\n10,076,733\n\n0.33\n\n13,172,880\n\n0.43\n\nPresident\n\nUSA\n\nGregg \n\nPrendergast\n\nMale\n\n09/01/2015\n\n163,000\n\n0.01\n\nPresident\n\nR.O.C\n\nAndrew Hou\n\nMale\n\n03/25/2016\n\n139,500\n\nPresident\n\nR.O.C\n\nVictor Chien\n\nMale\n\n03/25/2016\n\n97,506\n\nCTO\n\nR.O.C\n\nRC Chang\n\nMale\n\n09/01/2015\n\n63,135\n\n0\n\n0\n\n0\n\nCorp. \nsetting remuneration procedures; and the relevance \nof the business performance and the future risks.\n\n(1) The remuneration of the company\'s director as the percentage of the net profit after tax \n\nin the last two years:\n\nTitle\n\n2017\n\n(Company)\n\n2017\n\n(All companies in the \n\nconsolidated statement)\n\nDirector\n\n0.69%\n\n0.69%\n\n2018\n\n(Company)\n\n0.76%\n\n2018\n\n(All companies in the \n\nconsolidated statement)\n\n0.76%\n\nNote: It does not include relevant remuneration to the director who holds a concurrent position as an employee.\n\n1. Policy, Standard and Combination of the Remuneration\n\nThe directors\' remuneration of the Company is based on the provisions of the Company\'s Articles of Incorporation; in accor-\ndance with the directors\' participation in the company\'s operations and the value of their contributions. The Remuneration \nCommittee refers to the standard of peers in the same industry and submits to the Board of Directors for resolution and issue \npayment after passing the resolution, and reports to the shareholders during the annual meeting in accordance with the law. \nThe remuneration of the directors includes fixed remuneration, reward of directors, and business execution expenses (travel \nexpenses included). When the company makes profit that year, the profit less an amount reserved to make up for the accumu-\nlative losses and no more than 0.8% of that balance is allocated to the directors as the reward. Regardless of fixed remunera-\ntion, business execution expenses and reward of directors, they are subject to the standards of the high-tech industry and \nare submitted by the Remuneration Committee to the Board of Directors for resolution and issue payment after passing the \nresolution.\n\nIn addition, according to the principle of remuneration paid by the company\'s remuneration committee and the board of \ndirectors, the director concurrently served as an employee would not be awarded with other director\'s remuneration (i.e. fixed \nremuneration and reward of directors) except for the business execution expenses.\n\nThe combination of Director\'s remuneration of 2018 is as follows:\n\n6%\n\nBusiness execution \nexpense\n\nReward of directors\n\n30%\n\nFixed Remuneration\n\n64%\n\n2. Remuneration setting procedures\n\nAccording to the first paragraph of Article 16-1 of the Company\'s Articles of Incorporation, , when the company makes any \nprofit that year, the profit less an amount reserved to make up for the accumulative losses and no more than 0.8% of that bal-\nance is allocated to the directors as the reward. The method of allocation is submitted by the Remuneration Committee to the \nboard of directors to decide.\n\n3. The relevance of the business performance and the future risks\n\nThe directors\' remuneration is stipulated in the company\'s Articles of Incorporation, and the non-fixed remuneration part is \nbased on the company\'s annual profitability and is directly related to the company\'s operating performance. In addition, consid-\nering the directors\' responsibilities, the company\'s operating performance and the standard of the peers in the same industry, \nfixed remuneration is set to avoid the negligence in assessing the future risks resulting from pursuing short-term operation \nprofits. The Remuneration Committee also regularly evaluates and reviews the remuneration of the Board of Directors and re-\nports the results to the Board for discussion to ensure it is balanced with the company\'s sustainable business operation.\n\n(2) The remuneration of the company\'s general manager and deputy general manager as \n\nthe percentage of the net profit after tax in the last two years:\n\nTitle\n\n2017\n\n(Company)\n\n2017\n\n(All companies in the \n\nconsolidated statement)\n\n2018\n\n(Company)\n\n2018\n\n(All companies in the \n\nconsolidated statement)\n\nGeneral Manager \nand Deputy General \n\nManager\n\n4.84%\n\n11.32%\n\n4.83%\n\n11.38%\n\n1. Policy, Standard and Combination of the Remuneration\n\nThe remuneration of the company to the manager is mainly divided into fixed salary, variable bonus and retire/severance pay; \nfixed salary is the monthly salary agreed with the employee, and the variable bonus is further divided into short-term bonus and \nlong-term bonus.\n\nShort-term bonuses are awarded when the annual performance has reached the target and in accordance with the Article 20 of \nthe Company\'s Articles of Incorporation. The short-term bonus considers the performance and contribution in the current year. \nThe remuneration committee will consider the factors such as the responsibilities of the job, the overall market of the industry \nand the market standard, report to the board of directors for approval. Upon approval, the annual bonus of the company will be \nreleased according to the times and date announced.\n\nThe long-term bonus is for the period of three years or more, and the profit of the shareholders\' investment in the company\'s \nstock is used as the standard for issuing the bonus which connects with the interests of the shareholders.\n\nVariable Bonus\n\n66%\n\nFixed Salary\n\n32%\n\n2%\n\nRetire/\nSeverance Pay\n\nAcer Incorporated 2018 Annual ReportCorporate Governance ReportAcer Incorporated 2018 Annual ReportCorporate Governance Report\x0c36\n\n37\n\n2. Remuneration setting procedures\n\nThe manager\'s remuneration is dealt in accordance with the company\'s Articles of Incorporation and the relevant provisions of \nthe company. The human resources unit submits the manager\'s remuneration to the remuneration committee. After reviewing \nand approving by the remuneration committee, it is submitted to the board of directors for verification.\n\n3. The relevance of the business performance and the future risks\n\nEmployees\' remuneration is dealt in accordance with the regulations and the results of the year\'s business operations. The stan-\ndards, structure and system of, will be reviewed and adjusted at any time depending on the actual operating conditions and the \nchanges in relevant regulations. The remuneration committee of the Company also regularly assesses the current status of the \nremuneration of the Manager and provides recommendations to the Board of directors for referencing and discussion to ensure \nthe consideration of the overall remuneration.\n\n3.3 Corporate Governance Status \n\n3.3.1 Meetings Held by the Board of Directors\n\nThe Board of Directors held five meetings from Jan. 1, 2018 to Dec. 31, 2018. \nThe record of the Directors\' attendances is shown below:\n\nTitle\n\nChairman\nDirector\nDirector\n\nDirector\n\nName\n\nJason Chen \nStan Shih\n\nGeorge Huang\nCarolyn Yeh \n\n(Representative of Hung \nRouan Investment Corp.)\n\nPhilip Peng\n\nDirector\n\n(Representative of Smart \n\nIndependent \n\nDirector\n\nIndependent \n\nDirector\n\nIndependent \n\nDirector\n\nIndependent \n\nDirector\n\nCapital Corp.)\n\nF.C. and this Item has been \napproved unanimously by other board of directors who \npresent at the meeting.\n\nThe Board of Directors has established following functional committees to actively strengthen board of director functions and \nimplement good corporate governance through every functional committees\' teamwork.\n\n(1) For the purpose of building sound remuneration system of board of director and officer, the Remuneration Committee was \nestablished in August 2011 based on Board resolution in accordance with Taiwan Securities and Exchange Act and relevant \nAuthority\' ruling, it consists by three independent directors.\n\n(2) For the purpose of good corporate governance, the Audit Committee was established in June 2014 after board of director \nre-election by the shareholders meeting; it consists of all independent directors in accordance with Taiwan Securities and \nExchange Act and Company Act.\n\n(3) For the purpose of previewing the investment, joint venture, M&A regarding new business and other strategic investment, \nthe Investment Committee was established in June 2017 by board resolution in accordance with the Company\'s Articles of \nIncorporation; it consists of 5 board of directors, and at least 2 of 5 members shall be independent directors.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9cAcer\'s Corporate Governance Best-Practice Principles\xe2\x80\x9d have been amended in 2017 and 2019 to strengthen board of directors\' \nfunction and duties, and we set up a series of targets to enhance board functions, such as the attendance rate of board meeting, \nan appropriate policy on diversity of board members, and board of directors\' performance evaluation, etc.\n\nThe performance assessment result of the Board has been publicly disclosed on Acer Group website in accordance with Acer\'s \n\xe2\x80\x9cMeasures for Performance Evaluation of the Board of Directors\xe2\x80\x9d from 2017. The Audit Committee comprehensively \n\nevaluates the independence of CPA based \non CPA\'s Statement of Independence and \nitems stated in relevant regulations. The \nimportant evaluation items are summa-\nrized as following:\n\n(1)  Whether the management of the \n\nCompany will respect objective and \nchallenging audit procedures.\n\n(2)  Whether CPA\'s non-audit service may \n\naffect the independence of CPA\'s \nauditing.\n\n(3)  Whether CPA firm enacts indepen-\ndence rules and request the itself, \nstaffs and any other person to keep \nindependence in accordance with the \nNorm of Professional Ethics for CPA, \nand prohibit insider trading, misusing \ninternal information or any behavior \nwhich the security or capital market \nmay be misleading.\n\n(4)  Whether the CPA mandatory rotation \n\nis applied and implemented to the \nlead auditor and review auditor in ac-\ncordance with competent regulations.\n\nAcer practices its corporate governance \nunder Chairman and Corp President & CEO\'s \nsupervision. The Company\'s Global Finance, \nLegal, HR, Corporate Sustainability Office \nand Internal Auditors handle related matters \nas following summary:\n1.  Developing and designing a competent \n\nsystem to improve transparency, \ncompliance and implementation of internal \nauditing.\n\n2. Responsibilities of the Remuneration Committee\n\nThe Acer Inc. \xe2\x80\x9cBoard of Directors and Supervisors Remuneration Guidelines\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cExecutive Remuneration Guideline\xe2\x80\x9d are pro-\nposed by Remuneration Committee, effective upon the approval of Acer Inc. Board of Directors. The compensation of the Board of \nDirectors is defined in \xe2\x80\x9cAcer\'s Articles of Incorporation\xe2\x80\x9d. Where there are earnings at the end of the fiscal year after making up the \nlosses of previous years. Then, if any balance left over, no more than 0.8% of profits shall be distributed as profit sharing for the \nBoard of Directors and supervisors according to Acer Inc. \xe2\x80\x9cBoard of Directors and Supervisors Remuneration Guidelines\xe2\x80\x9d. Employee \nDirector are not entitled to receive Director profit-sharing. \n\nThe remuneration of Acer executive is governed under Acer Group \xe2\x80\x9cExecutive remuneration guideline\xe2\x80\x9d. The short-term incentive \nlinks to both individual and company overall team performance, while the long-term incentive links to long-term shareholders\' \nvalue. The annual KPIs, which includes a portion of strategic KPIs assigned by the board whether financial or non-financial, ensures \nthe executive team move on the same direction to reach the strategic goal of the company. Standards of Business Conduct (SBC) \nis reminded and confirmed by each executive on the compensation sign back letter each year.\n\nAcer Incorporated 2018 Annual ReportCorporate Governance ReportAcer Incorporated 2018 Annual ReportCorporate Governance Report\x0c48\n\n49\n\nC. Not an employee of the Company or any of its affiliates.\n\n2.  Not a director or supervisor of affiliated companies. Not applicable in cases where the person is an independent director of the parent \n\ncompany, or any subsidiary as appointed in accordance with the Act or with the laws of the country of the parent or subsidiary. \n\n3.  Not a natural-person shareholder who holds shares, together with those held by the person\'s spouse, minor children, or held by the \nperson under others\' names, in an aggregate amount of 1% or more of the total number of outstanding shares of the Company, or \nranking in the top 10 in holdings.\n\n4.  Not a spouse, relative within the second degree of kinship, or lineal relative within the third degree of kinship, of any of the persons in \n\nthe preceding three sub-paragraphs.\n\n5.  Not a director, supervisor, or employee of a corporate shareholder who directly holds 5% or more of the total number of outstanding \n\nshares of the Company, or who holds shares ranking in the top five holdings.\n\n6.  Not a director, supervisor, officer, or shareholder holding 5% or more of the shares of a specified company or institution which has a \n\nfinancial or business relationship with the Company.\n\n7.  Not a professional individual, who is an owner, partner, director, supervisor, or officer of a sole proprietorship, partnership, company, \nor institution that provides commercial, legal, financial, accounting services or consultation to the Company or to any affiliate of the \nCompany, or a spouse thereof.\n\n8.  Not a person of any conditions defined in Article 30 of the Company Law.\n\nAs good corporate citizens Acer Group respect human rights, local communities and compliance with laws, environment, ethics, \nsafety standards, regulations and social norms.  Based on our core values of "Serve with honor and work with pride", we have formu-\nlated a Standards of Business Conduct (SBC) document to guide us on how we interact with each other, our customers, our business \npartners, our shareholders and the communities where the Acer Group does business. This is done every day in every decision and \nevery action by each one of us. We continue to build on our reputation for trust, integrity and honesty, both internally and exter-\nnally, by appreciating people, their diversities and cultures.\n\nYou are welcome to visit Acer Group website (http://www.acer-group.com) for the details of our \xe2\x80\x9cStandards of Business Conduct.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nItems\n\nEnforcement Status\n\nYes\n\nNo\n\nSummary\n\nDiscrepancy between the \n\ncorporate governance \nprinciples implemented \nby the Company and the \nPrinciples, and the reason \n\nfor the discrepancy\n\n1.  Establishment of Corporate \n\nConduct and Ethics Policy and \nImplementation Measures\n\n(1) Are the Company\'s guidelines \n\non corporate conduct and \nethics provided in internal \npolicies and disclosed \npublicly? Have the Board of \nDirectors and the management \nteam demonstrated their \ncommitments to implement the \npolicies?\n\n(2) Has the company established \n\nrelevant policies for preventing \nany unethical conduct? Are the \nimplementation of the relevant \nprocedures, guidelines and \ntraining mechanism provided in \nthe policies?\n\n(3) Has the company establishes \nappropriate measures against \nthe acts listed in Article 7 of the \nEthical Corporate Management \nBest Practice Principles for TWSE/\nGTSM Listed Companies or \nother higher potential unethical \nconducts in the relevant policies?\n\n4\n\n4\n\n4\n\nIntegrity is the most important core \nvalue of Acer\'s culture. The Board \nof Directors and the management \nteam are dedicated to enforcing the \nCompany\'s guideline on corporate \nconduct and ethics. \n\nIt is Acer Group\'s policy to fully comply \nwith all laws and regulations governing \nour people and operations around the \nworld and to conform to the highest \nlegal and ethical standards. The \nCompany has adopted Our "Standards \nof Business Conduct (SBC) ", "Anti-\nbribery and anti-corruption policy" and \nother relevant procedure. Furthermore, \nwe arrange new employee orientation \nand on-the-job training for our \nemployees to prevent any unethical \nconduct. Most importantly, our Internal \nAudit Unit would conduct regular \naudits to raise overall awareness, \ndetect potential misconduct and \nmonitor the procedures compliance. \n\nIn order to prevent any unethical \nconduct, we have enacted several \npolicies and guidelines, such as \nStandards of Business Conduct, \nAntitrust and Fair Competition \nGuidelines, Anti-bribery and Anti-\ncorruption Policy, Regulations on \nInsider Trading, and Rules Governing \nManagement of Personal Data, etc. In \naddition, our Legal Unit is responsible \nto review the contracts to prevent \npotential illegal risk (including request \nour vendors to sign integrity letters), \nand Audit Unit may check relevant \nbusiness relationship irregularly.\n\nNo discrepancy\n\nNo discrepancy\n\nNo discrepancy\n\nAcer Incorporated 2018 Annual ReportCorporate Governance ReportAcer Incorporated 2018 Annual ReportCorporate Governance Report\x0cDiscrepancy between the \n\ncorporate governance \nprinciples implemented \nby the Company and the \nPrinciples, and the reason \n\nfor the discrepancy\n\nNo discrepancy\n\nNo discrepancy\n\n50\n\nItems\n\nEnforcement Status\n\nYes\n\nNo\n\nSummary\n\n2.  Corporate Conduct and Ethics \n\nCompliance Practice\n\n(1) Has the company conducted \n\ninvestigation regarding unethical \nrecords with whomever the \nCompany doing business with, \nand included business conduct \nand ethics related clauses in the \nbusiness contracts.\n\n4\n\n(2) Has the Company set up \n\ndedicated unit in charge of \npromotion and execution of the \ncompany\'s corporate conduct \nand ethics?\n\n4\n\nIn addition to sending emails to our \ncustomers and suppliers to inform \nthem about our ethical policy, in order \nto further enhance our commitment \nto ethical practice, we also request our \ncontractors, vendors, suppliers and \nservice providers to sign a letter of \nundertaking to demand compliance \nwith our ethical policy. \n\nAcer Group has committed ourselves \nto meeting high standards of law and \nethics compliance to carry out our \nbusiness. The management is required \nto establish a paragon of placing a \nhigh value of corporate conduct and \nethics. Under the supervision of the \nboard of directors, HR, Legal, Internal \nAuditor, Finance, and other cross-\nfunctional teams  co-work to promote \nthe Company\'s corporate conduct \nand ethics and urge all employees and \nstakeholders to act up to the corporate \nconduct and ethics.  For the concrete \nimplementation of the code of conduct \nand ethics, the pertinent compliance \nstatus will be reported to Audit \nCommittee and the Board of Directors \nmeeting by Chief Internal Auditor. The \ncore implementation is summarized as \nfollows:\n1. Reviewing contractual terms and \nconditions to avoid dealing with \nsomeone who has negative record \nregarding corporate conduct and \nethics.\n\n2. Promoting the Company\'s \ncooperative parties to sign \nAcer\'s integrity declaration and \nundertaking (or including similar \nterms and conditions in the \ncontracts)\n\n3. Disseminating Acer\'s corporate \n\nconduct and ethics relevant policies \nto every employee.\n\n4. Requesting anyone who participates \n\nin important project to sign non-\ndisclosure agreement and promise \nnot to disclose the Company\'s \ntrade secret or other significant \ninformation to third party.\n\n5. Promoting other project with respect \nto the corporate conduct and ethics.\n\n51\n\nDiscrepancy between the \n\ncorporate governance \nprinciples implemented \nby the Company and the \nPrinciples, and the reason \n\nfor the discrepancy\n\nNo discrepancy\n\nNo discrepancy\n\nNo discrepancy\n\nNo discrepancy\n\nItems\n\nEnforcement Status\n\nYes\n\nNo\n\nSummary\n\n(3) Has the Company established \n\npolicies to prevent conflicts \nof interest and provided \nappropriate communication and \ncomplaint channels?\n\n(4) Has the Company established \n\neffective accounting and \ninternal control systems for the \nimplementation of policies, and \nthe internal or external auditors \naudit such execution and \ncompliance.\n\n4\n\n4\n\n(5) Does the Company provide \n\ntraining regarding ethic \ncompliance practice regularly?\n\n4\n\n3. Our \nfinancial reports are also audited by \nexternal auditors regularly.\n\nIt is Acer Group policy to fully comply \nwith all laws and regulations governing \nour people and operations around \nthe world and to conform to the \nhighest legal and ethical standards. \nOur Standards of Business Conduct \n(SBC) are formulated to guide the way \nAcer Group employees behave with \neach other, our customers, business \npartners, our shareholders and the \ncommunities where Acer Group does \nbusiness. Within their first month, new \nstaff are put through training to better \nunderstand the company\'s Standards of \nBusiness Conduct (including instruction \non labor rights, freedom of expression, \nsexual harassment prevention, and \ncorruption prevention), thus helping \nthem become fully integrated parts of \nthe team.\n\nIn order to enhance corporate \ngovernance, Acer provides a \nwhistleblower mailbox on our website \n(http://www.acer-group.com/public/\nInvestor_Relations/corporate.htm) \nfor people to report any threats of \ninvolvement of fraudulence, corruption, \nviolation of Acer\'s Standards of \nBusiness Conduct, any illegal conducts \nor conducts violated corporate \ngovernance by Acer employee. The \naudit office, which functions directly \nunder the board of directors, will handle \nthe report exclusively.\n\nAcer Incorporated 2018 Annual ReportCorporate Governance ReportAcer Incorporated 2018 Annual ReportCorporate Governance Report\x0c52\n\n53\n\nItems\n\nEnforcement Status\n\nYes\n\nNo\n\nSummary\n\nDiscrepancy between the \n\ncorporate governance \nprinciples implemented \nby the Company and the \nPrinciples, and the reason \n\nfor the discrepancy\n\n(2) Has the Company established \n\npolicy and security mechanisms \nregarding the procedures for \nresponding to the reports of \nethical irregularities?\n\n(3) Has the Company established \n\nmeasures to protect the identity \nof the informer? \n\n4. \n\nInformation Disclosure\n\n(1) Has the Company published \ninformation relating to the \nCompany\'s corporate conduct \nand ethics on its website or \nMarket Observation Post \nSystem?\n\n4\n\n4\n\n4\n\nAcer has established policy and security \nmechanisms regarding the procedures \nfor responding to the reports of ethical \nirregularities.\n\nNo discrepancy\n\nThe Company has taking measures to \nprotect the identity of the informer. \n\nNo discrepancy\n\nThe Company has published \ninformation relating to the Company\'s \ncorporate conduct and ethics on our \nwebsite (www.acer-group.com) and \nMarket Observation Post System.\n\nNo discrepancy\n\n5. \n\nIf the company has established corporate governance policies based on TSE Corporate Conduct and Ethics Best Practice \nPrinciples, please describe any discrepancy between the policies and their implementation: No discrepancy\n\n6. Tseng, Ji-Ren Lee, \nSan-Cheng Chang, Ching-\nHsiang Hsu\n\nAcer Incorporated 2018 Annual ReportCorporate Governance ReportAcer Incorporated 2018 Annual ReportCorporate Governance Report\x0c54\n\n55\n\n3.3.9 Statement of Internal Control System\n\n3.3.9.1 A Statement on Internal Control\n\nDate: March 20, 2019\n\nBased on the findings of a self-assessment, Acer Incorporated (hereinafter, the \xe2\x80\x9cCompany\xe2\x80\x9d) states the following with regard to its \ninternal control system during year 2018 :\n\n1.  The Company is fully aware that establishing, operating, and maintaining an internal control system are the responsibility of \nits Board of Directors and managers. The Company has established such a system aimed at providing reasonable assurance \nregarding the achievement of objectives in the following categories: (1) effectiveness and efficiency of operations (including \nprofitability, performance, and safe-guarding of assets), (2) reliability, timeliness, transparency, and regulatory compliance of \nreporting, and (3) compliance with applicable laws, regulations and bylaws.\n\n2.  An internal control system has inherent limitations. No matter how perfectly designed, an effective internal control system \ncan provide only reasonable assurance of accomplishing the three objectives mentioned above. Moreover, the effectiveness \nof an internal control system may be subject to changes of environment or circumstances. Nevertheless, the internal control \nsystem of the Company contains self-monitoring mechanisms, and the Company promptly takes corrective actions whenever \na deficiency is identified.\n\n3.  The Company evaluates the design and operating effectiveness of its internal control system based on the criteria provided \nin the \xe2\x80\x9cRegulations Governing Establishment of Internal Control Systems by Public Companies\xe2\x80\x9d promulgated by the Securi-\nties and Futures Bureau of the Financial Supervisory Commission (hereinafter, the \xe2\x80\x9cRegulations\xe2\x80\x9d). The criteria adopted by the \nRegulations identify five constituent elements of internal control based on the process of management control: (1) control en-\nvironment, (2) risk assessment, (3) control activities, (4) information and communications, and (5) monitoring activities. Each \nconstituent element further contains several items. Please refer to the Regulations for details.\n\n4.  The Company has evaluated the design and operating effectiveness of its internal control system according to the aforesaid \n\ncriteria.   \n\n5.  Based on the results of the evaluation mentioned in the preceding paragraph, the Company believes that, as of December 31, \n2018, its internal control system (including its supervision of subsidiaries), was effective in design and operation, and reason-\nably assured the achievement of the above-stated objectives.\n\n6.  This Statement will be an essential content of the Company\'s Annual Report for the year 2018 and Prospectus, and will be \npublicly disclosed. Any false-hood, concealment, or other illegality in the content made public will entail legal liability under \nArticles 20, 32, 171, and 174 of the Securities and Exchanged Act.\n\n7.  This Statement has been passed by the Board of Directors in their meeting held on March 20, 2019, with  0  of the  9  attending \n\ndirectors expressing dissenting opinions, and the remainder all affirming the content of this Statement.\n\nAcer Incorporated\n\nCEO\n\nChairman of the Board of Directors \n\n3.3.9.2 Where a CPA has been hired to carry out a special audit of the internal \n\ncontrol system, furnish the CPA audit report\n\nNone\n\n3.3.10 For the most recent fiscal year or during the current \nfiscal year up to the date of publication of the annual \nreport, disclose any sanctions imposed in accordance \nwith the law upon the company or its internal person-\nnel, any sanctions imposed by the company upon its \ninternal personnel for violations of internal control \nsystem provisions, principal deficiencies, and the state \nof any efforts to make improvements\n\nNone\n\n3.3.11 Resolutions of the Board of Directors\' Meeting and the \n\nGeneral Shareholders\' Shares\x0c66\n\n67\n\n4.1.6 Dividend Policy and the Execution\n\n4.1.6.1 Proposed Distribution of Dividends \n\nDue to rapid changes of the industrial situation and development trend, the Company\'s dividend strategy depends on annual \nearnings and external environments, therefore, the Company adopts balance dividend policy in accordance with relevant laws and \nregulations: Cash dividends shall be distributed at least ten percent of total annual dividends, such policy has been approved at the \nGeneral Shareholder\'s Meeting held on June 17, 2004.\n\n4.1.6.2 Dividends the Company Proposed to 2019 General Shareholders Meeting\n\nThe Board of Directors proposed FY2018 dividends to 2019 General Shareholders Meeting as following:\n\n(1)  The beginning balance of the un-appropriated retained earnings of the Company is NT$0 in 2018. After plus the net income \nafter tax of 2018 and the impact caused by the new accounting standards applied and the disposal of fair value through \nother comprehensive income financial assets, set aside legal reserve ad special reserve in accordance with applicable laws and \nregulations,  the total accumulative retained earnings available for appropriation is NT$2,373,276,341. It is proposed to dis-\ntribute NT$2,367,699,047 as the dividends to the shareholders, the ending balance of the unappropriated retained earnings \nis NT$5,577,294, which is reserved for distribution in the future. \n\n(2) \n\nIt is proposed to distribute the cash dividend of NT$2,367,699,047 to the shareholders whose names and respective shares \nare in the shareholders\' register on the record date for ex-dividend, at a ratio of NT$0.77 per share. (Rounded down to NT$1.0 \nand the residue will be calculated as the Company\'s other income)\n\n(3)  Should the cash distribution be adjusted due to the amendment of laws or regulations, a request by competent authorities, or \nany change of the numbers of outstanding share, subject to the approved distribution, it is proposed the General Sharehold-\ners\' Meeting to authorize the Board of Directors with full power to adjust the distribution ratio.\n\n(4)  The record date for ex-dividend is temporarily set on July 11, 2019, and the distribution date is set on August 7, 2019. Should \nthe dates above be adjusted due to the amendment of laws or regulations, a request by competent authorities, it is proposed \nthe General Shareholders\' Meeting to authorize the Board of Directors with full power to adjust accordingly.\n\n4.1.7 Analysis on Impact of Proposed Stock Dividends Ap-\n\npropriation in Terms of Operating Results, Earnings Per \nShare and Rate of Return of Shareholders\' Investment\n\nNot Applicable.\n\n(2)  Employees\' Compensation Resulted from Annual Earnings:\n\nWhere there is profit at the end of each fiscal year, after covering the accumulated losses, at least 4% of the profit shall be \ndistributed as employees\' compensation. \n\nThe employees\' compensation in the previous section may be distributed in the form of either cash or stock bonus, and \nmay be distributed to the employees of subsidiaries of this Company. Qualification requirements of the employees who are \nentitled to receive the employees\' compensation may be specified by the Board of Directors.\n\n2. The standard of accruing employee compensation and remuneration of the Board of Directors and Supervisors, the standard \nof distributing employees\' compensation in the form of stock bonus, and the accounting treatment of difference between the \nactual distribution amount and the accrued amount:\n\n  The  Company  accrues  employee  compensation  and  remuneration  of  the  Board  of  Directors  proportionally  from  the  pre-tax \nincome which referred in Acer\'s Articles of Incorporation before deducting employee compensation and remuneration of the \nBoard of Directors. Should there be any differences between the actual distribution amount and the accrued amount after the \nannual financial statements is made and ratified, the difference should be treated as changes in accounting estimates and ad-\njusted in the following year.\n\n3. Distribution of Remuneration of the Board of Directors and Employee Compensation: \n\n(1)  The total amount of employees\' compensation distributed in the form of either cash or stock bonus, and Remuneration of \nthe Board of Directors. Should there be any differences between the actual distribution amount and the accrued amount \nafter the annual financial statements is made and ratified, the revealing differences, causes and treatment:\n\nThe total amount of employees\' 2018 profit sharing bonus is NT$163,312,536, and the total amount of Board Directors\' \n2018 compensation is NT$6,910,504. The Board of Directors approved the proposal of employees\' 2018 profit sharing bo-\nnus and Board Directors\' compensation on March 20, 2019. The employees\' profit sharing bonus and Board Directors\' com-\npensation are to be distributed in cash.\n\nThere is no difference between the actual distribution amount and the accrued amount.\n\n(2)  The proportion that the amount of employees\' compensation distributed in stock bonus to net income stated in this year \n\nfinancial statement or individual financial reports, and the total amount employee compensation: N/A\n\n4. The actual distribution to the remunerations to employees, Directors and Supervisors in 2018(including distributed shares, \n\namount and price of shares.) of Restricted Stock Awards\n\nDate of Effective Registration\n\nIssue Date\n\nNumber of new shares issued\n\nIssue Price (NT$)\n\nIssued RSA Shares as a Percentage of \nShares Issued\n\n2014 1st Employee Restricted Stock Awards\n\nAugust 26,2014\n\nAugust 26,2014\n\n17,460,000 shares (Note)\n\nNone\n\n0.56 %\n\nVesting Conditions of Restricted Stock \nAwards\n\n3.  These Employee Restricted Stock Awards ("RSA\xe2\x80\x9d) are granted to the heads of \ndepartments and above (including the head of the departments), and the vest-\ning conditions are described as follows\xef\xbc\x9a\n\n1.1 Company overall performance\xef\xbc\x9a\n\n(1)  RSA can be issued as long as two of the following three company KPIs are \n\nreached in the previous year at the time of the schedule; \n\n(2)  the three KPIs in year 2014 are set in absolute targets, and as long as two \nof the three KPIs are reached,100% shares can be issued, and none will be \nissued if KPIs reached less than two.\n\n(3)  KPIs of year 2015 and beyond are set in high, medium, and low standards, \n\nwith three KPIs to reach at least two of the higher standards for the basis of \nissuance, up to the high standard can be issued 100% of shares, up to the \nmedium standard can be issued 65% of shares, up to low standard can be \nissued 40% of shares, shares do not issue if less than two KPIs are reached. \nFor example, if the three KPIs of 2015 are reached in high, medium and low \nstandards, the RSA should be issued as the medium criteria, 65% shares will \nbe awarded in this case since the medium standard is reached for at least \ntwo KPIs. \n\n(4)  In addition to the annual guideline of year 2014 is absolute and not distin-\nguished in high, medium, low standards, the KPIs are based on the growth \nrate or increase of the actual operating results of the previous year since \n2015. \n\n(5)  Detailed KPI standards are described below:\n\nKPIs\n\n2014\n\n2015 & after\n\nNet \nRevenue \n\nTurnover up \nto TWD340 \nbillion\n\nOperation \nIncome\n\nTurn loss \ninto gain\n\nEPS\n\nTurn loss \ninto gain\n\nHigh Standard: Growth 15%\nMedium Standard: Growth 10%\nLow Standard: Growth 5%\nHigh Standard: Increase TWD 3 billion\nMedium Standard: Increase TWD 2 billion\nLow Standard: Increase TWD 1 billion\nHigh Standard: Increase TWD 1 per share\nMedium Standard: Increase TWD 0.5 per share\nLow Standard: Increase TWD 0.3 per share\n\nAcer Incorporated 2018 Annual ReportCapital and SharesAcer Incorporated 2018 Annual ReportCapital and Shares\x0c70\n\n71\n\nCustody Status of Restricted Stock \nAwards\n\nThe delivery of trust custody, such as the delivery of trust custody, by the company \nor the person designated by the company on behalf of the staff and the stock Trust \n\ncustodian signed a trust contract.\n\nMeasures to be Taken When Vesting \nConditions are not Met\n\n1.   If following circumstances occur within four years of the allocation of new shares \nthat limit employee rights and the company has allocated a share that has not yet \nbeen acquired, then the company shall/should/must recover it from the employees \nwithout compensation.\n\n  (1) Voluntary-resignation, retirement\n\n  (2) Dismissal or repatriation due to labor factors\n\n  (3) Voluntary transfer to the affiliated company/enterprises\n\n2.  Employee on approved leave without pay/leave of absence within the four years \n\nof new share issuance is considered in the category of unfulfilled vested condi-\ntions of employee rights, the new shares may be restored after reinstatement. The \nvested period for which the employee\'s rights are restricted to new shares shall be \ndeferred according to the period during which the employee is not employed, and \nshall be approved in accordance with subparagraph (3.) of this article.\n\n3.  If the company\'s overall performance indicators or individual performance indica-\ntors fail to meet the vested conditions in any year before the expiration of the new \nemployee\'s rights, the company shall be allocated the shares that have not yet \nbeen acquired, and the company shall recover from employees without compensa-\ntion.\n\nNumber of New Restricted Employee \nShares that have been Redeemed or \nBought Back\n\n11,634,000 Shares\n\nNumber of Released New Restricted  \nEmployee Shares\n\n5,826,000 Shares \n\nNumber of Unreleased New Restricted \nShares\n\n0 Share(Note)\n\nRatio of Unreleased New Restricted \nShares to Total Issued Shares (%)\n\n0%\n\nImpact on possible dilution of share-\nholdings\n\nIt\'s no significant impact on the existing shareholders\' equity\n\nNote: This time to the Financial Supervisory Commission Securities and Futures Bureau to declare the issuance of limited staff rights of the total \n\nissue of 50,000,000 shares, issued a total of 17,460,000 shares on August 26th ,2014.  \n\n1.2 Employees Personal Performance: \n\n(1) On the basis of the company\'s overall performance to calculate the \nnumber of shares can be issued, personal performance is added to cal-\nculate the actual number of shares issued to individual according to the \nfollowing criteria:\n\nTimeframe\n\nPerformance\nThe performance appraisal is excellent or \nabove; Rate of 90% or above\n\nThe performance appraisal is good or above; \nRate of 80% or above\n\n1st \nyear\n100% \nshares\n\n80% \nshares\n\n2nd  \nyear\n100% \nshares\n\n80% \nshares\n\n3rd  \nyear\n100% \nshares\n\n80% \nshares\n\n4th  \nyear\n100% \nshares\n\n80% \nshares\n\nThe performance appraisal is below average\n\n0\n\n0\n\n0\n\n0\n\n(2) If the shares which are assigned to restrict the rights of employees can-\nnot be divided into four periods according to the above methods, the \nremainder will be placed in the first phase. For example, if 8550 shares are \nprovided, the number of shares divided in four years will be 2139 shares, \n2137 shares, 2137 shares and 2137 shares. \n\n(3) Calculation of the above-mentioned shares (maturity of shares X company\'s \n\noverall performance issuance standard x individual performance issuance \ncriteria) as of the unit, less than 1 share is rounded down unconditionally. \nFor example, 2139 shares x 65% x 80% = 1112.28 shares were rounded \ndown to 1112 shares.\n\n2. Assigned to the long-term commitment and special contributors (reported by the \n\nrelevant units, after review by the Human Resources Unit, and approved by the \nBoard), both the conditions to "limit the rights of employees new shares" after the \nlength of service as a guideline, its time and the proportion of the following:\n\nTimeframe\n\nPerformance\nThe performance appraisal is excellent or \nabove; Rate of 90% or above\n\nThe performance appraisal is good or above; \nRate of 80% or above\n\n1st \nyear\n100% \nshares\n\n80% \nshares\n\n2nd  \nyear\n100% \nshares\n\n80% \nshares\n\n3rd  \nyear\n100% \nshares\n\n80% \nshares\n\nThe performance appraisal is below average\n\n0\n\n0\n\n0\n\n4th  \nyear\n\n100% shares\n\n80% \nshares\n\n0\n\n1.  The employee shall not, except for inheritance, sell, pledge, transfer, give to oth-\ners, set up, or otherwise dispose of the new shares after the employees have been \ngranted new shares without achieving the acquired conditions. If the employee \nmeets the conditions, the entrusted Trust custodian shall allocate the shares \nfrom the trust account to the individual collection and insurance account of the \nemployee. \n\n2.  The rights of shareholders\' meetings, proposals, speeches, voting and the right to \nvote shall be the same as those issued by the company since the appointment of \nthe employees and entrusted to the custodian of the trust. The new stock restrict-\ning the rights of employees can still participate in the distribution of shares, but \nthe rights and interests of the shares are not limited by the conditions.\n\n3.  Employees are assigned under these measures to restrict the rights of employ-\n\nees of new shares, before the acquisition of the acquired conditions, other rights \ninclude, but are not limited to: dividends, dividends, capital reserve distribution \nrights, cash replenishment of the equity, etc., with the same rights as the common \nshares which company has issued.\n\n4.  The Company shall cease the transfer date, the cash dividend stop transfer date, \nthe shareholders under article 165-3 of the Company law, or any other period of \nstatutory suspension of transfer in accordance with the facts to the base date of \nthe right assignment, during which the acquired conditions shall be reached, It has \nthe time and procedure of lifting the limitation of stock to be carried out in accor-\ndance with the trust custody contract or the relevant regulations.\n\nRestricted rights of employees Re-\nstricted Stock Awards\n\nAcer Incorporated 2018 Annual ReportCapital and SharesAcer Incorporated 2018 Annual ReportCapital and Shares\x0c72\n\n73\n\n4.7 Issuance of New Shares Due to Company\'s \n\nMergers and Acquisitions\n\nNone\n\n4.8 Issuance of New Shares by Cash\n\nNone\n\nList of Executives Receiving New Restricted Employee Shares \nand the Top Ten Employees & Consultants with New Re-\nstricted Employee Shares (March 31, 2019)\n\nNo. of New \nRestricted  \n\nShares\n\nNew \n\nRestricted  \nShares as a\nPercentage \nof Shares \n\nIssued\n\nReleased\n\nUnreleased\n\nNo. of \nShares\n\nIssued \nPrice\n(NT$)\n\nAmount\n(NT$ \n\nthousands)\n\nReleased \nRestricted  \nShares as a \nPercentage \nof Shares \n\nIssued\n\nNo. of \nShares\n\nIssued \nPrice\n(NT$)\n\nAmount\n(NT$ \n\nthousands)\n\nReleased \nRestricted  \nShares as a \nPercentage \nof Shares \n\nIssued\n\n2,100,000\n\nShares\n\n0.068%\n\n866,250 \nShares\n(Note 1)\n\n0 \n\n0 \n\n0.028%\n\n0 Share\n\n0 \n\n0 \n\n0%\n\n2,040,000 \n\nShares\n\n0.066%\n\n817,800 \nShares\n(Note 2)\n\n0 \n\n0 \n\n0.027%\n\n0 Share\n\n0 \n\n0 \n\n0%\n\nTitle\n\nName\n\nChairman & \nCEO\n\nJason Chen\n\nCorp.
