As Acer looks into \nthe future, it is focused on enabling a world where hardware, software and services will fuse with one another to open up new pos-\nsibilities for consumers and businesses alike. From service-oriented technologies to the Internet of Things and to gaming, Acer\'s \n7,000+ employees are dedicated to the research, design, marketing, sale, and support of products and solutions that break barri-\ners between people and technology. \n\nThe revenue contribution by Acer\'s PC business is led by notebooks with 60 percent share, followed by desktops with 14 percent \nshare, displays (PC monitors and projectors) with 13 percent share. \n\n5.1.1.2 Industry Highlights\n\n1.  Status and Opportunity: AIoT is the convergence of artificial intelligence (AI) and internet of things (IoT) technologies and \nsolutions, which leads to smarter networks and systems that are becoming ever more capable of solving problems across a \ndiverse number of industry verticals. AIoT, devices must directly connect to the cloud, and thereby opening the way for a wider \nscope of innovation. AI adds value to IoT with big data analytics and machine learning to more sophisticated decision making, \nwhile IoT brings the additional benefits of connectivity, signaling, and data exchange to AI. Medical, smart transportation or \ncities are such examples of the various new possibilities that arise through AIoT.\n\n2.  Upstream to Downstream Suppliers: Acer\'s upstream suppliers include the CPU, chipset, graphics chip, DRAM, and other semi-\nconductor industries, as well as system programing and software industries. The midstream suppliers include motherboard, \nchassis, keyboard, monitor displays, optoelectronics, hard disk, battery, power supply, and other computer peripherals indus-\ntries. The downstream suppliers include notebook, desktop, projector, server and other OEM/ODM system assembly industries.\n\n3.  Trends: Acer\'s IT product business includes notebook and desktop PCs, projectors, monitors, digital signage, gadgets and other \nsmart devices. While continuing to research and innovate to enhance its product offerings, Acer will also dedicate more re-\nsources to high-margin products such as gaming PCs and gadgets to optimize investments. With the prevalence of AIoT, Acer \nis actively investing in new businesses, including software and devices for cloud applications, along with people-centric ser-\nvices to integrate ICT devices to create new solutions and business models.\n\nThrough its subsidiary, Altos Computing, it supplies servers integrated with other software and services to offer a wide range \nof solutions, and has won 12 high-performance computing (HPC) tenders in 2018. Acer is also stepping up its presence in the \ndigital signage and Chrome for enterprise markets.\n\n4.  Competition: The PC industry continues to demand thinner, lighter, and mobile devices. Acer has successfully introduced a se-\nries of notebooks weighing under 1 kg and measuring less than 1 cm thin. Gaming competition is also rigorous. Acer stands out \nfrom competition by introducing generation after generation of its advanced thermal cooling solutions to enable machines to \nrun at peak performance.\n\n5.1.1.3  Technology and R&D\n\nIn 2018, Acer spent NT$2.56 billion on research and development, which accounted for 1.06% of total revenues, focusing on user \ninterface, industrial design, ICT related hardware and software, cloud, and gaming technology. In addition, the company is build-\ning on its existing PC business and expanding into new areas that can seamlessly integrate PCs with new software applications, \n\nAcer Incorporated 2018 Annual ReportAcer\xe2\x80\x99s Business FormulaAcer Incorporated 2018 Annual ReportAcer\xe2\x80\x99s Business Formula\x0c76\n\n77\n\nand also integrate cloud platforms with cloud services to complete the transition to a \xe2\x80\x9chardware + software + services\xe2\x80\x9d company. \nWith a focus on differentiated and high-margin products, Acer adopts an efficient product-mix strategy that tailors to the needs \nof individual markets.\n\nUnderscoring the importance we place on research and development, in 2018 Acer was ranked among the top 3 in the number of \nTaiwan patent applications with 476 filings, up 25 percent from the previous year.\n\nWith the commitment in designing for customer needs, Acer is proud to have received many international design awards for excel-\nlence in 2018 and made progress in the development of new technologies for the future:\n\nDesign Awards\n\xe2\x80\xa2  Three 2018 Good Design Awards of Japan - The award-winning products are the Acer OJO 500 Windows Mixed Reality headset, \n\nSwift 7 ultrathin laptop, and Acer Chromebook 11.\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2  Acer Chromebook 11 clinched Gold at the Computex d&i Awards 2018, the most coveted honor. Three more products also won \n\nthe d&i award \xe2\x80\x93 Acer Chromebox, Swift 7 and Switch 7 Black Edition notebooks.\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2  Multiple Computex Best Choice Awards in the fields of IoT, gaming, and consumer tech with the Acer Air Monitor, Acer Win-\n\ndows Mixed Reality Headset, and Acer Leap Beads.\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2  13 Red Dot Design Awards 2018 of Germany, setting Acer\'s historical high. Award-winning entries are:\n\n \xe2\x9e\xa2 Gaming line - Predator Triton 700 notebook, Predator Galea 500 headset, Nitro 5 notebook, Nitro RG0 and VG0 series \n\nmonitors\n\n \xe2\x9e\xa2 Notebooks - Swift 5, Spin 5 convertible, Swift 7\n\n \xe2\x9e\xa2 Chrome OS devices - Chromebox CXI3, Chromebook Tab 10\n\n \xe2\x9e\xa2 Desktops \xe2\x80\x93 Veriton N series\n\n \xe2\x9e\xa2 Projectors \xe2\x80\x93 VL7860 and C200\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2  12 iF Design Awards 2018 of Germany \xe2\x80\x93 led by Acer\'s gaming devices, software and packaging designs: Predator Orion 9000 \n\ndesktop, Predator Triton 700 notebook, Predator X27 monitor, Predator X34P monitor, PredatorSense\xe2\x84\xa2 software and Predator \nGaming Gadget packaging design. Other award winners are the Swift 7 notebook, Aspire S 24 all-in-one desktop, VG0 series \ngaming monitor, Holo360 and Vision360 cameras, and Pawbo Wagtag pet tracker.\n\nNew Technologies\n\xe2\x80\xa2 \n\nIn the realm of smart cities, Acer\'s subsidiary Acer ITS won the \xe2\x80\x9cGlobal ICT Excellence Award - Private Sector Excellence,\xe2\x80\x9d which \nis regarded as the Olympics of the global ICT industry, for its smart parking meter solution. This solution has become Taiwan\'s \nfirst roadside Smart Parking Meter build\xe2\x80\x93operate\xe2\x80\x93transfer (BOT) project in collaboration with the Tainan city government, with \nparking meters implemented along 2,000 spaces across the city.\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2  Venturing into technology for the future, Acer\'s Value Lab collaborated with one of Taiwan\'s top automakers to showcase the \n\nvision of artificial intelligence (AI) and autonomous driving technology with a level 4-ready self-driving concept car. Acer \nstepped up the development further by cooperating with Taiwan\'s National Yang-Ming University School of Medicine to \nimprove the passenger experience, where the physiological state of passengers during the technology development stage is \nmonitored to improve comfortability of the ride even during unexpected situations.\n\n5.1.1.4   Long and Short Term Business Plan\n\nAcer is engaging in dual transformation with its core business and new initiatives. It will continue to optimize the foundations \nof existing product lines and innovations, along with the development of software applications, integrating cloud platforms and \ncloud services. \n\nExpanding its business boundaries, Acer aims to identify and incubate micro trends, followed by the scale up of feasible technolo-\ngies, to ultimately create multiple growth engines for the company\'s future.\n\n5.1.2 Market Highlights\n\n5.1.2.1 Market Analysis\n\n1. Market Share of PC Products\n\nAcer\'s 2018 revenue breakdown by regional operations were: Pan Asia Pacific with 38 percent share, EMEA with 35 percent share, \nand Pan America with 27 percent share. In worldwide PC shipments (Source: IDC), Acer ranked No. 4 for total PCs with 7 percent \nshare, No. 5 for notebooks with 8 percent share, and No. 4 for desktops with 4 percent share.\n\n2. The Future of Market Demand and Supply\n\nAccording to IDC, the growth of global PC shipments has officially reached saturation. However, the gradual development of 5G has \nbrought about the emergence of related IoT applications. In esports, its core development is based around the user experience and \nwhat is otherwise known as the "Gaming 3.0" era in Taiwan. In addition to hardware development, brand companies must embrace \nthose opportunities arising from the huge esports ecosystem with diversified business models and innovative applications.\n\nUnder this market condition, Acer will continue to focus on high-growth products, such as Chromebooks, thin-and-light note-\nbooks, and gaming PCs; in addition, the new brand \xe2\x80\x9cConceptD\xe2\x80\x9d launched in 2019 for "creators" is expected to inject fresh energy \ninto the overall stagnant PC industry. In 2018, Acer gaming products, Chromebooks, and among others, have reaped fruitful re-\nsults. Acer ranked No. 1 in worldwide gaming notebooks with 46 percent growth year-on-year (source: GFK and NPD, 2018), and \nNo. 1 worldwide for Chromebooks with 31 percent market share (source: IDC for Q4, 2018). In the year ahead, the company will \ncontinue to observe users\' needs and identify micro-trends that have the potential to create a new blue ocean of opportunities. \nIn parallel to focusing on its core PC products, Acer will persist in developing multiple growth engines, and integrate \xe2\x80\x9csoftware + \nhardware + services\xe2\x80\x9d to become a forward-looking company.\n\n3. Competitive Advantage\n\nAcer is engaging in a dual transformation of its core business and new initiatives. Underscoring the importance the company \nplaces on research and development, in 2018 Acer ranked among the top three in the number of Taiwan patent applications with \n476 filings for design.\n\nIn addition, its R&D takes into account of the design thinking process and key technologies, creating a competitive advantage for \nthe company and resulting in the launch of numerous highly competitive and innovative products. In new business developments, \nAcer has shifted away from traditional computer hardware manufacturers\' mindset. Its Value Lab has gradually invested more \nresources in developing artificial intelligence, big data and more, while exploring new business models to create opportunities for \ngrowth. Acer also has a number of subsidiaries in diverse scopes of business including information security, smart transportation, \nservers, digital signage solutions, and are just some examples of its multiple growth engines.\n\nIn terms of sales channel reach, Acer has a presence in over 160 countries and a lean organization for effective and fast decision \nmaking. Its R&D, design, marketing, sales, and services all adopt a global strategy, which is the company\'s advantage.\n\n4. Advantages, Disadvantages and Counter Measures\n\nAdvantages\n\n(1)  The traditional PC market is stagnating, segmentation of the market has become the mainstream. Acer focuses on PCs in the \nareas of thin-and-light, gaming, creators,  Chromebooks, and more, for different users\' needs. Market segments are further \ndivided to address specific users, for example, gaming PCs for hardcore and casual gamers.\n\n(2)  Facing the rapidly changing market dynamics, innovation and entrepreneurship pave the way to the future. Ranking in the top \nthree in the number of Taiwan patent applications with 476 filings, among these, Acer was one of the top 10 domestic compa-\nnies in the design patent category. These achievements demonstrate that design and innovation are Acer\'s competitive edge.\n\nAcer Incorporated 2018 Annual ReportAcer\xe2\x80\x99s Business FormulaAcer Incorporated 2018 Annual ReportAcer\xe2\x80\x99s Business Formula\x0c78\n\n79\n\n(3)  With a presence in over 160 countries, Acer has a comprehensive network of sales channels, and a lean organization for effec-\n\ntive and fast decision making.\n\n(4)  Corporate social responsibilities: Acer and its subsidiaries adhere to the brand spirit of  \xe2\x80\x9cinnovative caring.\xe2\x80\x9d The three key \npillars of CSR are sustainable operations, financial transparency, and caring for the environment, while keeping a balance of \nstakeholders and company interests, lifting the brand image of Acer as a whole.\n\nDisadvantages and Countermeasures:\n\n(1)  The volatile and rapidly changing ICT industry presents a challenge to forecast the future PC demand with accuracy. \n\nActions: Continue to adopt \xe2\x80\x9cdual transformation\xe2\x80\x9d as the core strategy, explore different  markets and launch products for dif-\nferent applications, identify micro trends for a blue ocean of opportunities. In addition to core PC businesses, fulfill \nthe needs of more user groups and market segments; Acer is expanding its offering to smart wearable devices, smart \nparking solutions, information security and others, to discover new opportunities.\n\n(2)  Market volatility may result in greatly fluctuating demands. \n\nActions: Acer and its subsidiaries will continue to adopt the channel business model and strengthen cooperation with key sup-\npliers and distributors, while continuously optimizing the monitoring of market demands. In addition, e-commerce \nsales models have been adopted to directly serve consumers and understand their preferences.\n\n5.1.2.2 Key Products and Manufacturing Process\n\n1.Current product and service offering\n\n(1)  Notebook PCs\n\n(2)  Desktop PCs\n\n(3)  LCD monitors\n\n(4)  Projectors\n\n(5)  Servers\n\n(6)  Gaming\n\n(7)  Gadgets\n\n(8)  Mixed reality devices\n\n(9)  Cloud services and edge-computing devices\n\n(10) E-business and services\n\n(11) Commercial software\n\n(12) Digital signage solutions\n\n2.Manufacturing process\n\nAcer and its subsidiaries outsource all manufacturing, and are not directly involved in the manufacturing processes. However, to \nfulfill its responsibilities as a corporate citizen, and to support global standards in strictly controlling the use of harmful environ-\nmental substances, the company released the \xe2\x80\x9cGuidelines for the Control of Restricted Substances\xe2\x80\x9d, which suppliers required to \nadhere to in the restriction of harmful substances including chemicals. Since July 1, 2006, all Acer products have complied with the \nEuropean Union\'s Restriction of Hazardous Substances (RoHS) and with the RoHS Recast to ban four types of phthalates. In addi-\ntion, the company\'s products are designed to reduce environmental impact from stages from design, packaging, transportation, \nusage, through to recycling for the goal of reducing harmful impacts on the environment. For example, in 2018, Acer achieved 100 \npercent use of recycled paper for its products, saving the earth\'s resources.\n\n5.1.3 Production Process of Key Products\n\nAcer has long-term cooperation with reputable firms, in and out of Taiwan, for the supply for raw materials. In addition, the com-\npany joined the Electronic Industry Citizenship Coalition in 1997, which later became the Responsible Business Alliance (RBA), \nand continues to be an active participant in the organization\'s actions. The company strictly prohibits suppliers from using com-\nponents and finished products produced with raw materials obtained illegally or via inhumane ways; or purchasing tantalum, tin, \ntungsten and gold (known as 3TG) from sources with direct or indirect funding or benefits from armed groups of the Congo or \nneighboring countries. Acer also updated the \xe2\x80\x9cResponsible Raw Materials Purchasing Policy\xe2\x80\x9d in 2017 by expanding the scope of \nmineral management beyond 3TG and Congo to ensure minerals management is consistent with the OECD\'s guidance for mineral \nsupply chains in conflict-affected and high-risk areas. The company requires suppliers to provide mineral procurement policies \nand processes, and shoulder the responsibility of social and environmental protection.\n\nSince 2016, the company has expanded its supplier responsibility management to the second-tier supplier (i.e. the supplier of sup-\npliers), and plans to expand to third-tier suppliers in 2021 to promote a positive cycle for sustainable future.\n\n5.1.4  Key Buyers and Suppliers Accounting Over 10% of Total \n\nNet Sales and Purchase:\n\n(1) Key Buyers for Acer Group: None\n\n(2) Key Suppliers for Acer Future\n\n5.3 Employees\n\nEngaging in dual transformation for core IT business and new initiatives, Acer continues to pursue business growth and expansion, \nand upholds the following business philosophy and strategies:\n\n5.3.1 Global Human Asset Management\n\n5.2.1 Focus on competitive IT products with high margin in-\n\ncluding the gaming PC market\n\nCombining the strength and scale of its core products business with the innovation and integration capabilities of new businesses, \nAcer is transforming into a \xe2\x80\x9chardware + software + services\xe2\x80\x9d company. In addition, Acer is reinforcing its core competencies: en-\ntrepreneurship, innovation, talent cultivation and brand value, and aims to deepen the qualities of \xe2\x80\x9ctrust\xe2\x80\x9d, \xe2\x80\x9cinnovation\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cex-\ncellence\xe2\x80\x9d associated with the Acer brand. The company will continue to push for operational growth through an efficient mix of \npeople-centric products with unique designs and innovative technologies that create high margins and address the market needs.\n\nThe gaming line of powerful devices with advanced thermal cooling technologies and sensational designs like the Predator Thro-\nnos gaming chair are creating statements with their premium quality and high performance. Participation in esports events like \nLeague of Legends World Championships and hosting its own Asia Pacific Predator League has enabled Acer to engage new audi-\nences while bringing game-changing designs first to market.\n\nIn the PC market, Acer seeks to focus on segments with high growth potential; such as the thin and light notebooks, Chromebooks, \nand displays, where Acer as delivered many award-winning innovations.\n\n5.2.2 Internalize the Wang-dao philosophy into the corpo-\nrate culture, and create value based on profitability \nfirst\n\nThe Wangdao philosophy of altruism is the foundation of Acer\'s transformation. Through the philosophy\'s three key areas of focus \n\xe2\x80\x93 Sustainable Development, Value Creation, Balance of Interests, Acer places the interests of its stakeholders, including sharehold-\ners and employees, at the forefront of business success. Acer continually strives to innovate in the field of technology and create \nvalue with its partners and stakeholders alike to pursue sustainable development.\n\nEmployees are the Company\'s key assets and the main driver of business growth. Acer has fostered a work environment that em-\npowers employees by entrusting them with the tasks matched to their skill or qualification. There are clear objectives and reward \nfor achievement, extensive communication and interaction among coworkers, constant encouragement for innovations, and an \neffective decision making process. On-the-job training provides the ideal platform for learning and development.\n\nAs a result of employees\' joint effort, Acer has received numerous industry and media recognition. For example, Acer has been \nlisted on the DJSI Sustainability Indices (Emerging Markets Index) for the fourth consecutive year, and the second time on the FT-\nSE4Good Emerging Index in year 2017; scored eight 2017 Good Design Awards for outstanding products design. All above results \nare contributed by our most valuable assets: our employees.\n\n-Human Asset Analysis by Manpower, Average Age and Years of Employment\n\nCategory\n\nDate\n\nManpower\n\nAverage Age\n\nAverage Years of Employment\n\nMale (%)\n\nFemale (%)\n\nEnd of 2016\n\nEnd of 2017\n\nEnd of 2018\n\nMarch of 2019\n\n7,033\n\n37.4\n\n7.7\n\n64.7%\n\n35.3%\n\n7,046\n\n38.7\n\n8.0\n\n63.8%\n\n36.2%\n\n7,338\n\n39.6\n\n8.4\n\n62.8%\n\n37.2%\n\n7,305\n\n39.8\n\n8.5\n\n62.5%\n\n37.5%\n\n-Human Asset Analysis by Job Function\n\nDate\n\nJob Function\n\nGeneral Management\n\nSales & Product Marketing\n\nCustomer Service\n\nResearch & Development\n\nSales Support\n\nAdministration\n\nTotal\n\nEnd of 2016\n\nEnd of 2017\n\nEnd of 2018\n\nMarch of 2019\n\n202\n\n2,323\n\n1,997\n\n859\n\n851\n\n801\n\n7,033\n\n183\n\n2,205\n\n1,866\n\n1,035\n\n859\n\n898\n\n7,046\n\n202\n\n2,233\n\n1,831\n\n1,172\n\n957\n\n943\n\n7,338\n\n199\n\n2,206\n\n1,849\n\n1,153\n\n990\n\n908\n\n7,305\n\n5.2.3 Transforming with effective strategies\n\n- Human Asset Analysis by Education Level\n\nAcer diligently builds on the synergy of partnerships and utilize resources to effectively operate and grow its business. We are committed to providing equal opportunities and prohibit-\ning discrimination against candidates in regards to their ethnic origin, gender, age, religion or nationality, and we are sticking to \nthe principle of putting the right people at the right position. Acer seeks high-potential candidates with multi-disciplinary back-\ngrounds in order to build a strong global workforce. \n\n5.3.3 Continuing Learning and Growth\n\nPeople Development and Career Growth\n\nFor sustaining Acer\'s competitiveness in multiple business arenas, Acer introduces multiple growth engines by creating new busi-\nness entities and proceeding toward stock exchange market. In 2018, in aligning with the project of developing top leaders for \nbusiness venture, a series of trainings were held for developing top leaders in the capacity of corporate governance, business acu-\nmen, accounting and financial analysis, industry trend analysis, global business operation, team leadership, and decision-making.\n\nFor the efforts to implement the trainings in 2018, we followed the corporate strategic development direction to develop the orga-\nnizational capabilities of core and new business for optimizing the synergy of a fleet of teams.  We, therefore, laid the emphasis on \nthe development of trending knowledge, technology and business opportunities, digital marketing proficiency, and continued to \nenhance the capabilities in integrating hardware, software, and services, with the aim to creating values and boosting profitability, \nultimately leading to higher brand premium.   \n\n\xe2\x80\xa2 \n\nIn management training we were positioned to enhance people management skills, including people selection and interview \nskills, goal setting, management communication, coaching skills, motivating and retaining people, and performance manage-\nment skills, in order to lead the team-members in more effective way.\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2  For professional field training, the trend analysis forums were systematically held, helping the product development teams \nunderstand the end-users\' requirements and grasp the trending direction, so that they may apply it to the new product devel-\nopment or solutions provided.\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2 \n\nIn shaping more competitive brand premium, we were committed to exploring the new trend of serving end-users.  In 2018, \nwith the trend development focus, we held the trainings or seminars about AI tech, social media tactics, smart tech applied in \ninnovative services and information securities.\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2  As for general education and training, by guiding staff in their application of the latest technological trends to marketing and \nsales, we were able to make our workforce more effective and more efficient.  Directed by our core values, we continued to \npromote the full range of skills, including fostering innovation, improving cross-team cooperation, project management and \nBusiness English communication skills.\n\nTo ensure the quality implementation of such training, all trainings were conducted in accordance with the "Management Process \nof Internal and External Training." In 2018, a global total of 22,542 attendees participated in such training, accounting for 96,108 \nman-hours.  All training was done in accordance with the principles of operational necessity, gender equality, and equal opportu-\nnity.\n\n83\n\nMultiple Approaches of Learning and Development\n\nEach employee was provided with multiple development paths to enhance the profession. For example, from company within, such \nopportunities can be found as on-the-job training, coaching, job rotation, speech, online learning.  For the company outside, they \nincluded profession club seminars, short-term intensive training hosted by the prestigious universities or training institutions.  \n\nFor developing the senior leaders, we got rid of the traditional learning and took highly interactive learning approach, for example, \nwe invited the senior professionals who served in Acer to share the experience of business operation in the past.  For example, the \nforum of global company merging experience, where they had in-depth discussion triggered among these managers.  With the \nexperience sharing, we passed on the Acer\'s business operation culture and belief, in the expectation of reducing trials and errors \nand further enhancing the business capabilities.\n\nManagement Systems\n\nSenior\nManager\n\nMid\n\nManager\n\nSupervisory\n\nManager\n\nGeneral\nManager\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2 \nIPO Leaders Training Series\n\xe2\x80\xa2  Spokesman Training(for IPO \n\nLeaders)\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2  Corporate Governance\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2  Mid-Level Manager Training\n\xe2\x80\xa2  Delegation Skills\n\xe2\x80\xa2  Motvating and Retaining Talents\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2  Ownership for Achieving Goals\n\xe2\x80\xa2  Cross-Departmental \n\nCommunication and Conflict \nDealings\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2  Supervisory-Level Management\n\xe2\x80\xa2  Problem Analysis and Solving\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2  Project Management\n\xe2\x80\xa2  Execution Efficiency\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2  Core Values Training\n\xe2\x80\xa2  Communications Skills Training\n\xe2\x80\xa2  Cloud Applications (Digital \n\nMarketing, Social Media)\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2  Self-Management Training\n\xe2\x80\xa2  Office Computer Applications \n\nTraining\n\n1. Managerial Training\n\nFor the training at senior level, in 2018, we held a series of trainings for IPO leaders to develop the leaders holding the key posi-\ntions.  In addition, to emphasize the concept of corporate governance, we invited a lawyer from a law consulting firm specializing \nin the field to host the training of the corporate governance and the Securities and Exchange Act of Taiwan, and invited Professor \nJi-Ren Lee of Taiwan of College of Management in National Taiwan University to share the practices of remuneration committee of \nthe Board of Directors.\n\nWith regard to strengthening mid and supervisory-level management\'s managerial capabilities, we continued our focus on the \nhuman touch awareness in managerial competencies.  For the managers\' training, it was planned in two phases.  The first phase \nequipped the managers with the competencies in management communication, coaching, performance management for en-\nhancing the performance of the team and individuals, and the second phase helped the managers develop the skills in selecting \nthe best talents, goal setting, motivating and retaining talents, and performance management in practices.\n\nIn EMEA, to advance the leadership for the senior managers, some of EMEA managers were assigned to attend the five-day senior \nleadership training of London Business School, and the management programs at Lausanne\'s International Institute for Manage-\nment Development (IMD).  We were endeavored to assisting these leaders to understand the latest trend of management and help \n\nAcer Incorporated 2018 Annual ReportAcer\xe2\x80\x99s Business FormulaAcer Incorporated 2018 Annual ReportAcer\xe2\x80\x99s Business Formula\x0c84\n\n85\n\nmake full use of their advantages under the condition of VUCA (Volatility, Uncertainty, Complexity and Ambiguity) environment to \nmake quick and appropriate responses.\n\nIn Pan America Regional Office, to promote the notion of free trade and fair competition, we held the anti-trust training for the \nsenior managers and PM/BM; Besides, to call attention to the importance of privacy protection, including the collection, use, pro-\ntection of personal data, we held the training of privacy act enacted by the State of California.  For reinforcing our leadership skills \nin the field of customer service quality department, we held the experience sharing forums of dealing with difficult customers.  Also, \nfor strengthening the workplace safety of warehouses, the forklift training was held.\n\nIn Pan Asia Regional Office, we organized top sales training (3 days) for Indian sales team to enhance their selling skills, with a total \nof 264 persons having attended.  In Malaysia, we held the training of selling skills and help the teams to the get familiarized with \nkey features of the products, with a total of 576 persons having attended.  In Thailand, for assuring customer service and satisfac-\ntion, the Customer Service Quality Training was held, attracting 71 persons to attend.  For enhancing the selling skills for the team \nof Oceanic areas (Australia and New Zealand), we included the 9 senior top managers to attend the workshop of leadership skills \nin selling teams.\n\n2. Professional Training\n\nThis  system  provided  the  technical  training  required  by  the  Company\'s various  departments,  as well  as  seminars  by  specialist \nspeakers given to help keep staff up on the latest trends in product development.  In 2018, marked the start of our series of semi-\nnars on business trends, with a team of senior analysis from the Institute for Information Industry, they were invited each month \nto discuss with production-line staff analyses and observations on IoT consumer trends. These seminars covered topics including \nAI applications in medical industries, the trend and development of smart cars, the development of LPWA (Low-Power Wide-Area), \nand the trend of Brain Informatics.  Each department also held its own experience sharing sessions, with many focusing on imple-\nmenting consumer insights in product concepts or discussing how to make business opportunities through product innovation.\n\n3. General Training\n\nThe focuses of our general education courses were on English communication skills, for example, Business English listening- Strat-\negy and Tactics, the Mostly-used Sentence Patterns of Business English, the tone accent of English, etc.  For employing the techni-\ncal tools for enhancing work efficiency, we held the BI analysis Report using Excel and essential functions of Excel.\n\nWe also continued to promote stronger core competencies and basic professional skills through courses covering areas like im-\nproving workplace communication and the protection and use of patents. In marketing, we covered areas including digital mar-\nketing success secrets, the method of story-telling for effective selling and the IT product trends by examining CES (Consumer \nElectronics Show) 2018.  In order to promote the awareness in the area of securing personal data, we continued holding General \nData Protection Regulations (GDPR) training. To strengthen corporate governance, regulate risks, and assure business ethics, we \nconducted the training of Anti-Bribery and Anti-Corruption.\n\n4. New Employee Training\n\nOn their first day of work, new staff were given orientation training to help them quickly come to grips with the Company\'s basic op-\nerating processes. Within their first month, new staff were put through training to better understand the company\'s mechanisms, \nregulations, core values, brand values, corporate culture, and the Standards of Business Conduct (including instruction on labor \nrights, freedom of expression, individual privacy rights, sexual harassment prevention, and corruption prevention), thus helping \nthem become fully integrated parts of the team.\n\nNew staff working in product-related positions also received training on patent protection, CSR (including green products, EICC, \nand greenhouse gasses), and electrostatic discharge (ESD). We also actively encourage staff to take training in CPR and automated \nexternal defibrillator (AED) use.\n\n5. Performance Management and Development\n\nThe goal of Acer\'s performance management and development system is to improve performance at individual, departmental \nand organizational levels, and includes goal setting, delegation, communication & coaching, the link between performance & \nremuneration, and career development. In 2018, the proportion of Acer\'s global employees involved in performance evaluations \napproached 80%.\n\n5.3.4 Compensation\n\nAcer provides a competitive salary package to attract and retain high-potential human assets. The Company surveys global IT \ncompanies\' salary levels annually, to ensure that our salary packages are adjusted accordingly and reasonably to reflect market \nconditions. On top of the monthly salary, the Company offers the bonuses that are differentiated from the performance of busi-\nness unit and each individual. Taking Taiwan for example, in addition to the fixed monthly salary and festival bonuses, Acer offers \nincentives that reward new innovations, intellectual property rights, sales achievements, performance bonus and profit sharing.\n\n5.3.5 Welfare\n\nThe Company abides to each country\'s labor laws and customs, and strives to provide a comfortable working environment, at-\ntractive welfare programs, candid communication ways to enhance productivity and creativity. Taking Taiwan for example, Acer \nhas established a welfare committee that initiates activities for employees\' welfare. For example: educational grants, Acer Family \nDays, internal social clubs, speeches on topics of arts appreciation, domestic and overseas holiday breaks, gift money for wedding \nor funeral, and emergency relief measures, etc.  Besides, we have recreation and leisure facilities installed in office area to release \nemployees\' pressure from work, and provide health-promotion programs to keep the body and mind well-balanced.\n\n5.3.6 Pension \n\nThe Company abides to each country\'s labor laws and customs. Taking Taiwan for example, Acer conforms to the Labor Standards \nAct and Labor Pension Act by contributing a portion of employees\' salaries toward a pension scheme. Besides, employees who have \nserved for 15 years and have reached 50 years of age can apply for early retirement.\n\nAcer Incorporated 2018 Annual ReportAcer\xe2\x80\x99s Business FormulaAcer Incorporated 2018 Annual ReportAcer\xe2\x80\x99s Business Formula\x0c86\n\n87\n\n5.3.7 Employee Relations\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2   Sexual Harassment Prevention Measures\n\nAcer respects employees\' opinions and is dedicated to maintaining a harmonious relation between managers and their team mem-\nbers. In the past two years, Acer has not suffered any financial loss from employee conflict. \n\nTaking Taiwan for example, Acer offers multiple channels for interaction in order to improve two-way communication:\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2  A Dedicated Hotline: A hotline for each supporting function has been set up for employees to call, in confidence, to express \n\nconcerns or issues. Acer will provide counsel and/or resolve the issues in the most efficient way.\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2  Open and Candid Communication Channels: Employees can report areas of concern to their immediate supervisor or choose to \nconvey to higher authorities for resolution. Meanwhile, the Company Chairman & CEO meets face-to-face with employee rep-\nresentatives from each office area on a quarterly basis, to discuss areas of improvement and respond to issues. The Chairman & \nCEO also assigns the relevant member(s) to aggressively follow up on change or improvement, and to report on progress at the \nnext quarterly meeting to ensure the resolution effectiveness. The meeting minutes are published on the Company Intranet for \nall employees\' attention.\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2  The Chairman & CEO also hold face-to-face communication meetings to deliver new vision, strategies, and action plans, so as \n\nto assure the general staff have a clear understanding of communication messages.  \n\n5.3.8 Acer Employee Management\n\nStandards of Business Conduct\n\nAcer has formulated the Standards of Business Conduct (SBC) to serve as the guide to regulate the interactions between the em-\nployees and the parties of customers, vendors, stakeholders, or communities.  The Standards are set based on Acer\xe2\x80\x99s Core Values\xe2\x80\x94\nPassion, Customer-centric, Innovation, Teamwork, Balance of Interests, and Integrity\xe2\x80\x94to regulate the behaviors in fair competi-\ntion, work environment with care and respect, intellectual properties, interest conflicts, legal payments, acceptance of customary \nbusiness amenities, or political contributions.  \n\nFor any questions regarding SBC raised by the employees, Acer management, global HR headquarters, and global legal headquar-\nters are available for both staff and external inquiries.  For any matters related to the likelihood of violating SBC, the employees or \nany external parties may also resort to the units mentioned above directly for clarification. In the event that the SBC is violated, \nthe situation will be handled according to the severity of the violation, with serious cases subject to disciplinary action and even \ndismissal.\n\nSBC regulates the proper behavior clearly when encountering with interest conflicts, or accepting proper offers etc., and provides \na mechanism for controlling the potential risks resulted from bribery or corruption. Acer makes internal audits periodically on the \nprocess flow of daily operation, reducing the possibilities of bribery or corruptions cases effectively.\n\nAll  staff  are  required  to  undergo  training  regarding  anti-corruption  measures.  During  annual  performance  reviews, we  require \nmanagement and colleagues to review their adherence to our standards of professional behavior. In the event of corruption being \nfound, the company must immediately report the incident and implement management measures, while also reminding staff that \nthey must adhere to the regulations of the Standards of Business Conduct.\n\nThe Company is dedicated to ensuring gender equality and human dignity in workplace, securing work environment free from \nsexual harassment and discrimination. With the promise, the Prevention Measures and Disciplinary Actions on Sexual Harassment \nis enacted, which specifies the reporting channels, dealing procedures, and disciplines.\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2  Declaration of Secrecy and Intellectual Property Rights\n\nThe Company places extreme importance on the protection of intellectual properties rights. All staff are required to have the Dec-\nlaration on Non-Disclosure Agreement signed when onboard, which declares the obligations to protect confidential information \nand the restrictions on use of the confidential information during the employment period and employment termination.\n\n5.4 Important Contracts\n\nNature of  \nContracts\n\nContracting Parties\n\nBeginning and Ending \n\nDates of \n\nResponsibility 6\n\nCorporate Social Responsibility\n\nAcer\'s corporate social responsibility mission aligns the Company\'s CSR strategy with the Company\'s new development direction \nand the core spirit of the brand:\n\nWhile pursuing profitability, leading transformation, and providing innovative services, we will continue to create tangible and \nintangible value while focusing on our three core beliefs of creating value, balancing interests, and developing sustainably in order \nto promote sustainability model transfer and leverage our social influence as we become a future-oriented business.\n\nAcer\'s CSR policy covers three axes: integrated sustainable governance, pioneering green innovation, and comprehensive sustain-\nable impact.\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2 \n\n\xe2\x80\xa2 \n\n\xe2\x80\xa2 \n\nIntegrated Sustainable Governance: Deepening CSR governance and stakeholder engagement, as well as strengthening the \noverall management and transparent disclosure of both financial and non-financial performance.\n\nPioneering  Green  Innovation:  Incorporating  low-carbon,  sustainable,  and  cyclically  innovative  technologies  and  concepts \ninto products and services, taking the lead in smart cities and the development of a new green economy.\n\nComprehensive Sustainable Impact: Creating real corporate value and leveraging our influence on vendors and partners to \nhelp the overall industry move toward a sustainable future.\n\nAcer\'s efforts in CSR continue to be recognized by top-notch sustainability indices. In 2018, the Company was selected for the \nfifth consecutive year as a component stock of MSCI\'s Global Sustainability ESG Indexes and Dow Jones Sustainability Index (DJSI) \nEmerging Markets Index. Acer was included in the FTSE4Good Emerging Index for the third straight year, and listed in the new sub-\ncategory FTSE4Good TIP Taiwan ESG Index.\n\nIn 2008, Acer stablished the Corporate Sustainability Office (CSO) as an establishment directly in charge of Acer Group\'s CSR af-\nfairs. In line with the Company\'s new group-based strategy, a number of subsidiaries have become listed companies. As a result, \nour CSR governance structure faces changes, and thus we continue to review our CSR framework. In 2017, in response to the trans-\nformation of the company and changes in the global environment, we further adjusted our sustainability mission and CSR policy, \nensuring we are fully equipped to make good on our commitments to development that is sustainable on both the corporate and \nsocial  levels.  In  2018,  the  Company  undertook  a  comprehensive  review  of  CSR  framework,  reorganizing  the  2012-established \nGlobal Corporate Social Responsibility Committee (GCSRC) into the Corporate Sustainability Committee (CSC) to integrate corpo-\nrate social responsibility strategies and enhance Acer\'s ESG performance.\n\nIn the environment, safety and health management aspects, we implement office carbon reduction programs, enhance suppliers\' \ncapacity of greenhouse gases management, launch several projects to improve the health and safety of our employees and have \nthird party verification for the GHGs emissions data of Acer Group global operation sites every year. For supply chain management, \nwe conduct suppliers\' Social and Environmental Responsibility (SER) on-site audits, investigate smelters in our supply chain for \nconflict minerals issue to enhance the SER performance of acer suppliers. Regarding communication, we build a good communi-\ncation channel with stakeholders to ensure mutual understandings and respect, and we continuously improve the quality of our \ncustomer service and the protection of customer privacy. About community involvement, Acer is committed to give back to the \nsociety by creating digital opportunities for the disadvantages through Acer Volunteer Team and Acer Foundation.\n\n.\n\nAcer Incorporated 2018 Annual ReportCorporate Social ResponsibilityAcer Incorporated 2018 Annual ReportCorporate Social Responsibility\x0c90\n\n91\n\n6.1 Environment, Safety and Health Management\n\nsafety in the recycling process, we work with plastics manufacturers and upstream recyclers to conform to international standards \nof quality, environmental safety, occupational health and safety, and responsible recycling (R2), earning international export li-\ncenses and recycling service provision qualifications from local governments.\n\n6.1.1 The Environmental Protection\n\n1. Energy and Climate Change\n\nWe continue to implement the Acer Integrated Energy and Climate Change Policy. We have also formulated long-term carbon \nreduction targets in line with the methodology proposed by the Science Based Targeting initiative, and we expect to accomplish in \n2050 an 80% reduction in Scope 1 and Scope 2 carbon emissions from the baseline year of 2009. In 2018, in line with GHG Protocol \nprinciples, we recalculated our benchmark for annual emissions based on structural changes.\n\nRegarding to the suppliers GHG management, we continually participate in the Carbon Disclosure Project Supply Chain Program, \nproviding the suppliers related training courses and consulting. We enforce suppliers\' capability on reacting to the climate change \nand saving energy and reduce emissions. Besides, we also encourage our suppliers to set reduction target to reduce the emission \nthrough the whole value chain. According to the report, our suppliers\' overall disclosure and performance on carbon reduction are \nover the average of the global suppliers\' performance.  \n\nOn the green electricity front, in 2017 Acer continued to expand our use of renewable energy in more operating locations, gradu-\nally expanding the use of renewable energy to achieve our medium-term goal of reducing carbon emissions by 60% by 2020.\n\n2. Green Product Management\n\nAcer\'s green product policy is:\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2  Based on the \xe2\x80\x9cproduct life cycle\xe2\x80\x9d concept, we offer high-quality products that are energy and resource efficient, low in pollut-\n\nants and hazardous substances, and easy to recycle.\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2  By employing green purchasing and through communications with our suppliers we have been able to establish a green supply \n\nchain that is fully compliant with international environmental practice.\n\nAll of Acer\'s products are in compliance with regulatory and customer requirements in all respective territories, protecting the \nhealth and safety of users and reducing potential risk to the environment. In addition to legal compliance, we also proactively \ncomply with our various markets\' voluntary environmental demands including product life cycle considerations such as energy ef-\nficiency, reduced use of toxic and/or hazardous substances, and end-of-life product processing. Since 2009, Acer has kept launch-\ning PVC-free and BFR (Bromine Flame Retardants)-free products, and is steadily accomplishing the target of non-halogenated \nproducts. We also continually evaluate the related regulations and the concerns of external stakeholders, gradually extending the \ncontrol scope of the chemicals.\n\nAcer supports the concept of resource recycling. In 2018, we continued to use recycled plastics in display units and all-in-one com-\nputers, including the B6, V6, B7, & V7 lines of displays and our all-in-one desktop models.\n\nThrough the Acer Packaging Design Principles, we are able to examine the life cycle of our packaging material and make informed \ndecisions about the environmental impact of our packaging at every stage, from initial R&D into and selection of materials through \nproduction methods, transportation and fuel consumption, durability in use, and waste handling. The Acer Packaging Design Prin-\nciples also address ongoing reduction in design, the use of environmentally friendly materials, and improved recyclability. \n\nAcer is committed to improving energy efficiency in our products to help consumers reduce the amount of energy they consume \nwhile using our products. During product design, we comply with energy consumption guidelines in each of our markets, including \nthe European ErP eco-design directive. To ensure our products comply with the requirements of particular customers and markets \naround the world, we have acquired US Energy Star\xc2\xae and China Energy Conservation labels for selected products.\n\nAcer not only supports the concept of resource recycling, but also actively strives to use post-consumer recycled plastics (PCR) in \nour products. At the same time, with regard to the materials that are most likely to create problems of pollution or occupational \n\n3.Office Carbon Reduction\n\nAcer\'s energy consumption primarily comes from office electricity usage. Each year we collect data on electricity usage from our \noffices around the world to facilitate prompt adaptations. We also aim to reduce electricity usage through the use of green elec-\ntricity, improved office equipment, and stronger power management, coupled with ongoing assessment and planning of energy \nconservation measures. Acer Taiwan\'s total solar power generation reached 3.258 million kWh in 2018, enough to supply about \n930 households for one year. The Acer eDC Longtan office, meanwhile, deactivated the power transformers for some floors after \nan electricity demand assessment, resulting in an annual saving of approximately 348,000 kWh.\n\nThe main source of electricity consumption in our offices is air conditioning and lighting. Given this, in 2018 we changed out air \nconditioning equipment in two office areas, including the Zhizun Building at Acer Taiwan Aspire Park, and high-consumption light-\ning in six office areas including our Xizhi headquarters, in addition to undertaking renovations at four office areas, including Xizhi, \nto make use of energy-saving lighting. In addition, our office areas continue to pursue stronger power management, including \nthe use of monitoring systems to adjust the hours air conditioners are active, adjusting the temperature of water emitted by air \nconditioner chiller on a seasonal basis, and using lighting systems that automatically shut off during lunch breaks and after hours \nto control energy consumption.\n\n6.1.2 Safety and Health\n\n1.  Environmental Safety and Health Management\n\nAs a global IT company focused on marketing and service, Acer endeavors to achieve balanced development in economy, envi-\nronment and society. We are devoted to environmental protection. We understand that all our products, services and activities \nhave potential impact to the environment and community where we conduct business. We are also dedicated to providing a safe \nand healthy workplace for employees believing that occupational health and safety is the foundation of sound and responsible \nbusiness operations. We ensure all employees understand their roles and responsibilities and are working with our partners and \nsuppliers to meet or exceed the environmental, health and safety commitments. Our policies on environmental safety and health \nmanagement are as below:\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2  Meet or exceed all applicable legal requirements, industry standards and voluntary agreements to which Acer subscribes.\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2 \n\nImprove resource productivity by promoting pollution prevention, energy efficiency and waste reduction.\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2  Carefully select raw materials and suppliers to provide safe and low environmental impact products.\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2  Strive to create a safe and healthful workplace and to prevent occupational injury and illnesses.\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2  Continuously improve EHS performance based on audit and communications.\n\nWe implement the Acer EHS management system to fulfill our pledges and reaching our corporate targets, including management \nof potential hazards to people and the environment, reducing the environmental impact of our company operations and products, \nregular monitoring to ensure we are compliant with relevant laws and Acer standards, and ensuring Acer staff enjoy a comfortable \nenvironment and attach importance to health and safety precautions\n\nIn 2018, most of Acer\'s Taiwan business units passed new ISO 14001:2015 environmental management system review and have \ncontinued to receive third-party certification. Some of our subsidiaries also passed ISO 14001:2015 review.\n\nAcer Incorporated 2018 Annual ReportCorporate Social ResponsibilityAcer Incorporated 2018 Annual ReportCorporate Social Responsibility\x0c92\n\n93\n\n2.  Working Environment and Employee Safety\n\nAcer cares about the working environment where employee\'s safety and health would largely depend on. We conducted a series \nof improvements, including water filtration system, drinking water quality, indoor air quality; strengthen the computer room and \nwarehouse safety. Acer also implemented environment, health and safety management system and conducted office sites hazards \nidentification. We then improved items with significant risks to lower the hazards.\n\n3.  Emergency Accident Operation\n\nAcer has established its own emergency operation procedures in the events of fire, earthquake, typhoon, power failure, water sup-\nply failure, contagious disease and other major accidents. In the fire safety aspect, we have organized a self-protection firefighting \nteam by the employees and their main duties are to extinguish the fire at the initial stage, evacuate the rest of the employees when \nnecessary and reduce possible damage from the accidents.\n\n4.  Employee Health \n\nAcer always cares about the health of colleagues. We keep promoting health management and promotion. In 2017, Acer applied for \nextended Healthy Workplace Certification. In 2018, Acer received the "sports enterprise certification from the minister of Educa-\ntion\'s Sports Administration" for the second consecutive year, further demonstrating our commitment to providing healthy work-\nplaces.\n\nMoreover, in order to strengthen workplace health promotion, we also hold afternoon lunch talks on health; offer weight loss class-\nes, smoking cessation classes, and physical fitness tests; hold sports competitions; set up health stations; and promote articles on \nhealth and wellbeing.\n\n6.2 Supply Chain Management\n\nWe treat our suppliers from all parts of the globe with consistent fairness in order to achieve efficient global operations and part-\nnerships and to provide clients with high quality products. We also strive to ensure that a safe working environment is provided \nthroughout the supply chain, that employees are treated with dignity and respect, and that suppliers observe ethical codes and \nshoulder their environmental responsibilities throughout their business operations. We will continuously investigate the necessary \nresponses to sustainability issues with a positive attitude and from a broad perspective so as to increase the positive effect of the \nsupply chain on society and the environment.\n\nAcer has been a member of the Responsible Business Alliance (RBA) (formerly the Electronic Industry Citizenship Coalition (EICC)) \nsince 2008, and actively participates in actions and discussions around supply chain social and environmental responsibility to \nbetter understand international trends in CSR and share in the practical experience of its members. All Acer manufacturers and \nservice providers are required to comply with both the RBA Code of Conduct and local regulations.\n\nIn addition, we carry out annual on-site RBA Code of Conduct vendor audits, gaining a deeper understanding of each location\'s \nworking environment and the human rights conditions of the staff. We also encourage and require vendors to uphold their cor-\nporate responsibility by ensuring their own vendors implement socially and environmentally responsible management and to ad-\nvocate for RBA Code of Conduct adherence, thus improving the working environment in the electronics supply chain worldwide.\n\nWe continue to communicate with vendors and enhance their ability to respond to sustainability issues, as well as encouraging \n\nvendors to incorporate sustainable development matters into their management agendas. In line with Acer\'s sustainable devel-\nopment strategy, we hold a variety of vendor sustainability conferences, and in our annual vendor CSR communication meetings, \nprovide information on the latest in CSR developments and trends, as well as analyzing important supply chain matters and po-\ntential actions that we can take together. These meetings also provide an opportunity for two-way communication between Acer \nand vendors, strengthening the supply chain\'s environmental and social responsibility and deepening our CSR-related cooperative \nrelationships.\n\nWe require new vendors pass the social and environmental responsibility assessment and sign an RBA Code of Conduct compliance \nstatement before they become official vendors. In order to put into practice environmental and social responsibility in Acerlnce \nstatement before they become official vendors. pliers to implement risk assessment and management based on the RBA Code of \nConduct. For higher risk suppliers, we also carry out on-site audits and management of follow-up improvement efforts. Addition-\nally, we incorporate performance in this regard into our vendor CSR scorecard assessments.\n\nAcer has taken multiple actions to verify the absence of forced labor, slavery and human trafficking in supply chain, including sup-\nplier risk assessment, declaration, on-site audit and training etc.\n\nRegarding to the topic on conflict minerals: Over the years, growing evidence has shown that mining is an intensive process in-\nvolving social and environmental risks. In 2017, Acer began the transformation of its conflict minerals program into a responsible \nminerals sourcing program with a broader focus that seeks to strategically identify priority minerals and regions that are a high \nrisk for negative social and environmental impacts. The mechanisms that drove the conflict minerals program are being adapted \nto address this broader focus, especially the supply chain tracing and due diligence processes that remain in alignment with the \nOECD Due Diligence Guidance for Responsible Supply Chains of Minerals from Conflict-Affected and High-Risk Areas. In addition, \nAcer realigned its policy and internal procedures to drive this renewed focus.\n\nIn 2017 and 2018, Acer\'s responsible minerals sourcing program completed the transformation to this renewed focus. Acer has \nidentified and prioritized minerals for inclusion in our responsible sourcing strategy and they currently include Conflict Minerals or \n3TG from the DRC and its adjoining countries, cobalt from the DRC and tin from Indonesia. Acer will continue to reassess its prior-\nity minerals as well as be involved in the refining of the procedures to identify Conflict-Affected and High-Risk Areas (CAHRAs). \nIn 2018, Acer issued its first consolidated responsible minerals report, outlining the steps taken to conduct due diligence on all \npriority minerals. \n\nIn order to review suppliers\' SER performance, we established the acer suppliers CSR scorecard. Through the mechanism, we could \nknow and track suppliers\' environmental, social and governmental risks in early time and assist the suppliers to conduct the neces-\nsary measures to reduce or mitigate the risks. To implement acer suppliers\' environmental and social responsibility, our suppliers \nhave to conduct the risk assessment and management to their next-tier suppliers according to the RBA code of conduct. Besides, \nthey have to conduct on-site audit to the suppliers with high risk. We called the mentioned management \xe2\x80\x9cAcer RBA 2.0.\xe2\x80\x9d We in-\nclude the performance by the suppliers in the evaluation of CSR scorecard. In 2018, we continued to carry out vendor CSR score-\ncard evaluations, including overall carbon management, carbon reduction results, and green energy adoption status, using this to \nfurther improve the ability of our overall supply chain to respond to climate change.\n\n6.3 Communication\n\n6.3.1 Communication with Stakeholders\n\nAcer is positioned to be a global citizenship among its stakeholders. With that in mind, we endeavor to understand stakeholder\'s \nopinions and recommendations, and build a good communication channel with them to ensure mutual understandings and re-\nspects. Stakeholders are defined as consumers, investors, suppliers, media, Non-governmental Organizations (NGOs), govern-\nment, community, academia, trade organizations and others. In addition to CSR performance disclosure for stakeholders on all \nfronts via Acer\'s designated Acer Sustainability webpage.\n\nAcer Incorporated 2018 Annual ReportCorporate Social ResponsibilityAcer Incorporated 2018 Annual ReportCorporate Social Responsibility\x0c94\n\n95\n\nof charity. In the past, such activities have included recruiting IT volunteers, working to protect mountains and the oceans, second-\nhand item donation drives, blood drives, electronics recycling, working with people with dementia, promoting carbon reduction \nand energy saving to address climate change, and helping both disadvantaged children and the elderly.\n\n6.4.2 Acer Foundation\n\nAcer Foundation is committed to promote digital opportunity since its establishment. \n\nIn the first semester of the 2017 academic year, we joined forces with the Global Views Educational Foundation on a full-scale \nupgrade of our bookmobiles and digital vans in the \xe2\x80\x9cReading for Hope x Cloud Professor Bookmobiles\xe2\x80\x9d project. In this, we took not \nonly traditional books, but also five to eight Acer Cloud Professor IoT smart \xe2\x80\x9cCloud Professor + GigoToys\xe2\x80\x9d sets into campuses to \nfoster a combination of reading habits and programming language knowledge for the new era. In the 2017 academic year, we vi-\nsited 112 rural elementary and junior high schools, helping some 6,000 students. In addition, we held four Cloud Professor teacher \ntraining sessions were held, focused on education in programming and IoT, with approximately 210 teachers participating. Over \nthe course of that same academic year, our four vehicles covered 175,199 km and helped foster over 1,000 \xe2\x80\x9creading kings.\xe2\x80\x9d We \nalso invited volunteers from universities and other walks of life to form reading volunteer teams to head into rural communities as \nstorytellers for the local children.\n\nIn addition to this, for several years Acer has organized the Longterm Smile Competition. In 2018, this competition was restruc-\ntured to incorporate smart technologies and IoT, relaunching as the Longterm Smile Internet of Beings Competition. With its first \nholding in this incarnation in 2018, the competition has continued to promote Taiwanese startup innovation. \n\nTo encourage today\'s youth to unleash their creative potential in the modern digital era, the Acer Foundation has for the second \ntime worked with the National Taiwan Science Education Center to hold the BeingLife Creativity Competition. This time, the com-\npetition attracted outstanding works from over 600 teams, from which a shortlist was compiled through judging interviews which \nlooked at the students\' insight into contemporary social issues. Each competing piece was the result of students\' observations of \nmodern life and attempts to incorporate technology in innovative ways, using cloud computing to solve everyday problems and \nshowcasing the value of the Internet of Things in creating an \xe2\x80\x9cInternet of Beings. \n\n6.3.2 Supplier CSR Communication Meeting\n\nEvery year, Acer invites representatives of our major vendors to participate in annual CSR Communication Meetings, sharing the \nlatest global trends in corporate sustainability and emphasizing Acer\'s requirements of and goals for supply chain CSR manage-\nment performance. At the 2017 Supplier CSR Communication Meeting, we announced a list of banned and restricted chemical \nsubstances, including substances that may impact the external environment or the health of operators. In 2018, with a focus on \ncircular economy, we invited the plastics recycler in our supply chain to share their practical operations and experiences to enhance \nthe overall supply chain\'s awareness of the topic and its gradual implementation in Acer\'s circular economy goal.\n\n6.3.3 Customer Relations\n\nAcer has always followed a quality policy of "Delivering zero-defect, competitive products and services on time" and adheres to \nthe concept of "Serve with honor and work with pride" in providing professional products and services. Acer designs and conducts \nregular customer satisfaction surveys tailored to each region to get customer feedback and work on the area that need improve-\nment to enhance the quality of customer service.\n\nIn addition, we also establish a complete globalized service structure in all major localized service sites and design different service \nprograms for variety of customers and retailers. Consumers and corporate customers can communicate with us through multiple \nchannels including:\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2 \n\n\xe2\x80\xa2 \n\n\xe2\x80\xa2 \n\n\xe2\x80\xa2 \n\n\xe2\x80\xa2 \n\n\xe2\x80\xa2 \n\nGlobal web site download and actively update service\n\nCall center support center / technical support\n\nDirect service center\n\nAuthorized service center and professional system repair company\n\nInternational Traveler Warranty service center\n\nAcer Web Master\n\nWe are committed to the protection of customers confidential information and strictly follow Acer\'s privacy policies to request \nall Acer employee must protect customers\' confidential information and private data with cautiousness; we also implement data \nprotection and security related tool to protect customers personal data in the products. In the same time, a dedicate mail account \nis set up to handle all escalation of privacy protection related case. All of our service engineers have signed a non-disclosure agree-\nment and prior to any actual repair, our service staff will provide the customer with a maintenance service list to the customer to \ndecide if any private information need to be deleted or removed and store in another hard drive or memory drive to prevent confi-\ndential information from being compromised.\n\n6.4 Community Involvement\n\n6.4.1. Acer Volunteer Team\n\nThe Acer Volunteer Team was established in 2004 for the purpose of giving employees a channel to contribute their spare time and \nenergy to public welfare service. Apart from providing opportunities for interaction and friendship between employees from dif-\nferent departments and backgrounds, the volunteer service also bring Acer employees new life experiences and personal growth \nthrough the activities. The focused areas of the Volunteer Team include digital inclusion, charity and philanthropy, international \nvolunteer work, and environmental conservation. Our volunteer teams have also created many opportunities to give back to the \ncommunity through volunteer experiences, organizing a number of activities for both staff and their families to promote concepts \n\nAcer Incorporated 2018 Annual ReportCorporate Social ResponsibilityAcer Incorporated 2018 Annual ReportCorporate Social Responsibility\x0c96\n\n6.5 Enforcement of Corporate Social Responsibility \n\nby the Company\n\nImplementation Status\n\nAssessment Items\n\nYes\n\nNo\n\nSummary Description\n\nImplementation Status\n\nAssessment Items\n\nYes\n\nNo\n\nSummary Description\n\n1.Exercising Corporate Governance\n\n(1)  Does the com-\n\npany declare its \ncorporate social \nresponsibility \npolicy and exam-\nine the results of \nthe implementa-\ntion?\n\n(2)  Is there any \n\ntraining about \nCorporate Social \nResponsibility \n(CSR) conducted \nregularly?\n\n(3)  Does the com-\npany establish \nexclusively (or \nconcurrently) \ndedicated units to \nbe in charge the \ncorporate social \nresponsibility \npolicies and re-\nport to the Board \nof Directors?\n\n4\n\n4\n\n4\n\nAcer Corporate Social Responsibility Policy:\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2 \n\nIntegrated Sustainable Governance: Deepening CSR governance \nand stakeholder engagement, as well as strengthening the overall \nmanagement and transparent disclosure of both financial and \nnon-financial performance\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2  Pioneering Green Innovation: Incorporating low-carbon, sustain-\n\nable, and cyclically innovative technologies and concepts into \nproducts and services, taking the lead in smart cities and the \ndevelopment of a new green economy\n\n\xe2\x80\xa2  Comprehensive Sustainable Impact: Creating real corporate value \nand leveraging our influence on vendors and partners to help the \noverall industry move toward a sustainable future\n\nWe formulate the action plans based on the corporate social respon-\nsibility policy and regularly review the performance. President \n& CEO. We require a new \nemployee attend the training, emphasizing the importance of abid-\ning by the regulations. The standards of SBC, the core essence of CSR \nin doing business, are built-in Acer\'s performance appraisal system, \nwhich helps managerial staff to monitor the status of exercising the \nregulations. Fostering a Sustainable Environment\n\nAcer strives to lower the environmental impacts of our operation and \nproducts, and keeps improving the efficiency of resource usage. The \nmajor achievements of 2018 include:\n\na. Use of Post-Consumer Recycled Plastics\n\nAcer supports the concept of resource recycling, and as such we \nactively strive to use post-consumer recycled plastics (PCR) in our \nproducts. At the same time, with regard to the materials that are \nmost likely to create problems of pollution or occupational safety \nin the recycling process, we work with plastics manufacturers and \nupstream recyclers to conform to international standards of quality, \nenvironmental safety, occupational health and safety, and respon-\nsible recycling (R2), earning international export licenses and recy-\ncling service provision qualifications from local governments.\n\nb. Use of recycled paper in packaging\n\nAcer carefully considers the materials we use in our packaging, with \npackaging design emphasizing recyclability and making use of easily \nrecyclable materials a priority. In 2018, some 8% of all desktop com-\nputers shipped used molded pulp or folded paper packaging. Acer\'s \ndesktop computer models use brown carton inserts and boxes of \n100% recycled paper pulp. The notebook computers also use 100% \nrecycled EPE foam and 100% recycled paper for their packaging, \nminimizing its negative impact on the environment. On top of this, \nall of the posters included with products are produced with Forest \nStewardship Council certified paper, while all printing uses environ-\nmentally friendly water-based and soy inks.\n\nAcer adopted international standards ISO 14001 to establish the en-\nvironmental management system and keep maintaining the validity \nof the Certificate. In 2018, all of Acer\'s Taiwan business units passed \nnew ISO 14001:2015 environmental management system review \nand have continued to receive third-party certification. Some of our \nsubsidiaries have also passed ISO 14001:2015 review.\n\nNo discrepancy\n\nNo discrepancy\n\n(1)  Does the company \n\nendeavors to uti-\nlize all resources \nmore efficiently \nand uses renew-\nable materials \nwhich have a low \nimpact on the \nenvironment?\n\n(2)  Does the company \n\nestablish proper \nenvironmental-\nmanagement sys-\ntems based on the \ncharacteristics of \ntheir industries?\n\n4\n\n4\n\nAcer Incorporated 2018 Annual ReportCorporate Social ResponsibilityAcer Incorporated 2018 Annual ReportCorporate Social Responsibility\x0c98\n\n99\n\nImplementation Status\n\nAssessment Items\n\nYes\n\nNo\n\nSummary Description\n\n(3)  Does the com-\n\npany monitor the \nimpact of climate \nchange on its \noperations and \nestablish com-\npany strategies \nfor energy conser-\nvation and carbon \nand greenhouse \ngas reduction?\n\n4\n\n3. Preserving Public Welfare\n\n(1)  Are there any \n\nhuman right poli-\ncies or processes \nformulated in \nthe company in \nresponse to the \nrequest of Inter-\nnational Bill of \nHuman Rights?\n\n(2)  Are there any \n\ncomplaint chan-\nnels created for \nemployees, and \nare the com-\nplaints properly \nhandled?\n\n(3)  Does the com-\n\npany provide safe \nand healthy work \nenvironments for \nits employees, \nand organizes \ntraining on safety \nand health for its \nemployees on a \nregular basis?\n\n4\n\n4\n\n4\n\nWe have also formulated long-term carbon reduction targets in line \nwith the methodology proposed by the Science Based Targeting \ninitiative, and we expect to accomplish in 2050 an 80% reduction \nin Scope 1 and Scope 2 carbon emissions from the baseline year of \n2009. In 2018, in line with GHG Protocol principles, we recalculated \nour benchmark for annual emissions based on structural changes. \nPlease view Acer Corporate Responsibility Report for details.\n\nThe Standards of Business Conduct requires each site of Acer \nworldwide follow the principles of labor rights, which are both inter-\nnationally or locally-regulated, including general labor laws, equal \nopportunity and transparency in recruitment process, with no dis-\ncrimination of race, gender, age, religion, or nationality, in pursuit of \nour value emphasizing that right man should be in the right position. \nBesides, employing a child labor is forbidden.  We have sound human \nresources management systems, for example, clear employment \ncontracts, work rules, or human resources regulations, to ensure the \nlegitimate rights and benefits of an employee being well-protected.\n\nAcer sets up whistleblower.acer@acer.com, encouraging people \ninside and outside the company to directly report any incidences of \nfraud, corruption, breaches of the Standards of Business Conduct, or \nany other activity that is illegal or a counter to good corporate gov-\nernance. Through this, personnel, legal, or auditing departments can \nbe notified, with each report passed on to the appropriate authori-\nties for confidential investigation. \n\nIn order to build a good working environment and ensure colleague \nhealth and safety, the Acer Taiwan headquarters has launched an \nESH (Environment, Safety, and Health) management system. This \nteam has a total of 44 members, 43 of whom are elected representa-\ntives, thus accomplishing 97.7% labor representation. At the same \ntime, in order to make sure internal communications are smooth, the \nCompany has set up Employee Representative Meetings, made up of \nregional representatives elected by employees. Meetings are elected \nheld quarterly to discuss topics including health and safety issues \nand improvement follow-up.\n\nIn order to strengthen staff understanding of health and safety, we \ntake advantage of all available channels for communications, as well \nas holding annual training and education programs tailored to dif-\nferent groups, passing on knowledge, improving focus on health and \nsafety, and further advancing the creation of a culture of health and \nsafety that can adapt to emergency situations.\n\nDeviations from \n\n\xe2\x80\x9cCorporate \n\nSocial Responsi-\n\nbility \n\n Best Practice \nPrinciples for \nTWSE/GTSM \nListed Com-\npanies\xe2\x80\x9d and \n\nreasons\n\nNo discrepancy\n\nNo discrepancy\n\nNo discrepancy\n\nNo discrepancy\n\nImplementation Status\n\nAssessment Items\n\nYes\n\nNo\n\nSummary Description\n\n(4)  Does the company \n\nbuild up sound \ncommunication \nchannels and em-\nploy the appro-\npriate methods \nto inform the \nemployees of the \npossible signifi-\ncant impacts?\n\n(5)  Does the compa-\nny have effective \ncareer develop-\nment plans for \nemployees?\n\n(6)  Does the com-\npany establish \npolicies on con-\nsumer rights and \nprovides griev-\nance mechanism \nregarding its \ndevelopment and \nresearch, procure-\nment, production \noperation and \nservices?\n\n(7)  Does the company \n\ncomply with the \nlaw and interna-\ntional regulations \non marketing \nand labeling of \nits product and \nservice?\n\n4\n\n4\n\n4\n\n4\n\nAcer attaches great importance to employees\' opinions, and there-\nfore strives to ensure communication channels open and candid, in-\ncluding the announcement of critical messages, dedicated hotlines \nof internal services, communication meetings across multiple-layers \nof managers, employee opinion survey, employees\' complaint chan-\nnels. Enhancing Information Disclosure\n\nDeviations from \n\n\xe2\x80\x9cCorporate \n\nSocial Responsi-\n\nbility \n\n Best Practice \nPrinciples for \nTWSE/GTSM \nListed Com-\npanies\xe2\x80\x9d and \n\nreasons\n\nNo discrepancy\n\n5.  If the Company has established corporate social responsibility principles based on \xe2\x80\x9cCorporate Social Responsi-\nbility Best Practice Principles for TWSE/GTSM Listed Companies\xe2\x80\x9d, please describe any discrepancy between the \nprinciples and their implementation:\n\n  To boost Acer\'s overall competitiveness, fulfill its corporate responsibility in the social, economic and environmental \n\naspects, and make Acer a leading brand-name in the history, the Standards of Business Conduct (SBC) were revised and \npromulgated in 2009 that serve as behavioral guidelines to Acer global employees providing them principles of conducting \nbusiness at worldwide. They serve as a guideline for decision-making and action with regard to fair competition, respect for \nthe environment; intellectual property rights; conflicts of interests; the banning of improper payments, gifts, or hospitali-\nties; political contributions and activities; and so forth.\n\n \n\nIn 2017, we revised and announced the part of the protection of human rights in the SBC.  The enactment of the SBC no \nonly protects Acer\'s global business interest in a legitimate manner but also helps to enhance its service quality for custom-\ners, partners, and the communities. We also establish Anti-Bribery and Anti-Corruption Policy, Antitrust and Fair Competi-\ntion Guidelines, Regulations on Insider Trading, Rules Governing Management of Personal Data, and Subject Regulations of \nPrevention, Complaint and Punishment of Sexual Harassment to bring the practice of corporate responsibility into our daily \noperation.\n\n6. Other important information to facilitate better understanding of the Company\'s corporate social responsibility \n\npractices:\n\n  More information can be found at: \n\n1. Acer Sustainability website: http://www.acer-group.com/public/Sustainability/index.htm \n2. Acer Foundation website: http://www.acerfoundation.org.tw/english/index.php\n\n7.   If the products or corporate social responsibility reports have received assurance from external institutions, they \n\nshould state so below:\n\n  Acer engaged KPMG to perform an independent limited
