Formerly,  Bluechip  was  an\nassociate  accounted  for  using  equity  method;  the  Group  acquired  additional  interest  in\nBluechip and obtained control over it in the first quarter of 2018; accordingly, Bluechip was\nincluded  in  the  accompanying  consolidated  financial  statements  from  the  date  the  control\ncommenced.\nAST, ITS, EDC, ABST, ABSG, AOI and its subsidiaries, ACVC, ACVP and SEB were newly\nestablished  subsidiaries  or  were  acquired  during  2017.  PKL  was  merged  into  ITS  in  2017.\nFormerly, ASBZ was a joint venture accounted for using equity method; the Group acquired\nadditional  interest  in  ASBZ  and  obtained  control  over  it  in  the  fourth  quarter  of  2017;\naccordingly, ASBZ was included in the accompanying consolidated financial statements from\nthe date the control commenced.\nIn  2018,  the  subsidiaries,  ACR,  ASK  and  WHI,  were  liquidated.  In  2017,  the  subsidiaries,\nBeijing Acer Information Co., Ltd. (BJAI), Acer BSEC Incorporated (AUA), and Acer Hellas\nLimited Liability Company of Marketing and Sale Services (AGR) were liquidated. Since the\ndates  the  control  ceased,  the  aforesaid  subsidiaries  were  excluded  from  the  accompanying\nconsolidated financial statements.\n\n(iii) List of subsidiaries which are not included in the consolidated financial statements: None.\n\n(d)\n\nForeign currency\n\n(i)\n\nForeign currency transactions\n\nForeign currency transactions are translated into the functional currency using the exchange\nrates prevailing at the dates of the transactions. Foreign exchange gains and losses resulting\nfrom the settlement of such transactions and from the translation at exchange rates at the end\nof the period (the \xe2\x80\x9creporting date\xe2\x80\x9d) of monetary assets and liabilities denominated in foreign\ncurrencies are recognized in profit or loss.\n\n(Continued)\n\n\x0cACER INCORPORATED AND SUBSIDIARIES\n\nNotes to Consolidated Financial Statements\n\n27\n\nNon-monetary assets and liabilities denominated in foreign currencies that are measured at fair\nvalue  are  retranslated  at  the  exchange  rate  prevailing  at  the  date  when  the  fair  value  is\ndetermined.  Exchange  differences  arising  on  the  translation  of  non-monetary  items  are\nrecognized in profit or loss, except for exchange differences arising on the retranslation of non-\nmonetary  items  in  respect  of  which  gains  and  losses  are  recognized  directly  in  other\ncomprehensive income, in which case, the exchange differences are also recognized directly in\nother comprehensive income. Non-monetary items denominated in foreign currencies that are\nmeasured at historical cost are not retranslated.\n\n(ii) Foreign operations\n\nThe assets and liabilities of foreign operations, including goodwill and fair value adjustments\narising  from  acquisition,  are  translated  into  the  presentation  currency  of  the  Group\xe2\x80\x99 s\nconsolidated financial statements at the exchange rates at the reporting date. The income and\nexpenses of foreign operations, excluding foreign operations in hyperinflationary economies,\nare translated into the presentation currency of the Group\xe2\x80\x99s consolidated financial statements at\nthe average exchange rates for the period. All resulting exchange differences are recognized in\nother comprehensive income.\n\nOn the disposal of a foreign operation which involves a loss of control over a subsidiary or loss\nof significant influence over an associate that includes a foreign operation, all of the exchange\ndifferences accumulated in equity in respect of that operation attributable to the shareholders\nof the Company are entirely reclassified to profit or loss.  In the case of a partial disposal that\ndoes  not  result  in  the  Group  losing  control  over  a  subsidiary,  the  proportionate  share  of\naccumulated  exchange  differences  is  reclassified  to  non-controlling  interests.  For  a  partial\ndisposal of the Group\xe2\x80\x99s ownership interest in an associate or joint venture, the proportionate\nshare of the accumulated exchange differences in equity is reclassified to profit or loss.\n\nWhen the settlement of a monetary receivable from or payable to a foreign operation is neither\nplanned nor likely to occur in the foreseeable future, the monetary item is, in substance, a part\nof net investment in that foreign operation, and the related foreign exchange gains and losses\nthereon are recognized as other comprehensive income.\n\n(e) Classification of current and non-current assets and liabilities\n\nAn  asset  is  classified  as  current  when  one  of  the  following  criteria  is  met;  all  other  assets  are\nclassified as non-current assets:\n\nIt is expected to be realized, or intended to be sold or consumed in the normal operating cycle;\nIt is held primarily for the purpose of trading;\nIt is expected to be realized within twelve months after the reporting period; or \n\n(i)\n(ii)\n(iii)\n(iv) The asset is cash or a cash equivalent unless the asset is restricted from being exchanged or\n\nused to settle a liability for at least twelve months after the reporting period.\n\nA liability is classified as current when one of the following criteria is met; all other liabilities are\nclassified as non-current liabilities:\n\n(i)\n(ii)\n(iii)\n\nIt is expected to be settled in the normal operating cycle;\nIt is held primarily for the purpose of trading;\nIt is due to be settled within twelve months after the reporting period; or \n\n(Continued)\n\n\x0cACER INCORPORATED AND SUBSIDIARIES\n\nNotes to Consolidated Financial Statements\n\n28\n\n(iv) The Group does not have an unconditional right to defer settlement of the liability for at least\ntwelve months after the reporting period. Terms of a liability that could, at the option of the\ncounterparty,  result  in  its  settlement  by  issuing  equity  instruments  do  not  affect  its\nclassification.\n\n(f) Cash and cash equivalents\n\nCash consists of cash on hand, checking deposits, and demand deposits.  Cash equivalents consist of\nshort-term and highly liquid investments that are readily convertible to known amounts of cash and\nare subject to an insignificant risk of changes in value.  Time deposits that meet the aforesaid criteria\nand are not held for investing purposes are also classified as cash equivalents.\n\nBank  overdrafts  that  are  repayable  on  demand  and  form  an  integral  part  of  the  Group\xe2\x80\x99 s  cash\nmanagement  are  included  as  a  component  of  cash  and  cash  equivalents  for  the  purpose  of  the\nconsolidated statement of cash flows.\n\n(g)\n\nFinancial instruments\n\n(i)\n\nFinancial assets (applicable commencing January 1, 2018)\n\nFinancial assets are classified into the following categories: measured at amortized cost, fair\nvalue through other comprehensive income (\xe2\x80\x9cFVOCI\xe2\x80\x9d), and fair value through profit or loss\n(\xe2\x80\x9cFVTPL\xe2\x80\x9d). A regular way purchase or sale of financial assets is recognized and derecognized\non a trade-date basis.\n\nThe Group shall reclassify all affected financial assets only when it changes its business model\nfor managing its financial assets.\n\n1)\n\nFinancial assets measured at amortized cost\n\nA  financial  asset  is  measured  at  amortized  cost  if  it  meets  both  of  the  following\nconditions and is not designated as at FVTPL:\n\xef\x82\xb7 it is held within a business model whose objective is to hold financial assets to collect\n\ncontractual cash flows; and\n\n\xef\x82\xb7 its contractual terms give rise on specified dates to cash flows that are solely payments\n\nof principal and interest on the principal amount outstanding.\n\nA financial asset measured at amortized cost is initially recognized at fair value, plus any\ndirectly  attributable  transaction  costs.  These  assets  are  subsequently  measured  at\namortized cost using the effective interest method, less any impairment losses. Interest\nincome, foreign exchange gains and losses, and recognition (reversal) of impairment loss\nare recognized in profit or loss. Any gain or loss on derecognition is recognized in profit\nor loss.\n\n(Continued)\n\n\x0cACER INCORPORATED AND SUBSIDIARIES\n\nNotes to Consolidated Financial Statements\n\n2)\n\nFinancial assets measured at fair value through other comprehensive income \n\n29\n\nA debt investment is measured at FVOCI if it meets both of the following conditions and\nis not designated as at FVTPL:\n\xef\x82\xb7 it  is  held  within  a  business  model  whose  objective  is  achieved  by  both  collecting\n\ncontractual cash flows and selling financial assets; and\n\n\xef\x82\xb7 its contractual terms give rise on specified dates to cash flows that are solely payments\n\nof principal and interest on the principal amount outstanding.\n\nOn initial recognition of an equity investment that is not held for trading, the Group may\nirrevocably elect to present subsequent changes in the investment\xe2\x80\x99s fair value in other\ncomprehensive income. This election is made on an instrument-by-instrument basis.\n\nA  financial  asset  measured  at  FVOCI  is  initially  recognized  at  fair  value,  plus  any\ndirectly  attributable  transaction  costs.  These  assets  are  subsequently  measured  at  fair\nvalue. Foreign exchange gains and losses, interest income calculated using the effective\ninterest method, and impairment losses deriving from debt investments, are recognized in\nprofit  or  loss;  whereas  dividends  deriving  from  equity  investments  are  recognized  in\nprofit or loss, unless the dividend clearly represents a recovery of part of the cost of an\ninvestment. Other changes in the carrying amount of financial assets measured at FVOCI\nare  recognized  in  other  comprehensive  income  and  accumulated  in  other  equity  as\nunrealized  gain  (loss)  from  financial  assets  measured  at  fair  value  through  other\ncomprehensive income. On derecognition, gains and losses accumulated in other equity\nof  debt  investments  are  reclassified  to  profit  or  loss.  However,  gains  and  losses\naccumulated  in  other equity of equity investments are reclassified to retained earnings\ninstead of profit or loss.\n\nDividend  income  derived  from  equity  investments  is  recognized  on  the  date  that  the\nGroup\xe2\x80\x99s right to receive the dividends is established (usually the ex-dividend date).\n\n3)\n\nFinancial assets measured at fair value through profit or loss \n\nAll financial assets not classified as measured at amortized cost or at FVOCI described\nas  above  are  measured  at  FVTPL,  including  derivative  financial  assets  and  non-\nderivative financial assets (e.g., convertible bond and right of profit-sharing). On initial\nrecognition,  the  Group  may  irrevocably  designate  a  financial  asset,  which  meets  the\nrequirements to be measured at amortized cost or at FVOCI, as at FVTPL if doing so\neliminates or significantly reduces an accounting mismatch that would otherwise arise.\n\nFinancial  assets  in  this  category  are  initially  recognized  at  fair  value.  Attributable\ntransaction  costs  are  recognized  in  profit  or  loss  as  incurred.  Subsequent  to  initial\nrecognition, they are measured at fair value, any changes therein, including any dividend\nand interest income, are recognized in profit or loss.\n\n(Continued)\n\n\x0cACER INCORPORATED AND SUBSIDIARIES\n\nNotes to Consolidated Financial Statements\n\n4)\n\nImpairment of financial assets\n\n30\n\nThe  Group  recognizes  loss  allowances  for  expected  credit  losses  on  financial  assets\nmeasured  at  amortized  cost  (including  cash  and  cash  equivalents,  notes  and  accounts\nreceivable, other receivables, and other financial assets) and contract assets.\n\nThe Group measures loss allowances for accounts receivable, contract assets and other\nfinancial assets at an amount equal to lifetime expected credit loss (\xe2\x80\x9cECL\xe2\x80\x9d), except for\nthe following financial assets which are measured using 12-month ECL:\n\n\xef\x82\xb7 debt securities that are determined to have low credit risk at the reporting date; and\n\xef\x82\xb7 other debt securities and bank balances for which credit risk (i.e., the risk of default\noccurring  over  the  expected  life  of  the  financial  instrument)  has  not  increased\nsignificantly since initial recognition.\n\nLifetime ECLs are the ECLs that result from all possible default events over the expected\nlife of a financial instrument. 12-month ECLs are the portion of ECLs that result from\ndefault events that are possible within the 12 months after the reporting date (or a shorter\nperiod if the expected life of the instrument is less than 12 months).\n\nThe  maximum  period  considered  when  estimating  ECLs  is  the  maximum  contractual\nperiod over which the Group is exposed to credit risk.\n\nWhen determining whether the credit risk of a financial asset has increased significantly\nsince  initial  recognition,  the  Group  considers  reasonable  and  supportable  information\nthat is relevant and available without undue cost or effort. The information includes both\nquantitative  and  qualitative  information  and  analysis  based  on  the  Group\xe2\x80\x99 s  historical\nexperience and credit assessment, as well as forward-looking information.\n\nECLs  are  probability-weighted  estimate  of  credit  losses  over  the  expected  life  of\nfinancial assets. Credit losses are measured as the present value of all cash shortfalls (i.e.,\nthe difference between the cash flows due to the Group in accordance with the contract\nand  the  cash  flows  that  the  Group  expects  to  receive).  ECLs  are  discounted  at  the\neffective interest rate of the financial asset.\n\nLoss allowances for financial assets measured at amortized cost are deducted from the\ngross carrying amount of the assets. The recognition or reversal  of the loss allowance is\nrecognized in profit or loss.\n\nThe gross carrying amount of a financial asset is written off, either partially or in full, to\nthe extent that there is no realistic prospect of recovery. This is generally the case when\nthe Group determines that the debtor does not have assets or sources of income that could\ngenerate sufficient cash flows to repay the amounts subject to the write-off. However,\nfinancial  assets  that  are  written  off  could  still  be  subject  to  enforcement  activities  in\norder to comply with the Group\xe2\x80\x99s procedures for recovery of amounts due.\n\n(Continued)\n\n\x0c31\n\nACER INCORPORATED AND SUBSIDIARIES\n\nNotes to Consolidated Financial Statements\n\n5)\n\nDerecognition of financial assets\n\nFinancial assets are derecognized when the contractual rights of the cash inflow from the\nassets are terminated, or when the Group transfers substantially all the risks and rewards\nof ownership of the financial assets to other enterprises.\n\nOn derecognition of a debt instrument in its entirety, the difference between the carrying\namount and the sum of the consideration received or receivable and any cumulative gain\nor  loss  that  had  been  recognized  in  other  comprehensive  income  and  accumulated  in\n\xe2\x80\x9cother equity\xe2\x80\x93unrealized gain (loss) from financial assets measured at fair value through\nother  comprehensive  income\xe2\x80\x9d   is  recognized  in  profit  or  loss,  and  included  in  non-\noperating income and loss.\n\nOn derecognition of a debt instrument other than in its entirety, the Group allocates the\nprevious  carrying  amount  of  the  debt  instrument  between  the  part  it  continues  to\nrecognize under continuing involvement, and the part it no longer recognizes on the basis\nof  the  relative  fair  values  of  those  parts  on  the  date  of  the  transfer.  The  difference\nbetween the carrying amount allocated to the part that is no longer recognized and the\nsum of the consideration received or receivable for the part no longer recognized and any\ncumulative gain or loss allocated to it that had been recognized in other comprehensive\nincome is recognized in profit or loss, and included in non-operating income and loss. A\ncumulative  gain  or  loss  that  had  been  recognized  in  other  comprehensive  income  is\nallocated between the part that continues to be recognized and the part that is no longer\nrecognized on the basis of the relative fair values of those parts.\n\n(ii) Financial assets (applicable before January 1, 2018)\n\nFinancial  assets  are  classified  into  the  following  categories:  financial  assets  at  fair  value\nthrough profit or loss, loans and receivables, and available-for-sale financial assets. A regular\nway purchase or sale of financial assets is recognized or derecognized on a trade-date basis. \n\n1)\n\nFinancial assets at fair value through profit or loss \n\nFinancial  assets  at  fair  value  through  profit  or  loss consist of financial assets held for\ntrading  and  those  designated  as  at  fair  value  through  profit  or  loss  at  inception.  A\nfinancial  asset  is  classified  in  this  category  if  acquired  principally  for  the  purpose  of\nselling in the short term. Derivatives are also categorized as financial assets at fair value\nthrough  profit  or  loss  unless  they  are  designated  as  hedges.  The  Group  designates\nfinancial assets, other than ones classified as held for trading, as at fair value through\nprofit or loss at initial recognition under one of the following situations:\n\n\xef\x82\xb7 Such  designation  eliminates  or  significantly  reduces  a  measurement  or  recognition\ninconsistency  that  would  otherwise  arise  from  measuring  assets  or  liabilities  or\nrecognizing the gains and losses on them on a different basis;\n\n\xef\x82\xb7 Performance of the financial asset is evaluated on a fair value basis; \n\xef\x82\xb7 A hybrid instrument contains one or more embedded derivatives.\n\n(Continued)\n\n\x0cACER INCORPORATED AND SUBSIDIARIES\n\nNotes to Consolidated Financial Statements\n\n32\n\nAt  initial  recognition,  financial  assets  carried  at  fair  value  through  profit  or  loss  are\nrecognized at fair value. Any attributable transaction costs are recognized in profit or loss\nas  incurred.  Subsequent  to  the  initial  recognition,  changes  in  fair  value  (including\ndividend  income  and  interest  income)  are  recognized  in  profit  or  loss  and  included  in\nnon-operating income and loss. \n\n2)\n\nLoans and receivables\n\nLoans  and  receivables  are  non-derivative  financial  assets  with  fixed  or  determinable\npayments  that  are  not  quoted  in  an  active  market.  Loans  and  receivables  comprise\naccounts  receivable,  other  receivables  and  investments  in  debt  instrument  without  an\nactive  market.  At  initial  recognition,  such  assets  are  recognized  at  fair  value  plus  any\ndirectly  attributable  transaction  costs.  Subsequent  to  initial  recognition,  loans  and\nreceivables  other  than  insignificant  interest  on  short-term  receivables  are  measured  at\namortized  cost  using  the  effective  interest  method  less  any  impairment losses. Interest\nincome is recognized as non-operating income in profit or loss.\n\n3)\n\nAvailable-for-sale financial assets\n\nAvailable-for-sale financial assets are non-derivative financial assets that are designated\nas available for sale or are not classified in any of the other categories of financial assets.\nAt initial recognition, available-for-sale financial assets are recognized at fair value plus\nany directly attributable transaction costs. Subsequent to initial recognition, these assets\nare  measured  at  fair  value,  and  changes therein, other than impairment losses, interest\nincome  calculated  using  the  effective  interest  method,  dividend  income,  and  foreign\ncurrency differences on monetary financial assets, are recognized in other comprehensive\nincome and accumulated in other equity as unrealized gain (loss) from available-for-sale\nfinancial  assets.  When  the  financial  asset  is  derecognized,  the  gain  or  loss  previously\naccumulated in equity is reclassified to profit or loss. \n\nDividends received from equity investments are recognized as non-operating income on\nthe date of entitlement to receive the dividends (usually the ex-dividend date). \n\n4)\n\nImpairment of financial assets\n\nFinancial assets, other than those carried at fair value through profit or loss, are assessed\nfor indicators of impairment at the end of each reporting date. Those financial assets are\nconsidered  to  be  impaired  when  there  is  objective  evidence  that,  as  a result of one or\nmore  events  that  occurred  after  the  initial  recognition  of  the  financial  assets,  their\nestimated future cash flows have been affected. \n\nEvidence  of  impairment  may  include  indications  that  the  debtor  is  experiencing\nsignificant financial difficulty, default or delinquency in interest or principal payments,\nindications  that  the  debtor  or  issuer  will  probably  enter  bankruptcy  or  other  financial\nreorganization, and the disappearance of an active market for that financial asset because\nof  financial  difficulties.  For  available-for-sale  equity  investments,  a  significant  or\nprolonged decline in the fair value of the security below its cost is also evidence that the\nassets are impaired. \n\n(Continued)\n\n\x0cACER INCORPORATED AND SUBSIDIARIES\n\nNotes to Consolidated Financial Statements\n\n33\n\nIf  the  Group  determines  that  no  objective  evidence  of  impairment  exists  for  an\nindividually  assessed  account  receivable,  whether  significant  or  not,  such  account\nreceivable  is  included  in  a  group  of  accounts  receivable  with  similar  credit  risk\ncharacteristics which are then collectively assessed for impairment.  Objective evidence\nthat receivables are impaired includes the Group\xe2\x80\x99s collection experience in the past, an\nincrease of delayed payments, and national or local economic conditions that correlate\nwith arrears of receivables.\n\nAn  impairment  loss  is  recognized  by  reducing  the  carrying  amount  of  the  respective\nfinancial assets with the exception of receivables, where the carrying amount is reduced\nthrough  an  allowance  account.  Except  for  the  write-off  of  uncollectible  receivables\nagainst  the  allowance  account,  changes  in  the  amount  of  the  allowance  account  are\nrecognized in profit or loss.\n\nAn impairment loss in respect of a financial asset measured at amortized cost is measured\nas the excess of the asset\xe2\x80\x99s carrying amount over the present value of the estimated future\ncash  flows  discounted  at  the  financial  asset\xe2\x80\x99 s  original  effective  interest  rate.  If,  in  a\nsubsequent period, the amount of the impairment loss decreases and the decrease can be\nrelated  objectively  to  an  event  occurring  after  the  impairment  was  recognized,  the\npreviously recognized impairment loss is reversed to the extent that the carrying amount\nof the financial assets at the date the impairment loss is reversed does not exceed what\nthe amortized cost would have been had the impairment loss not been recognized.\n\nWhen  an  impairment  loss  is  recognized  for  an  available-for-sale  asset,  the  cumulative\ngains  or  loss  that  had  been  recognized  in  other  comprehensive  income  is  reclassified\nfrom equity to profit or loss. Any subsequent recovery in the fair value of an impaired\navailable-for-sale  equity  security  is  recognized  in  other  comprehensive  income,  and\naccumulated  in  other  equity.  If,  in  a  subsequent  period,  the  fair  value  of  an  impaired\navailable-for-sale debt security increases and the increase can be related objectively to an\nevent  occurring  after  the  impairment  loss  was  recognized,  then  the  impairment  loss  is\nreversed, with the amount of the reversal recognized in profit or loss. \n\nImpairment  losses  and  recoveries  of  accounts  receivable  are  recognized  as  operating\nexpenses.  Impairment  losses  and  recoveries  of  other  financial assets are recognized as\nother gains and losses under non-operating income and loss.\n\n5)\n\nDerecognition of financial assets\n\nFinancial assets are derecognized when the contractual rights of the cash inflow from the\nasset are terminated, or when the Group transfers substantially all the risks and rewards\nof ownership of the financial assets to other enterprises.\n\nOn derecognition of a financial asset in its entirety, the difference between the carrying\namount and the sum of the consideration received or receivable and any cumulative gain\nor  loss  that  had  been  recognized  in  other  comprehensive  income  and  accumulated  in\n\xe2\x80\x9c other  equity  \xe2\x80\x93   unrealized  gain  (loss)  from  available-for-sale  financial  assets\xe2\x80\x9d   is\nrecognized in profit or loss, and included in non-operating income and loss.\n\n(Continued)\n\n\x0c34\n\nACER INCORPORATED AND SUBSIDIARIES\n\nNotes to Consolidated Financial Statements\n\nOn  derecognition  of  part  of  a  financial  asset,  the  previous  carrying  amount  of  the\nfinancial asset shall be allocated between the part that continues to be recognized and the\npart that is derecognized, on the basis of relative fair values of those parts on the date of\ntransfer. The difference between the carrying amount allocated to the part derecognized\nand the sum of the consideration received or receivable for the part of the financial asset\nderecognized  and  the  cumulative  gain  or  loss  that  has  been  recognized  in  other\ncomprehensive income allocated to the part derecognized is charged to profit or loss and\nincluded  in  non-operating  income  and  loss.  A  cumulative  gain  or  loss  that  had  been\nrecognized in other comprehensive income is allocated between the part that continues to\nbe recognized and the part that is derecognized, based on the relative fair values of those\nparts.\n\n(iii) Financial liabilities and equity instruments\n\n1)\n\nClassification of debt or equity\n\nDebt or equity instruments issued by the Group are classified as financial liabilities or\nequity  in  accordance  with  the  substance  of  the  contractual  agreement.  An  equity\ninstrument is any contract that evidences a residual interest in the assets of the Group\nafter deducting all of its liabilities. Equity instruments are recognized at the amount of\nconsideration received less the direct issuing cost.\n\nInterest and gain or loss related to the financial liability are recognized in profit or loss\nand included in non-operating income and loss.\n\n2)\n\nFinancial liabilities measured at fair value through profit or loss\n\nA financial liability is classified in this category if it is classified as held for trading or is\ndesignated as a financial liability measured at fair value through profit or loss on initial\nrecognition.  A  financial  liability  is  classified  as  held  for  trading  if  it  is  acquired\nprincipally for the purpose of selling or repurchasing in the short term.  Derivatives are\nalso categorized as financial liabilities at fair value through profit or loss unless they are\ndesignated  as  hedges.    The  Group  designates  financial  liabilities,  other  than  those\nclassified as held for trading, as measured at fair value through profit or loss at initial\nrecognition under one of the following situations:\n\n\xef\x82\xb7 Such  designation  eliminates  or  significantly  reduces  a  measurement  or  recognition\ninconsistency  that  would  otherwise  arise  from  measuring  assets  or  liabilities  or\nrecognizing the gains and losses on them on a different basis;\n\n\xef\x82\xb7 Performance of the financial liabilities is evaluated on a fair value basis; \n\xef\x82\xb7 A hybrid instrument contains one or more embedded derivatives.\n\n(Continued)\n\n\x0cACER INCORPORATED AND SUBSIDIARIES\n\nNotes to Consolidated Financial Statements\n\n35\n\nAt  initial  recognition,  the  financial  liability  is  recognized  at  fair  value,  and  any\nattributable  transaction  costs  are  recognized  in  profit  or  loss  as  incurred.  Subsequent\nchanges that are measured at fair value, which take into account any interest expense, are\nrecognized in profit or loss and included in non-operating income and loss.\n\n3)\n\nFinancial liabilities measured at amortized cost\n\nFinancial liabilities not classified as held for trading or not designated as at fair value\nthrough profit or loss, which comprise loans and borrowings, accounts payable, and other\npayables,  are  measured  at  fair  value  plus  any  directly  attributable  transaction  costs  at\ninitial  recognition.  Subsequent  to  initial  recognition,  these  financial  liabilities  are\nmeasured at amortized cost using the effective interest method. \n\n4)\n\nDerecognition of financial liabilities\n\nThe  Group  derecognizes  a  financial  liability  when  its  contractual  obligation  has  been\nfulfilled or cancelled, or has expired. The difference between the carrying amount of a\nfinancial liability derecognized and the consideration paid (including any non-cash assets\ntransferred  or  liabilities  assumed)  is  recognized  in  profit  or  loss  and  included  in  non-\noperating income and loss.\n\n5)\n\nOffsetting of financial assets and liabilities \n\nFinancial assets and liabilities are presented on a net basis only when the Group has the\nlegally enforceable right to offset and intends to settle such financial assets and liabilities\non a net basis or to realize the assets and settle the liabilities simultaneously.\n\n(iv) Derivative  financial  instruments  and  hedge  accounting  (applicable  commencing  January  1,\n\n2018) \n\nThe Group uses derivative financial instruments to hedge its foreign currency and interest rate\nexposures. Derivatives are initially measured at fair value. Any attributable transaction costs\nthereof  are  recognized  in  profit  or  loss  as  incurred.  Subsequent  to  initial  recognition,\nderivatives are measured at fair value, and changes therein are recognized in profit or loss and\nincluded  in  non-operating  income  and  loss,  unless  the  derivative  financial  instruments  are\ndesignated as effective hedging instruments, in which the timing of the recognition in profit or\nloss depends on the nature of the hedge relationship. If the valuation of a derivative instrument\nresults in a positive fair value, it is classified as a financial asset; otherwise, it is classified as a\nfinancial liability.\n\nEmbedded derivatives are separated from the host contract and accounted for separately if the\neconomic  characteristics  and  risks  of  the  host  contract  that  is  a  non-financial  asset  are  not\nclosely related to the embedded derivatives and the host contract is not measured at FVTPL.\n\nCertain derivatives are designated as either (i) hedges of the fair value of recognized assets or\nliabilities (fair value hedge) or (ii) hedges of highly probable forecast transactions (cash flow\nhedge).  The  Group  documents,  at  the  inception  of  the  transaction,  the  relationship  between\nhedging instruments and hedged items, as well as its risk management objectives and strategy\nfor  undertaking  various  hedging  transactions.  The  Group  also  documents  its  assessment  of\nwhether the derivatives used in hedging transactions are highly effective in offsetting changes\n\n(Continued)\n\n\x0cACER INCORPORATED AND SUBSIDIARIES\n\nNotes to Consolidated Financial Statements\n\n36\n\nin fair value or cash flows of hedged items.\n\nThe  Group  shall  discontinue  hedge  accounting  prospectively  only  when  the  hedging\nrelationship (or a part of a hedging relationship) ceases to meet the qualifying criteria (after\ntaking into account any rebalancing of the hedging relationship, if applicable). This includes\ninstances when the hedging instrument expires or is sold, terminated or exercised. \n\n1)\n\nFair value hedge\n\nChanges in the fair value of a hedging instrument that is qualified as a fair value hedge\nare  recognized  in  profit  or  loss  (or  other  comprehensive  income,  if  the  hedging\ninstrument hedges an equity instrument measured at FVOCI). \n\n2)\n\nCash flow hedge\n\nWhen  a  derivative  is  designated  and  qualified  as  a  cash  flow  hedging  instrument,  the\neffective  portion  of  changes  in  the  fair  value  is  recognized  in  other  comprehensive\nincome and accumulated in \xe2\x80\x9cother equity \xe2\x80\x94gains (losses) on hedging instruments\xe2\x80\x9d, and\nis limited to the cumulative change in fair value of the hedged item from inception of the\nhedge. Any ineffective portion of changes in the fair value of the derivative is recognized\nimmediately in profit or loss, and included in non-operating income and loss.\n\nAmounts  previously  recognized  in  other  comprehensive  income  and  accumulated  in\nequity  are  reclassified  to  profit  or  loss  in  the  same  periods  when  the  hedged  item  is\nrecognized in profit or loss, and are included in the same account in the statements of\ncomprehensive income as the hedged item.\n\n(v) Derivative financial instruments and hedge accounting (applicable before January 1, 2018) \n\nExcept for the following items, the Group applied the same accounting policies as applicable\ncommencing January 1, 2018. \n\nEmbedded derivatives are separated from the host contract and accounted for separately if the\neconomic characteristics and risk of the host contract are not closely related to the embedded\nderivatives and the host contract is not measured at FVTPL. \n\nFor all cash flow hedges including hedges of expected transactions recognized in non-financial\nassets  or  non-financial  liabilities,  amounts  previously  recognized  in  other  comprehensive\nincome, and accumulated in equity, are reclassified to profit or loss in the same periods when\nexpected cash flow of hedged items are recognized in profit or loss. In addition, for the cash\nflow  hedge  that  is  discontinuing  before  January  1,  2018,  changes  in  fair  value  of  forward\nposition are recognized in profit or loss. \n\n(h)\n\nInventories\n\nInventories are measured at the lower of cost and net realizable value. Inventories are recorded at\nstandard cost and adjusted to approximate weighted-average cost at the end of the reporting period.\nNet realizable value represents the estimated selling price in the ordinary course of business, less all\nestimated costs of completion and necessary selling expenses.\n\n(Continued)\n\n\x0cACER INCORPORATED AND SUBSIDIARIES\n\nNotes to Consolidated Financial Statements\n\n37\n\n(i) Non-current assets held for sale\n\nNon-current  assets  or  disposal  groups  comprising  assets  and  liabilities  that  are  expected  to  be\nrecovered primarily through a sale transaction, rather than through continuing use, are reclassified as\nnon-current assets held for sale. Such non-current assets or disposal groups must be available for\nimmediate sale in their present condition, and the sale is highly probable within one year. \n\nImmediately before the initial classification of the non-current assets (or disposal groups) as held for\nsale, the carrying amount of the assets (or all the assets and liabilities in the group) is measured in\naccordance with the Group\xe2\x80\x99s applicable accounting policies. Thereafter, the assets are measured at\nthe  lower  of  their  carrying  amount  and  fair  value  less  costs  to  sell.  Any  impairment  loss  on  a\ndisposal group will first be allocated to goodwill, and then the remaining balance of impairment loss\nis allocated to assets and liabilities on a pro rata basis, except for the assets not within the scope of\nIAS 36 \xe2\x80\x93 Impairment of Assets. Such assets will continue to be measured in accordance with the\nGroup\xe2\x80\x99s accounting policies. Impairment losses for assets initially classified as held for sale and any\nsubsequent  gains  or  losses  on  remeasurement  are  recognized  in  profit  or  loss;  nevertheless,  the\nreversal gains are not recognized in excess of any cumulative impairment loss.\n\nIntangible  assets  and  property,  plant  and  equipment are no longer amortized or depreciated when\nthey are classified as held for sale. \n\n(j)\n\nInvestments accounted for using equity method\n\nInvestments accounted for using the equity method include investments in associates and interests in\njoint venture. \n\nAn  associate  is  an  entity  over  which  the  Group  has  significant  influence  and  that  is  neither  a\nsubsidiary nor a joint venture. Significant influence is the power to participate in the financial and\noperating policy decisions of the investee but is not control or joint control over those policies.\n\nA joint venture is a joint arrangement whereby the Group and other parties that have joint control of\nthe  arrangement  have  rights  to  the  net  assets  of  the  joint  arrangement.  Joint  control  is  the\ncontractually agreed sharing of control of an arrangement, which exists only when decisions about\nthe relevant activities require unanimous consent of the parties sharing control. \n\nThe operating results as well as assets and liabilities of associates and joint venture are incorporated\nin these consolidated financial statements using the equity method of accounting. Under the equity\nmethod, an investment in an associate or a joint venture is initially recognized in the consolidated\nbalance sheet at cost, and adjusted thereafter, to recognize the Group\xe2\x80\x99s share of profit or loss and\nother  comprehensive  income  (loss)  of  the  associate  and  joint  venture,  as  well  as  the  distribution\nreceived. The Group also recognizes its share in the changes in the equities of associates and joint\nventure.\n\nAny excess of the cost of acquisition over the Group\xe2\x80\x99s share of the net fair value of the identifiable\nassets, liabilities, and contingent liabilities of an associate or a joint venture recognized at the date of\nacquisition,  is  recognized  as  goodwill,  which  is  included  within  the  carrying  amount  of  the\ninvestment. Any excess of the Group\xe2\x80\x99s share of the net fair value of the identifiable assets, liabilities\nand contingent liabilities over the cost of acquisition, after reassessment, is recognized immediately\nin profit or loss.\n\n(Continued)\n\n\x0cACER INCORPORATED AND SUBSIDIARIES\n\nNotes to Consolidated Financial Statements\n\n38\n\nWhen  necessary,  the  entire  carrying  amount  of  the  investment  (including  goodwill)  is  tested  for\nimpairment as a single asset by comparing its recoverable amount (higher of value in use and fair\nvalue less costs to sell) with its carrying amount. Any impairment loss recognized forms part of the\ncarrying amount of the investment. Any reversal of that impairment loss is recognized to the extent\nthat the recoverable amount of the investment subsequently increases.\n\nThe  Group  discontinues  the  use  of  equity  method  from  the  date  when  the  Group  ceases  to  have\nsignificant influence over an associate. When the Group retains an interest in the former associate,\nthe  Group  measures  the  retained  interest  at  fair  value  at  that  date.  The  difference  between  the\ncarrying amount of the associate at the date the equity method was discontinued, and the fair value\nof  any  retained  interest  and  any  proceeds  from  disposing  of  a  part  interest  in  the  associate,  is\nincluded in the determination of the gain or loss on disposal of the associate. In addition, the Group\nshall account for all amounts recognized in other comprehensive income in relation to that associate\non the same basis as would be required if the associate had directly disposed of the related assets or\nliabilities. If the Group\xe2\x80\x99s ownership interest in an associate is reduced as a result of disposal, with\nthe investment continues to be an associate, the Group should reclassify only a proportionate amount\nof the gain or loss previously recognized in other comprehensive income to profit or loss.\n\nWhen the Group subscribes to additional shares in an associate or a joint venture at a percentage\ndifferent  from  its  existing  ownership  percentage,  the  resulting  carrying  amount  of  the  investment\ndiffers from the amount of the Group\xe2\x80\x99s proportionate interest in the net assets of the associate or\njoint  venture.  The  Group  records  such  a  difference  as  an  adjustment  to  investments  with  the\ncorresponding amount charged or credited to capital surplus. If the Group\xe2\x80\x99s ownership interest is\nreduced  due  to  the  additional  subscription  to  the  shares  of  associate  or  joint  venture  by  other\ninvestors,  the  proportionate  amount  of  the  gains  or  losses  previously  recognized  in  other\ncomprehensive income in relation to that associate or joint venture shall be reclassified to profit or\nloss on the same basis as would be required if the associate or joint venture had directly disposed of\nthe related assets or liabilities.\n\nUnrealized profits resulting from transactions between the Group and an associate or joint venture\nare  eliminated  to  the  extent  of  the  Group\xe2\x80\x99 s  interest  in  the  associate  or  joint  venture.  Unrealized\nlosses on transactions with associates or joint venture are eliminated in the same way, except to the\nextent that the underlying asset is impaired.\n\nAdjustments  are  made  to  associates\xe2\x80\x99   and  joint  ventures\xe2\x80\x99   financial  statements  to  conform  to  the\naccounting polices applied by the Group. \n\n(k)\n\nProperty, plant and equipment \n\n(i)\n\nRecognition and measurement\n\nProperty,  plant  and  equipment  are  measured  at  cost  less  accumulated  depreciation  and\naccumulated impairment losses. Cost includes expenditure that is directly attributable to the\nacquisition of the asset and bringing the asset to the location and condition necessary for it to\nbe capable of operating in the manner intended by management, the initial estimate of the costs\nof dismantling and removing the item and restoring the site on which it is located, and any\nborrowing  cost  that  is  eligible  for  capitalization.  Purchased  software  that  is  integral  to  the\nfunctionality of the related equipment is capitalized as part of that equipment.\n\n(Continued)\n\n\x0cACER INCORPORATED AND SUBSIDIARIES\n\nNotes to Consolidated Financial Statements\n\n39\n\nThe  gain  or  loss  arising  from  the  disposal  of  an  item  of  property,  plant  and  equipment  is\ndetermined  as  the  difference  between  the  net  disposal  proceeds,  if  any,  and  the  carrying\namount of the item, and is recognized as non-operating income and loss.\n\n(ii) Reclassification to investment property \n\nA property is reclassified to investment property at its carrying amount when the purpose of\nthe property changes from owner-occupied to investment.  \n\n(iii) Subsequent costs\n\nSubsequent  costs  are  capitalized  only  when  it  is  probable  that  future  economic  benefits\nassociated  with  the  costs  will  flow  to  the  Group  and  the  cost  of  the  item  can  be  measured\nreliably. The carrying amount of the replaced part is derecognized in profit and loss. All other\nrepairs and maintenance are charged to expense as incurred.\n\n(iv) Depreciation\n\nDepreciation is calculated on the cost of assets less their residual values and is recognized on a\nstraight  line  basis  over  the  estimated  useful  lives.  When  an  item  of  property,  plant  and\nequipment  comprises  significant  individual  components  for  which  different  depreciation\nmethods or useful lives are appropriate, each component is depreciated separately. Land is not\ndepreciated. The depreciation is recognized in profit or loss.\n\nThe estimated useful lives of property, plant and equipment for the current and comparative\nperiods are as follows: buildings\xef\xbc\x8dmain structure - 30 to 50 years; air-conditioning system - 10\nyears;  other  equipment  pertaining  to  buildings  -  20  years;  computer  and  communication\nequipment - 2 to 5 years; and other equipment - 3 to 10 years.\n\nDepreciation  methods,  useful  lives,  and  residual  values  are reviewed at each financial year-\nend, with the effect of any changes in estimate accounted for on a prospective basis. \n\n(l)\n\nInvestment property\n\nInvestment property is property held either to earn rental income or for capital appreciation or for\nboth, but not for use in the ordinary course of business or for administrative purposes. Investment\nproperty  is  measured  at  cost  on  initial  recognition.  Subsequent  to  initial  recognition,  investment\nproperty  is  measured  at  initial  acquisition  cost  less  accumulated  depreciation  and  accumulated\nimpairment losses. The methods for depreciating and determining the useful life and residual value\nof investment property are the same as those adopted for property, plant and equipment. \n\nCost includes expenditure that is directly attributable to the acquisition of the investment property,\nbringing the investment property to the condition necessary for intended use, and any borrowing cost\nthat is eligible for capitalization.\n\nAn investment property is reclassified to property, plant and equipment at its carrying amount when\nthe purpose of the investment property has been changed from investment to owner-occupied.\n\n(Continued)\n\n\x0cACER INCORPORATED AND SUBSIDIARIES\n\nNotes to Consolidated Financial Statements\n\n40\n\n(m) Leases\n\nLeases  are  classified  as  finance  leases  when  the  Group  assumes  substantially  all  the  risks  and\nrewards incidental to ownership of the assets. All other leases are classified as operating leases.\n\n(i)\n\nThe Group as lessor\n\nLease income from an operating lease is recognized in profit or loss on a straight-line basis\nover the lease term. Initial direct costs incurred in negotiating and arranging an operating lease\nare added to the carrying amount of the leased asset and recognized as expense over the lease\nterm on a straight-line basis. Incentives granted to the lessee to enter into the operating lease\nare  recognized  as  a  reduction  of  rental  income  over  the  lease  term  on  a  straight-line  basis.\nContingent  rents  are  recognized  as  income  in  the  period  when  the  lease  adjustments  are\nconfirmed.\n\n(ii) The Group as lessee \n\nPayments  made  under  operating  leases  (excluding  insurance  and  maintenance  expenses)  are\ncharged to expense over the lease term on a straight-line basis. Lease incentives received from\nthe lessor are recognized as a reduction of rental expense over the lease term on a straight-line\nbasis. Contingent rents are recognized as expense in the period when the lease adjustments are\nconfirmed.\n\n(n)\n\nIntangible assets\n\n(i) Goodwill\n\nGoodwill arising from acquisitions of subsidiaries is accounted for as intangible assets. Refer\nto note 4(v) for the description of the measurement of goodwill at initial recognition.  Goodwill\narising  from  acquisitions  of  associates  is  included  in  the  carrying  amount  of  investments in\nassociates.  Goodwill  is  not  amortized  but  is  measured  at  cost  less  accumulated  impairment\nlosses.\n\n(ii) Trademarks\n\nTrademarks acquired in a business combination are measured at fair value at the acquisition\ndate. Subsequent to the initial recognition, trademarks with definite useful lives are carried at\ncost  less  accumulated  amortization  and  accumulated  impairment  losses.  Amortization  is\nrecognized on a straight-line basis over the estimated useful lives of 7 years. Trademarks with\nindefinite useful lives are carried at cost less any accumulated impairment losses and are tested\nfor impairment annually. The useful life of an intangible asset not subject to amortization is\nreviewed annually at each financial year-end to determine whether events and circumstances\ncontinue to support an indefinite useful life assessment for the asset. Any change in the useful\nlife assessment from indefinite to definite is accounted for as a change in accounting estimate.\n\n(Continued)\n\n\x0cACER INCORPORATED AND SUBSIDIARIES\n\nNotes to Consolidated Financial Statements\n\n41\n\n(iii) Other intangible assets\n\nOther separately acquired intangible assets are carried at cost or fair value at the acquisition\ndate,  less  accumulated  amortization  and  accumulated  impairment  losses.  Amortization  is\nrecognized in profit or loss on a straight-line basis over the following estimated useful lives:\ncustomer relationships - 7 to 10 years; developed technology - 10 years; channel resources -\n8.8 years; developing technology - 15 years; patents - 4 to 15 years; acquired software - 1 to 3\nyears.\n\nThe residual value, amortization period, and amortization method are reviewed at least at each\nfinancial year-end, with the effect of any changes in estimate accounted for on a prospective\nbasis.\n\n(o)\n\nImpairment of non-financial assets\n\n(i) Goodwill \n\nFor  the  purpose  of  impairment  testing,  goodwill  arising  from  a  business  combination  is\nallocated  to  each  of  the  Group\xe2\x80\x99 s  cash-generating  units  (CGUs)  that  are  expected  to  benefit\nfrom the synergies of the combination. The CGUs with goodwill are tested annually (or when\nthere  are  indications  that  a  CGU  may  have  been  impaired)  for  impairment.  When  the\nrecoverable amount of a CGU is less than the carrying amount of the CGU, the impairment\nloss  is  recognized  firstly  by  reducing  the  carrying  amount  of  any  goodwill  allocated  to  the\nCGU  and  then  proportionately  allocated  to  the  other  assets  of  the  CGU  on  the  basis  of  the\ncarrying amount of each asset in the CGU. Any impairment loss is recognized immediately in\nprofit or loss. A subsequent reversal of the impairment loss on goodwill is prohibited.\n\n(ii) Other tangible and intangible assets \n\nNon-financial  assets  other  than  inventories,  deferred  income  tax  assets,  assets  arising  from\nemployee benefits, and non-current assets held for sale are reviewed for impairment at each\nreporting date to determine whether there is any indication of impairment. When there exists\nan indication of impairment for an asset, the recoverable amount of the asset is estimated. If\nthe recoverable amount of an individual asset cannot be determined, the Group estimates the\nrecoverable amount of the CGU to which the asset has been allocated. \n\nThe recoverable amount for an individual asset or a CGU is the higher of its fair value less\ncosts to sell or its value in use. In assessing value in use, the estimated future cash flows are\ndiscounted to their present value using a pre-tax discount rate that reflects the evaluation of\ncurrent market on the time values of money and on the risks specific to the asset. When the\nrecoverable amount of an asset or a CGU is less than its carrying amount, the carrying amount\nof the asset or CGU is reduced to its recoverable amount, and an impairment loss is recognized\nin profit or loss immediately. \n\n(Continued)\n\n\x0cACER INCORPORATED AND SUBSIDIARIES\n\nNotes to Consolidated Financial Statements\n\n42\n\nThe Group assesses at each reporting date whether there is any evidence that an impairment\nloss recognized in prior periods for an asset other than goodwill may no longer exist or may\nhave decreased.  If so, an impairment loss recognized in prior periods for an asset other than\ngoodwill is reversed, and the carrying amount of the asset or CGU is increased to its revised\nestimate of recoverable amount. The increased carrying amount shall not exceed the carrying\namount  (net  of  amortization  or  depreciation)  that  would  have  been  determined  had  no\nimpairment loss been recognized in prior years.\n\nIntangible  assets  with  indefinite  useful  lives  or  those  not  yet  available  for  use  are  tested\nannually  for  impairment.  An  impairment  loss  is  recognized  for  the  excess  of  the  asset\xe2\x80\x99 s\ncarrying amount over its recoverable amount.\n\n(p)\n\nProvisions\n\nProvisions are recognized when the Group has a present obligation (legal or constructive) as a result\nof a past event, it is probable that the Group will be required to settle the obligation, and a reliable\nestimate can be made of the amount of the obligation.\n\n(i) Warranties\n\nA provision for warranties is recognized when the underlying products or services are sold.\nThis  provision  reflects  the  historical  warranty  claim  rate  and  the  weighting  of  all  possible\noutcomes against their associated probabilities.\n\n(ii) Sales return provision\n\nA  provision  for  sales  returns  is  recognized  when  the  underlying  products  are  sold.  This\nprovision is estimated based on historical sales return data.\n\n(iii) Others\n\nProvisions for litigation claims and environmental restoration are recognized when the Group\nhas a present obligation (legal or constructive) as a result of a past event, it is probable that the\nGroup  will  be  required  to  settle  the  obligation,  and  a  reliable  estimate  can  be  made  of  the\namount of the obligation.\n\n(q) Treasury stock\n\nCommon  stock  repurchased  by  the  Group  treated  as  treasury  stock  (a  contra-equity  account)  is\nreported at acquisition cost (including all directly accountable costs).  When treasury stock is sold,\nthe excess of sales proceeds over cost is accounted for as capital surplus\xef\xbc\x8dtreasury stock.  If the\nsales  proceeds  are  less  than  cost,  the  deficiency  is  accounted  for  as a reduction of the remaining\nbalance  of  capital  surplus\xef\xbc\x8d treasury  stock.  If  the  remaining  balance  of  capital  surplus\xef\xbc\x8d treasury\nstock  is  insufficient  to  cover  the  deficiency,  the  remainder  is  recorded  as  a  reduction  of  retained\nearnings. The cost of treasury stock is computed using the weighted-average cost of different types\nof repurchase.\n\n(Continued)\n\n\x0cACER INCORPORATED AND SUBSIDIARIES\n\nNotes to Consolidated Financial Statements\n\n43\n\nIf  treasury  stock  is  retired,  the  weighted-average  cost  of  the  retired  treasury  stock  is  written  off\nagainst the par value and the capital surplus premium, if any, of the stock retired on a pro rata basis.\nIf the weighted-average cost written off exceeds the sum of the par value and the capital surplus, the\ndifference  is  accounted  for  as  a  reduction  of  capital  surplus\xef\xbc\x8d treasury  stock,  or  a  reduction  of\nretained earnings for any deficiency where capital surplus\xef\xbc\x8dtreasury stock is insufficient to cover the\ndifference. If the weighted-average cost written off is less than the sum of the par value and capital\nsurplus, if any, of the stock retired, the difference is accounted for as an increase in capital surplus\xef\xbc\x8d\ntreasury stock.\n\n(r) Revenue recognition \n\n(i)\n\nRevenue from contracts with customers (applicable commencing January 1, 2018)\n\nRevenue is measured based on the consideration to which the Group expects to be entitled in\nexchange for transferring goods or services to a customer. The Group recognizes revenue when\nit  satisfies  a  performance  obligation  by  transferring  control  of  a  good  or  a  service  to  a\ncustomer. The accounting policies for the Group\xe2\x80\x99s main types of revenue are explained below.\n\n1)\n\nSale of goods\n\nThe Group recognizes revenue when control of the products has been transferred, being\nwhen the products are delivered to the customer, the customer has full discretion over the\nchannel and price to sell the products, and there is no unfulfilled obligation that could\naffect the customer\xe2\x80\x99s acceptance of the products. Delivery occurs when the products have\nbeen  shipped  to  the  specific  location,  the  risks  of  obsolescence  and  loss  have  been\ntransferred  to  the  customer,  and  either  the  customer  has  accepted  the  products  in\naccordance with the sales contract, the acceptance provisions have lapsed, or the Group\nhas objective evidence that all criteria for acceptance have been satisfied.\n\nThe  Group  recognizes  revenue  based  on  the  price  specified  in  the  contract, net of the\nestimated volume discounts and rebates. Accumulated experience is used to estimate the\ndiscounts and rebates using the expected value method, and revenue is only recognized to\nthe extent that it is highly probable that a significant reversal will not occur. A refund\nliability  is  recognized  for  expected  sales  discounts  and rebate payable to customers in\nrelation to sales made until the end of the reporting period. No element of financing is\ndeemed  present  as  the  sales  are  made  with  a  credit  term  ranged  from  30  to  90  days,\nwhich is consistent with the market practice.\n\nSome  subsidiaries  of  the  Group  grant  their  customers  the  right  to  return  the  products\nwithin 90 days. Therefore, they reduce revenue by the amount of expected returns and\nrecognize a refund liability and a right to the returned goods. Accumulated experience is\nused  to  estimate  such  returns  at  the  time  of  sale.  At  each  reporting  date,  the  Group\nreassesses the estimated amount of expected returns.\n\nThe Group\xe2\x80\x99s obligation to provide a refund for faulty goods under the standard warranty\nterms  is  recognized  as  a  provision  for  warranty.  Please  refer  to  note  6(s)  for  more\nexplanation.\n\nA receivable is recognized when the goods are delivered as this is the point in time that\nthe Group has a right to an amount of consideration that is unconditional.\n\n(Continued)\n\n\x0cACER INCORPORATED AND SUBSIDIARIES\n\nNotes to Consolidated Financial Statements\n\n44\n\n2)\n\nRevenue from service rendered\n\nThe  Group  provides  system  implementation  or  integration  services  to  enterprise\ncustomers. Revenue from providing services is recognized in the accounting periods in\nwhich the services are rendered. For performance obligations that are satisfied over time,\nrevenue is recognized based on the actual service provided to the end of the reporting\nperiod  as  a  proportion  of the total services to be provided. The proportion of services\nprovided is determined based on the portion of the work performed, the time passed by,\nor the milestone reached. \n\nEstimates  of  revenues,  costs,  or  extent  of  progress  toward  completion,  are  revised  if\ncircumstances  change.  Any  resulting  increases  or  decreases  in  estimated  revenues  or\ncosts are reflected in profit or loss in the period in which the circumstances that give rise\nto the revision become known by the management.\n\nIn case of fixed-price contracts, the customer pays the fixed amount based on a payment\nschedule. If the accumulated revenue recognized by the Group exceed the payments, a\ncontract asset is recognized. If the payments exceed the accumulated revenue recognized,\na contract liability is recognized.\n\n3)\n\nFinancing components\n\nThe Group does not expect to have any contracts where the period between the transfer\nof  the  promised  goods  or  services  to  the  customer  and  the  payment  by  the  customer\nexceeds one year. As a consequence, the Group does not adjust any of the transaction\nprices for the time value of money. \n\n(ii) Revenue recognition (applicable before January 1, 2018)\n\nRevenue  from  the  sale  of  goods  or  services  is  measured  at  the  fair  value  of  consideration\nreceived or receivable, net of returns, rebates, and other similar discounts.\n\n1)\n\nSale of goods\n\nRevenue  from  the  sale  of  goods  is  recognized  when  all  the  following  conditions  have\nbeen satisfied: (a) the significant risks and rewards of ownership of the goods have been\ntransferred to the buyer; (b) the Group retains neither continuing managerial involvement\nto the degree usually associated with ownership nor effective control over the goods sold;\n(c) the amount of revenue can be measured reliably; (d) it is probable that the economic\nbenefits associated with the transaction will flow to the Group; and (e) the cost incurred\nor to be incurred, in respect of the transaction, can be measured reliably. \n\nThe timing of the transfers of risks and rewards varies depending on the individual terms\nof the sales agreement. Revenue is not recognized for the sale of key components to an\noriginal  design  manufacturer  for  manufacture  or  assembly  as  the  significant  risks  and\nrewards of the ownership of materials are not transferred.\n\nRevenue from extended warranty contracts is deferred and amortized as earned over the\ncontract period, ranging from one to three years.\n\n(Continued)\n\n\x0cACER INCORPORATED AND SUBSIDIARIES\n\nNotes to Consolidated Financial Statements\n\n45\n\n2)\n\nServices\n\nRevenue from services rendered is recognized by reference to the stage of completion at\nthe reporting date.\n\n3)\n\nRental income, interest income, and dividend income\n\nRental income from investment property is recognized over the lease term on a straight-\nline basis. \n\nDividend income from investments is recognized when the shareholder\xe2\x80\x99s right to receive\npayment has been established, provided that it is probable that the economic benefits will\nflow to the Group and the amount of income can be measured reliably. \n\nInterest income is accrued on a time basis, by reference to the principal outstanding and\nat the effective interest rate applicable.\n\n(iii) Contract costs (applicable commencing January 1, 2018)\n\n1)\n\nIncremental costs of obtaining a contract\n\nThe Group recognizes the incremental costs of obtaining a contract with a customer as an\nasset if the Group expects to recover those costs. The incremental costs of obtaining a\ncontract are those costs that the Group incurs to obtain a contract with a customer that it\nwould not have incurred if the contract had not been obtained. Costs to obtain a contract\nthat would have been incurred, regardless of whether the contract was obtained, shall be\nrecognized as an expense when incurred, unless those costs are explicitly chargeable to\nthe customer regardless of whether the contract is obtained.\n\nThe Group applies the practical expedient to recognize the incremental costs of obtaining\na contract as an expense when incurred if the amortization period of the asset that the\nGroup otherwise would have recognized is one year or less.\n\n2)\n\nCosts to fulfil a contract\n\nIf the costs incurred in fulfilling a contract with a customer are not within the scope of\nanother Standard (e.g., IAS 2 Inventories, IAS 16 Property, Plant and Equipment or IAS\n38 Intangible Assets), the Group recognizes an asset from the costs incurred to fulfil a\ncontract only if those costs meet all of the following criteria:\n\n\xef\x82\xb7 the costs relate directly to a contract or to an anticipated contract that the Group can\n\nspecifically identify;\n\n\xef\x82\xb7 the costs generate or enhance resources of the Group that will be used in satisfying (or\n\nin continuing to satisfy) performance obligations in the future; and\n\n\xef\x82\xb7 the costs are expected to be recovered.\n\n(Continued)\n\n\x0c46\n\nACER INCORPORATED AND SUBSIDIARIES\n\nNotes to Consolidated Financial Statements\n\nGeneral and administrative costs, costs of wasted materials, labor or other resources to\nfulfil the contract that were not reflected in the price of the contract, costs that relate to\nsatisfied  performance  obligations  (or  partially  satisfied  performance  obligations),  and\ncosts  for  which  the  Group  cannot  distinguish  whether  the  costs  relate  to  unsatisfied\nperformance  obligations  or  to  satisfied  performance  obligations  (or  partially  satisfied\nperformance obligations) are recognized as expenses when incurred.\n\n(s)\n\nEmployee benefits \n\n(i) Defined contribution plans\n\nObligations  for  contributions  to  defined  contribution  pension  plans  are  expensed  during  the\nyear in which employees render services.\n\n(ii) Defined benefit plans\n\nThe liability recognized in respect of defined benefit pension plans is the present value of the\ndefined benefit obligation at the reporting date less the fair value of plan assets. The discount\nrate for calculating the present value of the defined benefit obligation refers to the interest rate\nof high-quality government bonds that are denominated in the currency in which the benefits\nwill be paid and that have terms to maturity approximating the terms of the related pension\nobligation.\n\nThe defined benefit obligation is calculated annually by qualified actuaries using the projected\nunit credit method. When the calculation results in a benefit to the Group, the recognized asset\nis limited to the total amount of the present value of the economic benefits available in the\nform of refunds from the plan or reductions in future contributions to the plan.  The minimum\nfunding requirements of any plans applicable to the Group should be taken into consideration\nwhen determining the present value of the economic benefits. An economic benefit is available\nto  the  Group  if  it  is  realizable  during  the  life  of  the  plan  or  upon  settlement  of  the  plan\nliabilities.\n\nWhen the benefits of a plan are improved, the expenses related to the increased obligations\nresulting from the services rendered by employees in the past years are recognized in profit or\nloss immediately.\n\nThe remeasurements of the net defined benefit liability (asset) comprise (i) actuarial gains and\nlosses; (ii) return on plan assets, excluding amounts included in net interest on the net defined\nbenefit  liability  (asset);  and  (iii)  any  change  in  the  effect  of  the  asset  ceiling,  excluding\namounts  included  in  net  interest  on  the  net  defined  benefit  liability  (asset).  The\nremeasurements  of  the  net  defined  benefit  liability  (asset)  are  recognized  in  other\ncomprehensive income and reflected in other equity.\n\nThe Group recognizes gains or losses on the curtailment or settlement of a defined benefit plan\nwhen  the  curtailment  or  settlement  occurs.  The  gain  or  loss  on  curtailment  or  settlement\ncomprises any resulting change in the fair value of plan assets and any change in the present\nvalue of the defined benefit obligation. \n\n(Continued)\n\n\x0cACER INCORPORATED AND SUBSIDIARIES\n\nNotes to Consolidated Financial Statements\n\n47\n\n(iii) Short-term employee benefits\n\nShort-term  employee  benefit  obligations  are  measured  on  an  undiscounted  basis  and  are\nexpensed during the period in which employees render services.  A liability is recognized for\nthe  amount  expected  to  be  paid  under  short-term  cash  bonus  or  profit-sharing  plans  if  the\nGroup has a present legal or constructive obligation to make such payments as a result of past\nservice provided by the employees, and the obligation can be estimated reliably.\n\n(t)\n\nShare-based payment\n\nShare-based payment awards granted to employees are measured at fair value at the date of grant.\nThe fair value determined at the grant date is expensed over the period that the employees become\nunconditionally entitled to the awards, with a corresponding increase in equity. The compensation\ncost is adjusted to reflect the number of awards given to employees for which the performance and\nnon-market conditions are expected to be met, such that the amount ultimately recognized shall be\nbased on the number of equity instruments that eventually vested. \n\nThe grant date of options for employees to subscribe new shares for a cash injection is the date when\nthe Board of Directors approves the exercise price and the shares to which employees can subscribe. \n\n(u) Government grant\n\nA government grant is recognized in profit or loss only when there is reasonable assurance that the\nGroup will comply with the conditions attached to it and that the grant will be received.\n\nA  government  grant  that  becomes  receivable  as  compensation  for  expenses  or  losses  already\nincurred or for the purpose of giving immediate financial support to the Group with no future related\ncosts is recognized in profit or loss in the period in which it becomes receivable.\n\nGovernment grant is recognized in other gains and losses.\n\n(v)\n\nIncome taxes \n\nIncome tax expenses include both current taxes and deferred taxes. Current and deferred taxes are\nrecognized in profit or loss unless they relate to business combinations or items recognized directly\nin equity or other comprehensive income.\n\nCurrent tax is the expected tax payable or receivable on the taxable income or loss for the year, using\ntax rates enacted or substantively enacted at the reporting date, and any adjustments to tax payable in\nrespect of previous years.\n\nDeferred  income  taxes  are  recognized  in  respect  of  temporary  differences  between  the  carrying\namounts of assets and liabilities for financial reporting purposes and the amounts used for taxation\npurposes.  Deferred taxes are not recognized for:\n\n(i)\n\nTemporary differences on the initial recognition of assets or liabilities in a transaction that is\nnot a business combination and that affects neither accounting nor taxable profit or loss;\n\n(ii) Temporary differences arising from investments in subsidiaries and joint ventures to the extent\nthat the Group is able to control the timing of the reversal of the temporary differences, and it\nis probable that the differences will not reverse in the foreseeable future; and\n\n(iii) Temporary differences arising from initial recognition of goodwill.\n\n(Continued)\n\n\x0cACER INCORPORATED AND SUBSIDIARIES\n\nNotes to Consolidated Financial Statements\n\n48\n\nDeferred  tax  assets  are  recognized  for  unused  tax  losses,  tax  credits,  and  deductible  temporary\ndifferences to the extent that it is probable that future taxable profits will be available against which\nthey  can  be  utilized.    Deferred  tax  assets  are  reviewed  at  each  reporting  date  and  reduced  to  the\nextent that it is no longer probable that the related tax benefit will be realized.\n\nDeferred tax is measured based on the expected manner of realization or settlement of the carrying\namount of the assets and liabilities, using tax rates enacted or substantively enacted at the reporting\ndate.\n\nDeferred  tax  assets  and  liabilities  are  offset  when  where  is  a  legally  enforceable  right  to  offset\ncurrent tax assets against current tax liabilities and when the deferred tax assets and liabilities relate\nto income taxes levied by the same tax authority on either the same taxable entity or different taxable\nentities where there is an intention to settle the balances on a net basis.\n\n(w) Business combinations\n\nGoodwill  is measured as the excess of the acquisition-date fair value of consideration transferred\n(including any non-controlling interest in the acquiree) over the net of the acquisition-date amounts\nof  the  identifiable  assets  acquired  and  liabilities  assumed  (generally  at  fair  value).  If  the residual\nbalance  is  negative,  the  Group  shall  reassess  whether  it  has  correctly  identified  all  of  the  assets\nacquired and liabilities assumed and recognize any additional assets or liabilities that are identified\nin that review, and shall recognize a gain on the bargain purchase thereafter.\n\nAcquisition-related costs are expensed as incurred except for the costs related to issuance of debt or\nequity instruments.\n\nFor  each  business  combination,  non-controlling  interest  in  the  acquiree  is  measured  either  at  fair\nvalue  or  at  the  non-controlling  interest\xe2\x80\x99 s  proportionate  share  of  the  fair  value  of  the  acquiree\xe2\x80\x99 s\nidentifiable net assets.\n\nIn a business combination achieved in stages, the Group shall remeasure its previously held equity\ninterest in the acquiree at its acquisition-date fair value and recognize the resulting gain or loss in\nprofit or loss. The amount previously recognized in other comprehensive income in relation to the\nchanges in the value of the Group\xe2\x80\x99s equity interest should be reclassified to profit or loss on the\nsame basis as would be required if the Group had disposed directly of the previously held equity\ninterest.\n\nIf the initial accounting for a business combination is incomplete by the end of the reporting period\nin  which  the  combination  occurs,  provisional  amounts  for  the  items  for  which  the  accounting  is\nincomplete are reported in the financial statements. During the measurement period, the provisional\namounts recognized at the acquisition date are retrospectively adjusted to reflect new information\nobtained  about  facts  and  circumstances  that  existed  as  of  the  acquisition  date.  The  measurement\nperiod shall not exceed one year from the acquisition date.\n\n(Continued)\n\n\x0cACER INCORPORATED AND SUBSIDIARIES\n\nNotes to Consolidated Financial Statements\n\n49\n\n(x) Earnings per share (\xe2\x80\x9cEPS\xe2\x80\x9d)\n\nThe  basic  and  diluted  EPS  attributable  to  stockholders  of  the  Company  are  disclosed  in  the\nconsolidated  financial  statements.  Basic  EPS  is  calculated  by  dividing  net  income  attributable  to\nstockholders of the Company by the weighted-average number of common shares outstanding during\nthe year.  In calculating diluted EPS, the net income attributable to stockholders of the Company and\nweighted-average number of common shares outstanding during the year are adjusted for the effects\nof  dilutive  potential  common  shares.  The  Group\xe2\x80\x99 s  dilutive  potential  common  shares  include\nrestricted shares of stock issued to employees and profit sharing for employees to be settled in the\nform of common stock.\n\n(y) Operating segments\n\nAn operating segment is a component of the Group that engages in business activities from which it\nmay earn revenues and incur expenses (including revenues and expenses relating to transactions with\nother components of the Group). Operating results of the operating segment are regularly reviewed\nby the Group\xe2\x80\x99s chief operating decision maker, who decides on the allocation of resources to the\nsegment and assesses its performance for which discrete financial information is available.\n\n5.\n\nCritical Accounting Judgments and Key Sources of Estimation and Assumption Uncertainty\nThe preparation of the consolidated financial statements in conformity with the Regulations and Taiwan-\nIFRSs requires management to make judgments, estimates and assumptions that affect the application of\nthe accounting policies and the reported amount of assets, liabilities, income and expenses. Actual results\nmay differ from these estimates.\n\nThe  estimates  and  underlying  assumptions  are reviewed on an ongoing basis.  Revisions to accounting\nestimates are recognized in the period in which the estimate is revised and in the future periods affected.\n\nInformation about assumptions and estimation uncertainties that have a significant risk of resulting in a\nmaterial adjustment within the next financial year is included as follows:\n\n(a) Revenue recognition (accrual of sales return and allowance)\n\nThe  Group  recognizes  revenue  when  the earning process is completed. The Group also records a\nprovision for estimated future returns and other allowances in the same period the related revenue is\nrecorded. Provision for estimated sales returns and other allowances is generally made and adjusted\nbased on historical experience, market and economic conditions, and any other known factors that\nwould significantly affect the allowance. The adequacy of estimations is reviewed periodically. The\nfierce market competition and rapid evolution of technology could result in significant adjustments\nto the provision made.\n\n(Continued)\n\n\x0cACER INCORPORATED AND SUBSIDIARIES\n\nNotes to Consolidated Financial Statements\n\n50\n\n(b) Valuation of inventory\n\nInventories are measured at the lower of cost or net realizable value.  The Group uses judgment and\nestimates to determine the net realizable value of inventory at each reporting date.\n\nDue to rapid technological changes, the Group estimates the net realizable value of inventory, taking\nobsolescence and unmarketable items into account at the reporting date, and then writes down the\ncost  of  inventories  to  net  realizable  value.  The  net  realizable  value  of  the  inventory  is  mainly\ndetermined  based  on  assumptions  of  future  demand  within  a  specific  time  horizon,  which  could\nresult in significant adjustments.Refer to note 6(h) for further description of inventory write-downs.\n\n(c)\n\nImpairment of goodwill\n\nThe  assessment  of  impairment  of  goodwill  requires  the  Group  to  make  subjective  judgments  to\nidentify cash-generating units, allocate the goodwill to relevant cash-generating units, and estimate\nthe recoverable amount of relevant cash-generating units. Any changes in these estimates based on\nchanged economic conditions or business strategies could result in significant adjustments in future\nyears. Refer to note 6(n) for further description of the impairment of goodwill.\n\n6.\n\nSignificant account disclosures  \n(a) Cash and cash equivalents\n\nCash on hand\nBank deposits \nTime deposits\n\xe3\x80\x80\nFinancial assets and liabilities measured at fair value through profit or loss\n\n$\n\n$\n\n5,024\n16,414,413\n10,863,601\n27,283,038\n\n(b)\n\nDecember 31,\n\nDecember Accordingly,  the  Group  recognized  a  loss of $255,345 (arising\nfrom the fair value measurement of the convertible bonds) which was presented in other gains and\nlosses in the accompanying consolidated statements of comprehensive income. \n\nASBZ,  a  subsidiary  of  the  Company,  entered  into  separate  agreements  with  StarBreeze  and\nEnterspace AB, with a total investment amount of US$10,500 thousand, for the development of VR\nparks  to  obtain  its  profit-sharing  right.  In  2018,  the  Group  amended  the  expected  amount  of  net\nprofit  shared  and  recognized  a  loss  of  $244,633  (arising  from  the  fair  value  measurement  of  the\nprofit-sharing right) which was presented in other gains and losses in the accompanying consolidated\nstatements of comprehensive income.\n\n(Continued)\n\n\x0cACER INCORPORATED AND SUBSIDIARIES\n\nNotes to Consolidated Financial Statements\n\n52\n\nThe Group entered into derivative contracts to manage foreign currency exchange risk arising from\noperating activities.
