Consolidated Financial Statements\n\n(c)\n\nFinancial assets measured at fair value through other comprehensive income\n\nEquity investments measured at fair value through other comprehensive income\n\n54\n\nDecember 31,\n\n2018\n\n$\n\nCurrent\nNon-current\n\nDomestic listed stock\nUnlisted stock\n\n3,160,183\n1,269,263\n4,429,446\n88,989\n4,340,457\n4,429,446\nThe  Group  designated  the  investments  shown  above  as  financial  assets  measured  at  fair  value\nthrough  other  comprehensive  income  because  these  equity  instruments  are  held  for  long-term\nstrategic  purposes  and  not  for  trading.  These  investments  were  classified  as  available-for-sale\nfinancial assets on December 31, 2017.\n\n$\n$\n\n$\n\nIn  2018,  certain  financial  assets  measured  at  FVOCI  were  disposed  at  a  fair  value  of  $429,747,\nresulting a gain of $32,665. The realized gain accumulated in other comprehensive income has been\ntransferred to retained earnings. \n\n(d) Available-for-sale financial assets\n\nDomestic listed stock\nUnlisted stock\n\nCurrent\nNon-current\n\n(e)\n\nInvestments in debt instrument without an active market\n\nDecember 31,\n\n2017\n3,619,007\n1,751,663\n5,370,670\n118,329\n5,252,341\n5,370,670\n\n$\n\n$\n$\n\n$\n\nDecember 31,\n\n2017\n\nCurrent\nNon-current\n\nConvertible bond and convertible notes\nRight of profit-sharing in VR parks\n\n232,466\n308,444\n540,910\n232,466\n308,444\n540,910\nInvestments  in  debt  instrument  shown  above  were  classified  as  financial  assets  measured  at  fair\nvalue through profit or loss on December 31, 2018. While assessing the recoverability of notes and accounts receivable, the Group considers any\nchanges  in  the  credit  quality  between  the  initial  transaction  date  and  the  reporting  date.  The\nallowance  for  doubtful  receivables  was  assessed  by  referring  to  the  collectability  of  receivables\nbased  on  an  individual  trade  term  analysis,  the  historical  payment  behavior  and  current  financial\ncondition  of  customers,  and  the  provision  for  sales  returns  and  allowances.  Notes  and  accounts\nreceivable that were past due but for which the Group had not recognized a specific allowance for\ndoubtful receivables after the assessment were still considered recoverable.\n\nMovements of the allowance for notes and accounts receivable was as follows:\n\nBalance at January 1 (per IAS 39)\nAdjustment on initial application of IFRS 9\nBalance at January 1 (per IFRS 9)\nImpairment losses recognized (reversed)\nAcquisition through business combination\nWrite-off\nReclassification to other receivables (note 6(g))\nEffect of exchange rate changes\nBalance at December 31\n\n$\n\n$\n\n2018\n\n174,487\n60,777\n235,264\n(798)\n3,242\n(9,849)\n(40,141)\n(1,416)\n186,302\n\n2017\n\nIndividually\n\nassessed\n\nimpairment\n103,457\n\nCollectively\n\nassessed\n\nimpairment\n12,648\n\n28,432\n\n-\n(14,867)\n-\n\n(2,529)\n114,493\n\n5,750\n44,719\n(3,123)\n\n-\n-\n\n59,994\n\nThe  Group  entered  into  factoring  contracts  with  several  banks  to  sell  part  of  their  accounts\nreceivable without recourse. market price of similar\nreal estate transaction, the valuation (the inputs used in the fair value measurement were classified to\nlevel 3) by an independent appraiser or the value in use of the investment property. The value in use\nis the present value of the future cash flows from continuous lease activities. On December 31, 2018\nand 2017, the estimated discount rate used for calculating the present value of the future cash flows\nwas 6.13% and 4.90%, respectively.\n\nFor certain land acquired, the ownership registration has not been transferred to the land acquirer,\nAPDI,  a  subsidiary  of  the  Company.  To  protect  its  interests,  APDI  has  obtained  signed  deeds  of\nassignment  from  the  titleholders  assigning  all  rights  and  obligations  related  to  the  land  to  APDI.\nAdditionally, the land title certificates are held by APDI, and APDI has registered its liens thereon.\n\n(n)\n\nIntangible assets\n\n(i)\n\nThe  movements  of  costs,  and  accumulated  amortization  and The  plans  (covered  by  the  Labor  Standards  Law)  entitle  a  retired  employee  to\nreceive a payment based on years of service and average salary for the six months prior to the\nemployee\xe2\x80\x99s retirement.\n\n(25,691)\n\n$\n\nForeign subsidiaries, including AJC, ATH, AIN, AMI, AIL, APHI, AEG, ASZ, AIT, ASIN,\nACF and AOJ, also have defined benefit pension plans based on their respective local laws and\nregulations.\n\n1)\n\nComposition of plan assets\n\nThe pension fund (the \xe2\x80\x9cFund\xe2\x80\x9d) contributed by the Company and its domestic subsidiaries\nis managed and administered by the Bureau of Labor Funds of the Ministry of Labor (the\nBureau  of  Labor  Funds).  According  to  the  \xe2\x80\x9c Regulations  for  Revenues,  Expenditures,\nSafeguard and Utilization of the Labor Retirement Fund\xe2\x80\x9d, with regard to the utilization\nof the Fund, minimum earnings shall be no less than the earnings attainable from two-\nyear  time  deposits  with  interest  rates  offered  by  local  banks.  The  Company  and  its\ndomestic subsidiaries also established pension funds in accordance with the \xe2\x80\x9cRegulations\nGoverning the Management, Investment, and Distribution of the Employees\xe2\x80\x99 Retirement\nFund Established by a Profit-seeking Enterprise\xe2\x80\x9d, which are funded by time deposits and\nbank  deposits  deposited  in  the  designated  financial  institutions.  The  administration  of\npension funds is separate from the Group, and the principal and interest from such funds\nshall  not  be  used  in  any  form  except  for  the  payment  of  pension  and  severance  to\nemployees.\n\n(Continued)\n\n\x0c72\n\nACER INCORPORATED AND SUBSIDIARIES\n\nNotes to Consolidated Financial Statements\n\nForeign  subsidiaries  with  defined  benefit  pension  plans  make  pension  contributions  to\npension management institutions in accordance with their respective local regulations.\n\nAs  of  December  31,  2018  and  2017,  the  Group\xe2\x80\x99 s  fair  value  of  plan  assets,  by  major\ncategories, were as follows:\n\nDecember 31,\n\nDecember 31,\n\n2018\n\n2017\n\n$\n\nCash\nEquity instruments\nInstruments with fixed return\nReal estate\n\n481,557\n332,136\n58,661\n200,364\n1,072,718\nCash  includes  the  labor  pension  fund  assets. ranges from  5 years to 27\nyears. The Group expects to make contribution of $118,423 to the defined benefit plans\nin the year following December 31, 2018.\n\n8)\n\nSensitivity analysis\n\nWhen  calculating  the  present  value  of  the  defined  benefit  obligations,  the  Group  uses\njudgments and estimations to determine the actuarial assumptions for each measurement\ndate,  including  discount  rates  and  future  salary  changes.  Any  changes  in  the  actuarial\nassumptions may significantly impact the amount of the defined benefit obligations.\n\nThe following table summarizes the impact of a change in the assumptions on the present\nvalue of the defined benefit obligation on December 31, 2018 and 2017.\n\nDecember 31, 2018\n\n0.25% \nIncrease \n\n0.25%\nDecrease \n\nDecember 31, 2017\n0.25%\nDecrease \n\n0.25%\nIncrease \n\n$\n$\n\n112,668\n(71,357)\n\n(111,459)\n55,284\n\n115,350\nDiscount rate\n(59,065)\nFuture salary change\nEach sensitivity analysis considers the change in one assumption at a time, leaving the\nother assumptions unchanged. This approach shows the isolated effect of changing one\nindividual assumption but does not take into account that some assumptions are related.\nThe method used to carry out the sensitivity analysis is the same as the calculation of the\nnet defined benefit liabilities recognized in the balance sheets. The method used to carry\nout the sensitivity analysis is the same as in the prior year.\n\n(102,352)\n61,642\n\n(ii) Defined contribution plans\n\nThe Company and its domestic subsidiaries contribute monthly an amount equal to 6% of each\nemployee\xe2\x80\x99s monthly wages to the employee\xe2\x80\x99s individual pension fund account at the Bureau of\nLabor  Insurance  in  accordance  with  the  provisions  of  the  Labor  Pension  Act.  Under  this\ndefined contribution plan, the Group has no legal or constructive obligation to pay additional\namounts  after  contributing  a  fixed  amount  to  the  Bureau  of  Labor  Insurance.  Foreign\nsubsidiaries make contributions in compliance with their respective local regulations.\n\nFor the years ended December 31, 2018 and 2017, the Group recognized pension expenses of\n$390,521 and $350,873, respectively, in relation to the defined contribution plans.\n\n(Continued)\n\n\x0cACER INCORPORATED AND SUBSIDIARIES\n\nNotes to Consolidated Financial Statements\n\n75\n\n(v)\n\nIncome taxes\n\n(i)\n\nIncome tax returns of the Group are filed individually by each entity and not on a combined\nbasis. stock\n\nThe  Company  had  issued  17,460  thousand  shares  of  restricted  stock  to  its  employees  on\nAugust 26, 2014. In 2018 and 2017, the Company recalled 1,569 thousand shares and 4,230\nthousand  shares,  respectively,  of  restricted  stock  from  certain  employees  due  to  their\nresignation and retirement, as well as failing to meet certain vesting conditions. The Board of\nDirectors  had  approved  the  capital  reductions  for  retirement  of  restricted  shares  issued  to\nemployees and the related registration process has been completed.\n\nAs of December 31, 2018 and 2017, the Company had issued 5,858 thousand units and 6,446\nthousand units, respectively, of global depository receipts (GDRs).  The GDRs were listed on\nthe London Stock Exchange, and each GDR represents five common shares.\n\nAs  of  December  31,  2018  and  2017,  the  Company\xe2\x80\x99 s  authorized  shares  of  common  stock\nconsisted  of  3,500,000  thousand  shares,  of  which  3,074,934  thousand  shares  and  3,076,503\nthousand shares, respectively, were issued. The par value of the Company\xe2\x80\x99s common stock is\n$10 per share. All issued shares were paid up upon issuance.\n\nCertain shares of common stock were not outstanding as they were held by the Company\xe2\x80\x99s\nsubsidiaries  or  were  non-vested  restricted  stock.  The  movements  in  outstanding  shares  of\ncommon stock in 2018 and 2017 were as follows (in thousands of shares): \n\nBalance at January 1\nVested restricted stock\nBalance at December 31\n\n(ii) Capital surplus\n\n2018\n3,026,277\n1,911\n3,028,188\n\n2017\n3,026,277\n\n-\n\n3,026,277\n\nPaid-in capital in excess of par value\nSurplus from mergers\nSurplus related to treasury stock transactions and cash\n\ndividend\n\nDifference between consideration and carrying amount of\n\nsubsidiaries acquired or disposed\n\nEmployee share options\nSurplus from equity-method investments\nRestricted stock issued to employees\n\n$\n\n$\n\nDecember 31,\n\n2018\n11,101,376\n16,027,221\n\nDecember 31,\n\n2017\n13,173,098\n16,027,221\n\n340,556\n\n307,802\n\n100,600\n90,000\n253,598\n-\n\n27,913,351\n\n-\n\n90,000\n173,516\n80,547\n29,852,184\n\n(Continued)\n\n\x0cACER INCORPORATED AND SUBSIDIARIES\n\nNotes to Consolidated Financial Statements\n\n79\n\nPursuant  to  the  Company  Act,  any  realized  capital  surplus  is  initially  used  to  cover\naccumulated deficit, and the balance, if any, could be transferred to common stock as stock\ndividends  or  distributed  by  cash  based  on  the  original  shareholding  ratio.  Realized  capital\nsurplus  includes  the  premium  derived  from  the  issuance  of  shares of stock in excess of par\nvalue and donations received by the Company. In accordance with the \xe2\x80\x9cRegulations Governing\nthe Offering and Issuance of Securities by Securities Issuers\xe2\x80\x9d, distribution of stock dividends\nfrom capital surplus in any one year shall not exceed 10% of paid-in capital.\n\n(iii) Legal reserve, special reserve, and dividend policy\n\nThe Company\xe2\x80\x99s Articles of Incorporation stipulate that at least 10% of annual net income, after\ndeducting  accumulated  deficit,  if  any,  must  be  retained  as  legal  reserve  until such retention\nequals  the  amount  of  paid-in  capital.  In  addition,  a  special  reserve  shall  be  set  aside  in\naccordance  with  applicable  laws  and  regulations.  The  remaining  balance,  together  with  the\nunappropriated  earnings  from  the  previous  years,  after  retaining  a  certain  portion  of  it  for\nbusiness  considerations,  can  be  distributed  as  dividends  to  stockholders.  Except  for  the\ndistribution  of  capital  surplus  and  legal  reserve  in  accordance  with  applicable  laws  and\nregulations, the Company cannot distribute any earnings when there are no retained earnings.\n\nSince  the  Company  operates  in  an  industry  experiencing  rapid  change  and  development,\nearnings are distributed in consideration of the current year\xe2\x80\x99s earnings, the overall economic\nenvironment,  related  laws  and  decrees,  and  the  Company\xe2\x80\x99 s  long-term  development  and\nstability in its financial position. The Company has adopted a stable dividend policy, in which\na cash dividend comprises at least 10% of the total dividend distribution.\n\nAdditionally, according to the Company Act, a company shall first retain 10% of its income\nafter  taxes  as  legal  reserve  until  such  retention  equals  the  amount  of  paid-in  capital.  If  a\ncompany  has  no  accumulated  deficit,  it  may,  pursuant  to  a  resolution  approved  by  the\nstockholders,  distribute  its  legal  reserve  by  issuing  new  shares  or  distributing  cash  for  the\nportion of legal reserve which exceeds 25% of the paid-in capital.\n\nIn  accordance  with  Ruling  No.  1010047490  issued  by  the  FSC  on  November  21,  2012,  a\nspecial reserve shall be retained at an amount equal to the proportionate share of the carrying\nvalue of the treasury stock held by subsidiaries in excess of the market value at the reporting\ndate.  The  special  reserve  may  be  reversed  when  the  market  value  recovers  in  subsequent\nperiods.\n\nIn  accordance  with  Ruling  No.  1010012865  issued  by  the  FSC  on  April  6,  2012,  a  special\nreserve  equal  to  the  total  amount  of  items  that  are  accounted  for  as  deductions  from\nstockholders\xe2\x80\x99   equity  shall  be  set  aside  from  current  and  prior-year  earnings.  This  special\nreserve shall revert to retained earnings and be made available for distribution when the items\nthat  are  accounted  for  as  deductions  from  stockholders\xe2\x80\x99   equity  are  reversed  in  subsequent\nperiods.\n\nOn June 15, 2018, the Company\xe2\x80\x99s shareholders approved an appropriation of legal reserve and\nspecial  reserve  of  $281,559  and  $2,534,028,  respectively.  Additionally,  the  Company\xe2\x80\x99 s\nshareholders decided to distribute cash deriving from the capital surplus of $2,153,552 ($0.7\ndollars per share), of which $32,754 was distributed to the subsidiaries holding the Company\xe2\x80\x99s\ncommon shares. \n\n(Continued)\n\n\x0cACER INCORPORATED AND SUBSIDIARIES\n\nNotes to Consolidated Financial Statements\n\n80\n\nOn June 21, 2017, the Company\xe2\x80\x99s shareholders approved a decrease in its special reserve, legal\nreserve and capital surplus of $1,306,709, $145,190 and $3,448,397, respectively, to offset the\naccumulated  deficit.  Additionally,  the  Company\xe2\x80\x99 s  shareholders  decided  to  distribute  cash\nderiving from the capital surplus of $1,538,379 ($0.5 dollars per share), of which $23,308 was\ndistributed to the subsidiaries holding the Company\xe2\x80\x99s common shares. Related information is\navailable on the Market Observation Post System website of the Taiwan Stock Exchange.\n\nThe appropriation of 2018 earnings had been proposed by the Company\xe2\x80\x99s Board of Directors\non March 20, 2019, which included the appropriations of legal reserve and special reserve of\n$306,043 and $406,544, respectively, as well as the distribution of cash dividends amounting\nto $2,367,699 (at $0.77 dollars per share).\n\n(iv) Treasury stock\n\nAs  of  December  31,  2018  and  2017,  details  of  the  GDRs  (for  the  implementation  of  an\noverseas employee stock option plan) held by subsidiary AWI and the Company\xe2\x80\x99s common\nstock  held  by  subsidiaries  AWI  (to  maintain  the  Company\xe2\x80\x99 s  shareholders\xe2\x80\x99   equity),  CCI  (to\nmaintain the Company\xe2\x80\x99s shareholders\xe2\x80\x99 equity), and ETEN (resulting from the acquisition of \nETEN) were as follows (expressed in thousands of shares):\n\nCommon stock\nGDRs\n\nCommon stock\nGDRs\n\nNumber of\n\nshares\n21,809\n24,937\n\nNumber of\n\nshares\n21,809\n24,937\n\nDecember 31, 2018\n\nCarrying\namount\n\n945,239\n1,969,617\n2,914,856\n\n$\n\n$\n\nDecember 31, 2017\n\nCarrying\namount\n\n945,239\n1,969,617\n2,914,856\n\n$\n\n$\n\nMarket value \n424,185\n475,167\n899,352\n\nMarket value \n526,687\n558,991\n1,085,678\n\nAccording  to  the  Securities  and  Exchange  Act,  treasury  stock  cannot  be  collateralized.  In\naddition,  treasury  shares  do  not  bear  shareholder  rights  prior  to  being  sold  to  third  parties.\nMoreover,  the  number  of  treasury  shares  shall  not  exceed  10%  of  the  number  of  common\nshares issued. The total amount of treasury stock shall not exceed the sum of retained earnings,\npaid-in capital in excess of par value, and other realized capital surplus.\n\n(Continued)\n\n\x0cACER INCORPORATED The  employees  who  were  granted  restricted  stock  are  entitled  to  purchase  the\nshares of restricted stock at the exercise price of $ 0. The vesting period of the restricted stock\nis 1~4 years subsequent to the grant date, and the restricted shares of stock will be vested from\n0%  to  25%  considering  the  Company\xe2\x80\x99 s  and  individual  employee\xe2\x80\x99 s  performance  conditions.\nThe  restricted  stock  received  by  the  employees  shall  be  deposited  and  held  in  an  escrow\naccount and could not be sold, pledged, transferred, gifted, or disposed of in any other forms\nduring the vesting period; nevertheless, the rights of a shareholder (such as voting and election\nat the shareholders\xe2\x80\x99 meeting) are the same as the rights of the Company\xe2\x80\x99s shareholders but are\nexecuted by the custodian. During the vesting period, the restricted shares of stock are entitled\nto any earnings distribution.  The Company will take back the restricted stock from employees\nand retire those shares when the vesting conditions cannot be met.\n\nThe movements in number of restricted shares of stock issued (in thousands) in 2018 and 2017\nwere as follows:\n\n2018\n\n2017\n\nBalance at January 1\nForfeited during the period\nVested shares\nUnvested shares at December Statements\n\n86\n\nThe  major  changes  in  the  balance  of  contract  assets  primarily  resulted  from  the  timing\ndifference between obtaining the rights to consideration in exchange for transferring products\nor  providing  services  to  a  customer  and  the  billing  to  the  customer  (i.e.,  the  rights  to\nconsideration become unconditional). The major changes in the balance of contract liabilities\nwere due to the timing difference between the satisfaction of performance obligation and the\nreceipt of customer\xe2\x80\x99s payment. \n\nThe amount of revenue recognized for the year ended December 31, 2018 that was included in\nthe contract liability balance at January 1, 2018, was $609,943.\n\n(aa) Revenue\n\nRevenue from sale of goods\nRevenue from services rendered\nOthers\n\nPlease refer to note 6(z) for details on revenue for 2018.\n\n(ab) Remuneration to employees and directors\n\n2017\n230,527,987\n5,410,430\n1,336,466\n237,274,883\n\n$\n\n$\n\nThe Company\xe2\x80\x99s Articles of Incorporation require that annual earning shall first be offset against any\ndeficit,  then,  a  minimum  of  4%  shall  be  allocated  as  employee  remuneration  and  a  maximum  of\n0.8%  be  allocated  as  directors\xe2\x80\x99   remuneration.  Employees  who  are  entitled  to  receive  the\nabovementioned employee remuneration, in share or cash, include the employees of subsidiaries of\nthe Company who meet certain specific requirements.\n\nFor  the  years  ended  December  31,  2018  and  2017,  the  Company  accrued  its  remuneration  to\nemployees amounting to $163,313 and $121,049, respectively, and the remuneration for directors of\n$6,911 and $4,263, respectively. The said amounts, which were recognized as operating expenses,\nwere  calculated  based  on  pre-tax  net  profit  for  each  year  before  deducting  the  amount  of  the\nremuneration  to  employees  and  directors,  multiplied  by  the  proposed  distribution  ratio  of\nremuneration to employees and directors. The difference between accrual and actual payment, if any,\nwill be treated as change in accounting estimate and recognized in profit or loss in the following\nyear. \n\nThe aforementioned accrued remunerations to employees and directors were same as the amounts\napproved by the Board of Directors on March 20, 2019 and March 21, 2018, respectively, which\nwere paid in cash.\n\nRelated information is available on the Market Observation Post System website of Taiwan Stock\nExchange.\n\n(Continued)\n\n\x0cACER INCORPORATED AND SUBSIDIARIES\n\nNotes to Consolidated Financial The different levels have been defined as follows: \n\na)\n\nb)\n\nc)\n\nLevel  1:  quoted  prices  (unadjusted)  in  active  markets  for  identical  assets  or\nliabilities.\n\nLevel 2: inputs other than quoted prices included within Level 1 that are observable\nfor the asset or liability, either directly (i.e., as prices) or indirectly (i.e., derived\nfrom prices).\n\nLevel 3: inputs for the assets or liabilities that are not based on observable market\ndata (unobservable inputs).\n\n(Continued)\n\n\x0cACER INCORPORATED AND SUBSIDIARIES\n\nNotes to Consolidated Financial The  fair  value  of  foreign\ncurrency  forward  contracts  and  foreign  currency  option  contracts  is  computed\nindividually by each contract using the valuation technique.\n\nThe fair value of privately held stock in Level 3 fair value hierarchy is estimated by\nusing  the  market  approach  and  is  determined  by  reference  to  recent  financing\nactivities, valuations of similar companies, market conditions, and other economic\nindicators.\n\n4)\n\nQuantitative information of significant unobservable inputs \n\nSignificant\n\nunobservable inputs\n    Discount for lack of\n\nmarketability\n(10%~30%)\n\nInterrelationship\nbetween significant\nunobservable inputs\n\nand fair value\nmeasurement\nThe estimated fair\nvalue would\ndecrease if the\ndiscount for lack of\nmarketability was\nhigher\n\nValuation\ntechnique\nComparable\ncompany\nvaluation\n\nItem\n\nFinancial assets\nmeasured at fair\nvalue through\nother\ncomprehensive\nincome\n(Available-for-\nsale financial\nassets)\n\n5)\n\nFair  value  measurements  in  Level  3\xef\xbc\x8d sensitivity  analysis  of  reasonably  possible\nalternative assumptions\n\nThe  Group\xe2\x80\x99 s  measurement  on  the  fair  value  of  financial  instruments  may  change  if\ndifferent valuation models or inputs are used. For fair value measurements in Level 3,\nchanging  one  or  more  of  the  assumptions  would  have  the  following  effects  on  other\ncomprehensive income:\n\nDecember 31, 2018\nFinancial assets measured at fair value\nthrough other comprehensive income\nEquity investments without an active\n\nmarket\n\nInput\n\nChange in\nassumptions\n\nOther comprehensive income\nUnfavorable\nFavorable\n\nDiscount  for  lack\nof marketability\n\n1%\n\n11,431\n\n(11,431)\n\n(Continued)\n\n\x0cACER INCORPORATED AND SUBSIDIARIES\n\nNotes to Consolidated Financial Statements\n\n93\n\nDecember 31, 2017\nAvailable-for-sale financial assets\n\nInput\n\nChange in\nassumptions\n\nOther comprehensive income\nFavorable\nUnfavorable\n\nEquity investments without an active\n\nmarket\n\nDiscount  for  lack\nof marketability\n\n          1%\n\n12,051\n\n(12,051)\n\nThe favorable and unfavorable effects represent the changes in fair value, which is based\non  a  variety  of  unobservable  inputs  calculated  using  a  valuation  technique.  If  the  fair\nvalue  of  a  financial  instrument  is  subject  to  more  than  one  inputs,  the  analysis  above\nreflects  only  the  effects  of  changes  in  a  single  input  and  does  not  include  the\ninterrelationships with another input.\n\n(iv) Offsetting of financial assets and financial liabilities\n\nThe  Group  has  financial  instrument  transactions  which  are  set  off  in  accordance  with\nparagraph 42 of IAS 32; the related financial assets and liabilities are presented in the balance\nsheets on a net basis.\n\nThe  table  below  summarizes  the  related  information collateral\n\nreceived\n\nNet amount\n\n(e)=(c)-(d)\n42,750,982\n\nNotes and accounts\n\npayable\n\n(af) Financial risk management\n\nThe Group is exposed to credit risk, liquidity risk, and market risk (including currency risk, interest\nrate risk, and other market price risk).  The Group has disclosed the information on exposure to the\naforementioned risks and the Group\xe2\x80\x99s policies and procedures to measure and manage those risks as\nwell as the quantitative information below. \n\nThe Board of Directors are responsible for developing and monitoring the Group\xe2\x80\x99s risk management\npolicies.  The  Group\xe2\x80\x99 s  risk  management  policies  are  established  to  identify  and  analyze  the  risks\nfaced  by  the  Group,  to  set  appropriate  risk  limits  and  controls,  and  to  monitor  adherence  to  the\ncontrols. Risk management policies and systems are reviewed regularly to reflect changes in market\nconditions and the Group\xe2\x80\x99s operations.\n\nThe  Group\xe2\x80\x99 s  management  monitors  and  reviews  the  financial  activities  in  accordance  with\nprocedures  required  by  relevant  regulations  and  internal  controls.  Internal  auditors  undertake\nreviews of risk management controls and procedures, and the results of which are reported to the\nBoard of Directors on a regular basis.\n\n(i)\n\nCredit risk\n\n1)\n\nThe maximum exposure to credit risk\n\nCredit risk is the risk of financial loss to the Group if a customer or counterparty of a\nfinancial instrument fails to meet its contractual obligations, and arises principally from\nthe  Group\xe2\x80\x99 s  cash  and  cash  equivalents,  derivative  instruments,  receivables  from\ncustomers, and other receivables.  The maximum exposure to credit risk is equal to the\ncarrying amount of the Group\xe2\x80\x99s financial assets. \n\n(Continued)\n\n\x0cACER INCORPORATED AND SUBSIDIARIES\n\nNotes to Consolidated Financial Statements\n\n95\n\n2)\n\nConcentration of credit risk\n\nThe Group primarily sells and markets its multi-branded IT products through distributors\nin  different  geographic  areas.  The  Group  believes  that  there  is  no  significant\nconcentration of credit risk due to the Group\xe2\x80\x99s large number of customers and their wide\ngeographical spread.\n\n3)\n\nCredit risk from receivables\n\nRefer  to  note  6(f)  for  credit  risk  exposure  of  notes  and  accounts  receivable.  Other\nfinancial  assets  at  amortized  cost  includes  other  receivables  (refer  to  note  6(g)),  time\ndeposits (classified as other financial assets), etc. Abovementioned financial assets are\nconsidered  low-credit-risk  financial  assets,  and  thus,  the  loss  allowance  are  measured\nusing  12-months  ECL.  Please  refer  to note 4(g) for descriptions about how the Group\ndetermines the credit risk.\n\n(ii) Liquidity risk\n\nLiquidity  risk  is  the  risk  that  the  Group  will  encounter  difficulty  in  settling  its  financial\nliabilities by delivering cash or another financial assets. The Group manages liquidity risk by\nmonitoring  regularly  the  current  and  mid-  to  long-term  cash  demand,  maintaining  adequate\ncash and banking facilities, and ensuring compliance with the terms of the loan agreements. As\nof December 31, 2018 and 2017, the Group had unused credit facilities of $32,022,157 and\n$36,283,089, respectively.\n\nThe table below summarizes the maturity profile of the Group\xe2\x80\x99s financial liabilities based on\ncontractual undiscounted payments, including principal and interest.\n\nDecember 31, 2018\nNon-derivative financial liabilities:\n\xe3\x80\x80Short-term borrowings Group does not expect that the cash flows included in the maturity analysis would occur\nsignificantly earlier or at significantly different amounts.\n\n(iii) Market risk\n\nMarket risk is the risk that changes in market prices, such as foreign exchange rates, interest\nrates,  and  equity  prices,  will  affect  the  Group\xe2\x80\x99 s  income  or  the  value  of  its  financial\ninstruments.  The objective of market risk management is to manage and control market risk\nexposures within acceptable parameters, while optimizing the return.\n\nThe Group utilizes derivative financial instruments to manage market risk and the volatility of\nprofit or loss.  All such transactions are carried out within the guidelines set by the Board of\nDirectors. \n\n1)\n\nForeign currency risk\n\nThe  Group  is  exposed  to  foreign  currency  risk  on  sales  and  purchases  that  are\ndenominated in a currency other than the respective functional currencies of the Group\nentities.  The  foreign  currencies  used  in  these  transactions  are  mainly  the  US  dollar\n(USD),  Euro  (EUR),  Great  British  Pound  (GBP),  Australian  Dollar  (AUD),  Russian\nRuble (RUB), Indian Rupee (INR), etc.\n\nThe  Group  utilizes  foreign  currency  forward  contracts  to  hedge  its  foreign  currency\nexposure with respect to its forecast sales and purchases over the following 12 months.\n\n(Continued)\n\n\x0c97\n\nACER INCORPORATED AND SUBSIDIARIES\n\nNotes to Consolidated Financial Statements\n\na)\n\nExposure to foreign currency risk and sensitivity analysis\n\nThe  Group\xe2\x80\x99 s  exposure  to  foreign  currency  risk  arises  from  cash  and  cash\nequivalents,  notes  and  accounts  receivable  (including  related-party  receivables),\nnotes  and  accounts  payable  (including  related-party  payables),  other  receivables\n(including  related-party  receivables)  and  other  payables  that  are  denominated  in\nforeign  currency.  At  the  reporting  date,  the  carrying  amounts  of  the  Group\xe2\x80\x99 s\nsignificant monetary assets and liabilities denominated in a currency other than the\nrespective functional currencies of the Group entities and their sensitivity analysis\nwere  as  follows  (including  the  monetary  items  that  have  been  eliminated  in  the\naccompanying consolidated financial statements):\n\nDecember 31, 2018\n\nForeign\ncurrency \n\nExchange\n\nrate\n\nNTD \n\nChange in\nmagnitude\n\n(in thousands)\n\nPre-tax effect\non profit or\n\nloss  \n\nFinancial assets\n\xe3\x80\x80Monetary items\n\xe3\x80\x80EUR\n\xe3\x80\x80USD\n\xe3\x80\x80INR\n\xe3\x80\x80AUD\nFinancial liabilities\n\xe3\x80\x80Monetary items\n\xe3\x80\x80EUR\n\xe3\x80\x80USD\n\n$\n\n116,774\n754,410\n9,600,425\n85,158\n\n35.2415\n30.7330\n0.4405\n21.6637\n\n4,115,291\n23,185,283\n4,228,987\n1,844,837\n\n40,364\n1,728,583\n\n35.2415\n30.7330\n\n1,422,488\n53,124,541\n\nDecember 31, 2017\n\n%1\n%1\n%1\n%1\n\n41,153\n231,853\n42,290\n18,448\n\n%1\n%1\n\n14,225\n531,245\n(in thousands)\n\nPre-tax effect\non profit or\n\nloss  \n\nForeign\ncurrency \n\nExchange\n\nrate\n\nNTD \n\nChange in\nmagnitude\n\n$\n\n40.3336\n35.8325\n29.8480\n0.5174\n\n27,665\n52,458\n1,187,460\n1,293,499\n\n1,115,829\n1,879,701\n35,443,306\n669,256\n\nFinancial assets\n\xe3\x80\x80Monetary items\n\xe3\x80\x80GBP\n\xe3\x80\x80EUR\n\xe3\x80\x80USD\n\xe3\x80\x80RUB\nFinancial liabilities\n\xe3\x80\x80Monetary items\n\xe3\x80\x80GBP\n7,474\n\xe3\x80\x80EUR\n13,494\n\xe3\x80\x80USD\n612,683\nWith  varieties  of  functional  currencies  within  the  consolidated  entities  of  the\nGroup,  the  Group  disclosed  net  realized  and  unrealized  foreign  exchange  gain\n(loss)  on  monetary  items  in  aggregate.  Please  refer  to  note  6(ad)  for  further\ninformation.\n\n747,422\n1,349,380\n61,268,273\n\n11,158\n18,797\n354,433\n6,693\n\n18,531\n37,658\n2,052,676\n\n40.3336\n35.8325\n29.8480\n\n%1\n%1\n%1\n%1\n\n%1\n%1\n%1\n\n(Continued)\n\n\x0cACER INCORPORATED AND SUBSIDIARIES\n\nNotes to Consolidated Financial Statements\n\n98\n\n2)\n\nInterest rate risk\n\nThe Group\xe2\x80\x99s short-term borrowings and long-term debt carried floating interest rates, and\nthe  Group  has  not  entered into interest rate swap contracts to convert floating interest\nrates  to  fixed  interest  rates.    To  manage  the  interest  rate  risk,  the  Group  periodically\nassesses the interest rates of bank loans and maintains good relationships with financial\ninstitutions to obtain lower financing costs.  The Group also strengthens the management\nof  working  capital  to  reduce  the  dependence  on bank loans as well as the risk arising\nfrom fluctuation of interest rates.\n\nThe following sensitivity analysis is based on the risk exposure to floating-interest-rate\nliabilities on the reporting date. The sensitivity analysis assumes the liabilities recorded\nat the reporting date had been outstanding for the entire period.  The change in interest\nrate  reported  to  the  key  management  in  the  Group  is  based  on 100 basis points (1%),\nwhich is consistent with the assessment made by the key management in respect of the\npossible change in interest rate.\n\nIf the interest rate had been 100 basis points (1%) higher/lower with all other variables\nheld constant, pre-tax income (loss) for the years ended December 31, 2018 and 2017\nwould have been $39,771 and $64,854, respectively, lower/higher, which mainly resulted\nfrom the borrowings with floating interest rates.\n\n3)\n\nOther market price risk\n\nThe Group is exposed to the risk of price fluctuation in securities market resulting from\nits  investment  in  publicly  traded  stocks.  The  Group  supervises  the  equity  price  risk\nactively  and  manages  the  risk  based  on  fair  value.  The  Group  also  has  strategic\ninvestments in privately held stocks, in which the Group does not actively participate in\ntheir trading. \n\nAssuming  a  hypothetical  increase  or  decrease  of  5%  in  equity  prices  of  the  equity\ninvestments at each reporting date, the other comprehensive income for the years ended\nDecember  31,  2018  and  2017,  would  have  increased  or  decreased  by  $221,472  and\n$268,534, respectively.\n\n(ag) Capital management\n\nIn consideration of the industry dynamics and future developments, as well as external environment\nfactors, the Group maintains an optimal capital structure to enhance long-term shareholder value by\nmanaging its capital in a manner to ensure that it has sufficient and necessary financial resources to\nfund its working capital needs, research and development activities, dividend payments, and other\nbusiness  requirements  for  continuing  operations  and  to  reward  shareholders  and  take  into\nconsideration the interests of other stakeholders.\n\n(Continued)\n\n\x0cACER INCORPORATED AND SUBSIDIARIES\n\nNotes to Consolidated Financial Statements\n\n(ah) Changes in liabilities from financing activities\n\nThe reconciliation of liabilities arising from financing activities was as follows:\n\nLong-term debt\nShort-term borrowings\nTotal liabilities from\nfinancing activities\n\n$\n\n$\n\nJanuary 1,\n\n2018\n6,002,457\n482,894\n\nCash flows\n\n(2,681,440)\n98,492\n\n6,485,351\n\n(2,582,948)\n\n7. The Company has fulfilled its obligations according to the contracts.\n\n(b) An  American  company  has  filed  a  lawsuit  in  California  State  Court  against  Acer  for  violating\nconfidential  agreement  and  trade  secret.  The  Group  had  appointed  outside  counsel  to  handle  the\ncase. The lawsuit is still in progress. However, the Group has recognized the litigation provisions\nbased on the development of the aforesaid lawsuit. The management foresees no immediate material\nadverse effect on the Group\xe2\x80\x99 business operations and finance.\n\n(c)\n\nIn the ordinary course of its business from time to time, the Group received notices from third parties\nasserting that Acer has infringed certain patents and demanded that Acer should obtain certain patent\nlicenses. Although the Group does not expect that the outcome of any of these legal proceedings\n(individually or collectively) will have a material adverse effect on the Group\xe2\x80\x99s business operations\nand finance, the litigation is inherently unpredictable. Therefore, the Group could incur judgments or\nenter into settlements of claims that could adversely affect its operating results or cash flows in a\nparticular period.\n\n(Continued)\n\n\x0cACER INCORPORATED AND SUBSIDIARIES\n\nNotes to Consolidated Financial Statements\n\n103\n\n(d) The Group faces various taxation challenges around the world, such as in Australia, India, Indonesia,\nMexico, Austria, Italy, etc., due to rapid changes in international tax environment. The Group held\ndifferent position with various local tax authorities for certain tax audits (including income taxes and\nbusiness taxes) and has provided the accruals for the cases that met the criteria for recognizing a\nprovision.  Nevertheless,  the  tax  disputes  are  inherently  complicated  and  may  take  years  to  be\napproved by the tax authorities. The ultimate result is unpredictable and could adversely affect the\nGroup\xe2\x80\x99s operating results or cash flows in a particular period.\n\n(e) As of December 31, 2018 and 2017, the Company had outstanding stand-by letters of credit provided\n\nby the banks totaling $49,978 and $43,319, respectively, for purposes of bids and contracts.\n\n(f) As  of  December  31,  2018  and  2017,  the  Group  had  issued  promissory  notes  amounting  to\n$35,643,325 and $45,376,282, respectively, as collateral for obtaining credit facilities from financial\ninstitutions.\n\n10. Segment information\n\n(a) General information  \n\nThe Group\xe2\x80\x99s reportable segments comprise the device business group (\xe2\x80\x9cIT Hardware Products\xe2\x80\x9d) and\nother  business  groups.  The  IT  Hardware  Products  engages  mainly  in  the  research,  design,  and\nmarketing of personal computers, IT products, and tablet products. Other business groups, which do\nnot meet the quantitative reporting threshold, mainly engage in the activities of e-commerce, cloud\nservices,  sales  and  distribution  of  smart  devices,  IT  products,  new  energy  devices,  and  handheld\ndevices, as well as real estate services.\n\nStrategic investment expenditures (such as global branding expenditures, depreciation of the capital\nexpenditures  for  the  strengthening  of  the  global  information  structure,  and  non-routine  long-term\nstrategic  expenditures)  are  not  allocated  to  reportable  segments.  Operating  profit  is  used  as  the\nmeasurement for segment profit and the basis for performance evaluation. The reporting amount is\nconsistent  with  the  report  used  by  the  chief  operating  decision  maker.  There  was  no  material\ninconsistency between the accounting policies adopted for the operating segments and the significant\naccounting policies of the Group.\n\n(Continued)\n\n\x0cACER within which\n\nthe short-term financing amount shall not exceed 20% of the most recent audited or reviewed net worth of the Company.\n\n             For an entity which the Company owns more than 50% Parent-Company-Only Financial Statements\n\nFor the years ended December 31, 2018 and 2017\n\n(Expressed in Thousands of New Taiwan Dollars, Unless Otherwise Specified)\n\n8\n\n1. Organization and business\n\nAcer Incorporated (the \xe2\x80\x9cCompany\xe2\x80\x9d) was incorporated on August 1, 1976, as a company limited by shares\nunder  the  laws  of  the  Republic  of  China  (\xe2\x80\x9c R.O.C.\xe2\x80\x9d )  and  registered  under  the  Ministry  of  Economic\nAffairs, R.O.C. \n\nThe Company primarily engages in marketing and sale of brand-name IT products, as well as providing\nelectronic information services to its clients. The Company aims at the integrated applications of Internet\nof  Things  (IoT)  and  service-oriented  technology  in  the  future  to  provide  more  products  and  integrated\napplications combining software, hardware and service for consumer and commercial markets.\n\n2. Authorization of the Parent-Company-Only Financial Statements\n\nThese parent-company-only financial statements were authorized for issuance by the Board of Directors\non March 20, 2019.\n\n3. Application of New and Revised Accounting Standards and Interpretations\n\n(a)\n\nImpact  of  adoption  of  new,  revised  or  amended  standards  and  interpretations  endorsed  by  the\nFinancial Supervisory Commission, R.O.C. (\xe2\x80\x9cFSC\xe2\x80\x9d).\n\nIn preparing the accompanying parent-company-only financial statements, the Company has adopted\nthe  following  International  Financial  Reporting  Standards  (\xe2\x80\x9c IFRS\xe2\x80\x9d ),  International  Accounting\nStandards  (\xe2\x80\x9c IAS\xe2\x80\x9d ),  and  Interpretations  that  have  been  issued  by  the  International  Accounting\nStandards Board (\xe2\x80\x9c IASB\xe2\x80\x9d) (collectively, \xe2\x80\x9c IFRSs\xe2\x80\x9d) and endorsed by the FSC, with effective date\nfrom January 1, 2018.\n\nNew, Revised or Amended Standards and Interpretations\n\nAmendment to IFRS 2 Classification and Measurement of Share-based Payment\n\nTransactions\n\nEffective date\n\nper IASB\n\nJanuary 1, 2018\n\nAmendments to IFRS 4 Applying IFRS 9 Financial Instruments with IFRS 4\n\nInsurance Contracts\n\nIFRS 9 Financial Instruments\nIFRS 15 Revenue from Contracts with Customers\nAmendment to IAS 7 Statement of Cash Flows\xe2\x80\x94Disclosure Initiative\nAmendment to IAS 12 Income Taxes\xe2\x80\x94Recognition of Deferred Tax Assets for\n\nUnrealized Losses\n\nAmendments to IAS 40 Transfers of Investment Property\nAnnual Improvements to IFRS Standards 2014\xe2\x80\x932016 Cycle:\n\nAmendments to IFRS 12\nAmendments to IFRS 1 and Amendments to IAS 28\n\nJanuary 1, 2018\n\nJanuary 1, 2018\nJanuary 1, 2018\nJanuary 1, 2017\nJanuary 1, 2017\n\nJanuary 1, 2018\n\nJanuary 1, 2017\nJanuary 1, 2018\n\n(Continued)\n\n\x0c9\n\nACER INCORPORATED\n\nNotes to Parent-Company-Only Financial Statements\n\nNew, Revised or Amended Standards and Interpretations\nIFRIC 22 Foreign Currency Transactions and Advance Consideration\n\nEffective date\n\nper IASB\n\nJanuary 1, 2018\n\nExcept for the following items, the initial application of the above IFRSs did not have any material\nimpact on the parent-company-only\xe2\x80\x99s financial statements. The extent and impact of changes are as\nfollows:\n\n(i)\n\nIFRS 15 Revenue from Contracts with Customers\n\nIFRS 15 establishes a five-step model framework to determine the method, timing and amount\nof  revenue  recognized.  This  Standard  replaces  the  existing  revenue  recognition  guidance,\nincluding IAS 18 Revenue, IAS 11 Construction Contracts and the related interpretations. The\nCompany applies this standard retrospectively with the cumulative effect of initially applying\nthis Standard recognized at the date of initial application. The Company elected not to restate\nthe comparative information for the prior reporting period; but instead, continues to apply IAS\n11,  IAS  18  and  the  related  Interpretations  for  comparative  reporting  period.  The  Company\nrecognizes the cumulative effect upon the initial application of this Standard as an adjustment\nto the opening balance of its retained earnings on January 1, 2018.\n\nThe  Company  uses  the  practical  expedients  for  completed  contracts,  meaning,  it  need  not\nrestate those contracts that have been completed on January 1, 2018.\n\nThe following are the nature and impacts on the changes of accounting policies:\n\nUnder IAS 18, revenue for the sale of goods was recognized when the related significant risks\nand rewards of ownership of the goods have been transferred to the customers, the revenue and\nthe  cost  incurred,  or  to  be  incurred,  can  be  measured reliably, the economic benefits of the\ntransaction  will  probably  flow  to  the  Company,  and  there  is  neither  continuing  managerial\ninvolvement to the degree usually associated with ownership nor effect control over the goods\nsold. Under IFRS 15, revenue is recognized when a customer obtains control of the goods.\n\nFor certain contracts that give customers rebates or marketing support, revenue is recognized\nunder  IAS  18  when  relevant  allowance  could  be  reasonably  estimated  and  all  revenue\nrecognition criteria were met. Under IFRS 15, revenue is recognized for these contracts to the\nextent that it is highly probable that a significant reversal in the amount of cumulative revenue\nrecognized  will  not  occur.  A  refund  liability  will  be  recognized  for  the  estimated  sales\nallowance and presented separately in the statement of financial position.\n\n(Continued)\n\n\x0cACER INCORPORATED\n\nNotes to Parent-Company-Only Financial Statements\n\n10\n\n1)\n\nImpacts on financial statements\n\nThe  following  tables  summarize  the  impacts  of  adopting  IFRS15  on  the  Company\xe2\x80\x99 s \nparent-company-only financial statements.\n\nDecember 31, 2018\n\nBalance prior\n\nto the\n\nadoption of\nIFRS 15\n\n$\n\n3,436,721\n\nImpact of\nchanges INCORPORATED\n\nNotes to Parent-Company-Only Financial Statements\n\n11\n\nNote  1:  For  certain  contracts,  the  Company  recognizes  revenue  when  it  satisfied a  performance\nobligation but does not have an unconditional right to the considerations. Under IFRS 15,\ncontract  assets  and  revenue  are  recognized  for  such  situation,  different  from  accounts\nreceivable and revenue that would be recognized prior to the adoption of IFRS 15. On the\nother hand, for certain contracts, the Company has received a part of the considerations\nbut does not satisfy its obligations. Under IFRS 15, contract liabilities are recognized for\nsuch situation, different from other payables recognized prior to the adoption of IFRS 15.\n\nNote 2: Prior to the adoption of IFRS 15, rebate payables were recognized under other payables.\n\nUnder IFRS 15, they are recognized under refund liabilities.\n\n(ii)\n\nIFRS 9 Financial Instruments\n\nIFRS 9 replaces IAS 39 Financial Instruments: Recognition and Measurement which contains\nclassification and measurement of financial instruments, impairment, and hedge accounting.\n\nAs a result of the adoption of IFRS 9, the Company adopted the consequential amendments to\nIFRS  7  Financial  Instruments:  Disclosures  that  are  applied  to  disclosures  about  2018  but\ngenerally have not been applied to comparative information.\n\nThe details of new significant accounting policies and the nature and effect of the changes to\nIFRS 9 are as follows:\n\n1)\n\nClassification of financial assets and financial liabilities\n\nIFRS 9 contains three principal classification categories for financial assets: measured at\namortized  cost,  fair  value  through  other  comprehensive  income  (\xe2\x80\x9c FVOCI\xe2\x80\x9d ),  and  fair\nvalue through profit or loss (\xe2\x80\x9cFVTPL\xe2\x80\x9d). The classification of financial assets under IFRS\n9 is generally based on the business model in which financial assets are managed and\ntheir contractual cash flow characteristics. The standard eliminates the previous IAS 39\ncategories of held to maturity, loans and receivables and available-for-sale. Under IFRS\n9, if a hybrid contract contains a host that is within the scope of IFRS 9, the embedded\nderivatives  would  not  be  separated  from  the  host  contract;  instead,  the  entire  hybrid\ncontract is assessed for classification. Please refer to note 4(f) for an explanation of how\nthe Company classifies and measures its financial assets and accounts for related gains\nand losses under IFRS 9.\n\nThe  adoption  of  IFRS  9  did  not  have  any  significant  impact  on  the  Company\xe2\x80\x99 s\naccounting policies on financial liabilities.\n\n2)\n\nImpairment of financial assets\nIFRS 9 replaces the \xe2\x80\x9cincurred loss\xe2\x80\x9d model in IAS 39 with a forward-looking \xe2\x80\x9cexpected\ncredit  loss\xe2\x80\x9d (\xe2\x80\x9c ECL\xe2\x80\x9d )  model.  The  new  impairment  model  applies  to  financial  assets\nmeasured at amortized cost, contract assets, and debt investments at FVOCI, but not to\ninvestments in equity instruments. Under IFRS 9, credit losses are recognized earlier than\nunder IAS 39. Please refer to note 4(f) for more details.\n\n(Continued)\n\n\x0cACER INCORPORATED\n\nNotes to Parent-Company-Only Financial Statements\n\n12\n\n3)\n\nTransition\n\nThe adoption of IFRS 9 has generally been applied retrospectively, except as described\nbelow:\n\xe2\x80\xa7Differences in the carrying amounts of financial assets resulting from the adoption of\nIFRS  9  are  recognized  in  retained  earnings  and  other  equity  on  January  1,  2018.\nAccordingly,  the  information  presented  for  2017  does  not  generally  reflect  the\nrequirements of IFRS 9, and therefore, is not comparable to the information presented\nfor 2018 under IFRS 9.\n\xe2\x80\xa7The following assessments have been made on the basis of the facts and circumstances\nthat existed at the date of initial application.\n\n\xef\xbc\x8dThe determination of the business model within which a financial asset is held.\n\xef\xbc\x8d The  designation  and  revocation  of  financial  assets  and  financial  liabilities\n\npreviously designated as measured at FVTPL.\n\nmeasured at FVOCI.\n\n\xef\xbc\x8d The  designation  of  investments  in  equity  instruments  not  held  for  trading  as\n\xe2\x80\xa7If an investment in a debt security had low credit risk at the date of initial application of\nIFRS 9, the Company shall assume that the credit risk on the asset had no significant\nincrease since its initial recognition.\n\n4)\n\nClassification of financial assets on the date of initial application of IFRS 9\n\nThe following table shows the measurement categories and carrying amounts under IAS\n39 and IFRS 9 for each class of the Company\xe2\x80\x99s financial assets as of January 1, 2018.\nThere  is  no  change  in  measurement  categories  and  carrying  amounts  for  financial\nliabilities.\n\nIAS 39\n\nMeasurement \n\ncategories\n\nCarrying\nAmount\n\nMeasurement\n\ncategories\n\nIFRS 9\n\nCarrying\nAmount\n\nNote\n\nLoans and receivables\n\n$\n\n13,708,705  right  were  previously  categorized  as\ninvestments in debt instrument without an active market amounting to $227,243\nand  financial  asset  measured  at  fair  value  through  profit  or  loss  amounting  to\n$3,033, respectively, under IAS 39. The cash flows of these financial assets are\nnot solely payments of principal and interest on the principal amount outstanding.\nTherefore,  the  Company  has  classified  these  assets  at  the  date  of  initial\napplication of IFRS 9 as mandatorily measured at FVTPL amounting to $281,191,\nand  has  eliminated  the  interest  receivables  amounting  to  $849.  As  a  result,  an\nincrease of $50,066 in retained earnings on January 1, 2018 was recognized.\n\nNote2:These equity instruments represent investments that the Company intends to hold\nfor  long-term  strategic  purposes.  As  permitted  by  IFRS  9,  the  Company  has\ndesignated  these  investments  at  the  date  of  initial  application  as  measured  at\nFVOCI. \n\nNote3: Notes  receivable,  accounts  receivable,  other  receivables  (including  receivables\nfrom related parties) and other financial assets that were previously classified as\nloans  and  receivables  under  IAS  39  are  now  classified  as  financial  assets\nmeasured at amortized cost upon the initial application of IFRS 9. In addition, an\nallowance  for  impairment  of  $1,635  was  recognized  in  retained  earnings  on\nJanuary 1, 2018. \n\nThe following table reconciles the carrying amounts of financial assets under IAS 39 to\nthe carrying amounts under IFRS 9 upon transition to IFRS 9 on January 1, 2018.\n\nFinancial assets measured at FVTPL\n\nBeginning balance of FVTPL (IAS 39)\nAdditions \xe2\x80\x93 debt instruments:\nFrom loans and receivables\n\n(Investments in debt instrument\nwithout an active market and\ninterest receivable)\n\nTotal\n\nFinancial assets measured at FVOCI\n\nBeginning balance (IAS 39)\nAdditions:\n  From available-for-sale\n\nTotal\n\nFinancial assets measured at amortized cost\n\nBeginning balance of cash and cash\nequivalents, investments in debt\ninstrument without an active Financial Statements\n\n14\n\n(iii) Amendments to IAS 7 Disclosure Initiative\n\nThe  amendments  require  disclosures  that  enable  users  of  financial  statements  to  evaluate\nchanges  in  liabilities  arising  from  financing  activities,  including  both  changes  arising  from\ncash flow and non-cash changes.\n\nTo satisfy the new disclosure requirements, the Company presents a reconciliation between the\nbeginning and ending balances for liabilities with changes arising from financing activities in\nnote 6(ac).\n\n(b)\n\nImpact of IFRSs endorsed by the FSC but not yet in effect\n\nAccording to Ruling No. 1070324857 issued by the FSC on July 17, 2018, commencing from 2019,\nthe Company  is required to adopt the IFRSs that have been endorsed by the FSC with effective date\nfrom January 1, 2019. The related new, revised or amended standards and interpretations are set out\nbelow:\n\nNew, Revised or Amended Standards and Interpretations\n\nIFRS 16 Leases\nIFRIC 23 Uncertainty over Income Tax Treatments\nAmendments to IFRS 9 Prepayment features with negative compensation\nAmendments to IAS 19 Plan Amendment, Curtailment or Settlement\nAmendments to IAS 28 Long-term interests in associates and joint ventures\nAnnual Improvements to IFRS Standards 2015\xe2\x80\x932017 Cycle\n\nEffective date\n\nper IASB\n\nJanuary 1, 2019\nJanuary 1, 2019\nJanuary 1, 2019\nJanuary 1, 2019\nJanuary 1, 2019\nJanuary 1, 2019\n\nExcept for the items discussed below, the Company believes that the initial adoption of the above\nIFRSs  would  not  have  any  material  impact  on  its  financial  statements.  The  extent  and  impact  of\nsignification changes are as follows:\n\n(i)\n\nIFRS 16 Leases\n\nIFRS 16 replaces the existing leases guidance, including IAS 17 Leases, IFRIC 4 Determining\nwhether an Arrangement contains a Lease, SIC-15 Operating Leases \xe2\x80\x93 Incentives and SIC-27\nEvaluating the Substance of Transactions Involving the Legal Form of a Lease.\n\nIFRS  16  introduces  a  single  and  an  on-balance  sheet  lease  accounting  model  for  lessees.  A\nlessee recognizes a right-of-use asset representing its right to use the underlying asset and a\nlease  liability  representing  its  obligation  to  make  lease  payments.  In  addition,  the  nature  of\nexpenses related to those leases will now be changed since IFRS 16 replaces the straight-line\noperating lease expense with a depreciation charge for right-of-use assets and interest expense\non lease liabilities. There are recognition exemptions for short-term leases and leases of low-\nvalue items. The lessor accounting remains similar to the current standard \xe2\x80\x93 i.e. the lessors will\ncontinue to classify leases as finance or operating leases.\n\n(Continued)\n\n\x0cACER INCORPORATED\n\nNotes to Parent-Company-Only Financial Statements\n\n15\n\n1)\n\nDetermining whether an arrangement contains a lease\n\n On transition to IFRS 16, the Company can choose to apply either of the following: \n\n\xef\x82\xb7 IFRS 16 definition of lease to all its contracts; or \n\xef\x82\xb7 a  practical  expedient  that  does  not  need  any  reassessment  whether  a  contract  is,  or\n\ncontains, a lease. \n\nThe  Company  plans  to  apply  IFRS  16  definition  of  a  lease  to  all  its  contracts  upon\ntransition.\n\n2)\n\nTransition\n\nAs a lessee, the Company can apply the standard using either of the following: \n\n\xef\x82\xb7 retrospective approach; or \n\xef\x82\xb7 modified retrospective approach with optional practical expedients. \n\nThe Company plans to initially apply IFRS 16 using the modified retrospective approach.\nTherefore, the cumulative effect of adopting IFRS 16 will be recognized as an adjustment\nin the opening balance of retained earnings at January 1, 2019, with no restatement of\ncomparative information. \n\nWhen  applying  the  modified  retrospective  approach  to  leases  previously  classified  as\noperating leases under IAS 17, the lessee can elect, on a lease-by-lease basis, whether to\napply a number of practical expedients on transition. The Company chooses to elect the\nfollowing practical expedients:\n\n\xef\x82\xb7 apply a single discount rate to a portfolio of leases with similar characteristics;\n\xef\x82\xb7 apply  the  exemption,  and  not  to  recognize  the  right-of-use  asset  and  lease  liabilities\n\nwith  lease term that ends within 12 months at the date of initial application;\n\n\xef\x82\xb7 exclude  the  initial  direct  costs  from  measuring  the  right-of-use  asset  at  the  date  of\n\n\xef\x82\xb7 use hindsight to determine the lease term while the contract contains options to extend\n\ninitial application; and\n\nor terminate the lease.\n\n(Continued)\n\n\x0cACER INCORPORATED\n\nNotes to Parent-Company-Only Financial Statements\n\n16\n\n3)\n\nSo far, the most significant impact identified is that the Company will have to recognize\nthe  right-of-use  assets  and  lease  liabilities  for  the  operating  leases  of  its  offices  and\nwarehouses, which will result in an increase of $187,485 in its right-of-use assets and\nlease liabilities on January 1, 2019. Besides, the Company does not expect the adoption\nof  IFRS  16  to  have  any  impact  on  its  ability  to  comply  with  the  maximum  leverage\nthreshold loan covenant. Also, the Company is not required to make any adjustments for\nleases in which the Company is the intermediate lessor in a sub-lease.\n\nThe  actual  impacts  of  adopting  the  amended  standards  and  new  interpretations  may  change\ndepending on the economic conditions and events which may occur in the future.\n\n(c)\n\nImpact of IFRS issued by IASB but not yet endorsed by the FSC\n\nA summary of new and amended standards issued by the IASB but not yet endorsed by the FSC is\nset out below:\n\nNew, Revised or Amended Standards and Interpretations\n\nAmendments to IFRS 3 Definition of a Business\nAmendments to IFRS 10 and IAS 28 Sale or Contribution of Assets Between an\n\nInvestor and Its Associate or Joint Venture\n\nIFRS 17 Insurance Contracts\nAmendments to IAS 1 and IAS 8 Definition of Material\n\nEffective date\n\nper IASB\n\nJanuary 1, 2020\nEffective date to\nbe determined\nby IASB\nJanuary 1, 2021\nJanuary 1, 2020\n\nThose which may be relevant to the Company are set out below:\nIssuance / Release\n\nStandards or\nInterpretations\n\nDates\n\nOctober 31, 2018\n\nAmendments to IAS 1 and IAS\n8 Definition of Material\n\nContent of amendment\n\nfeatured  elsewhere \n\nThe  amendments  clarify  the  definition  of\nmaterial  and  how  it  should  be  applied  by\nincluding in the definition guidance that until\nnow  has \nIFRS\nStandards.  In  addition, \nthe  explanations\naccompanying \nthe  definition  have  been\nimproved.  Finally,  the  amendments  ensure\nthat  the  definition  of  material  is  consistent\nacross all IFRS Standards.\n\nin \n\nThe Company is currently evaluating the impact on its financial position and financial performance\nupon  the  initial  adoption  of  the  abovementioned  standards.  The  results  thereof  will  be  disclosed\nwhen the Company completes its evaluation.\n\n(Continued)\n\n\x0cACER INCORPORATED\n\nNotes to Parent-Company-Only Financial Statements\n\n17\n\n4.\n\nSummary of significant accounting policies\nThe  significant  accounting  policies  presented  in  the  parent-company-only  financial  statements  are\nsummarized  as  follows  and  have  been  applied  consistently  to  all  periods  presented  in  these  financial\nstatements.\n\n(a)\n\nStatement of compliance   \n\nThe  Company\xe2\x80\x99 s  accompanying  parent-company-only  financial  statements  have  been  prepared  in\naccordance  with  the  \xe2\x80\x9c Regulations  Governing  the  Preparation  of  Financial  Reports  by  Securities\nIssuers\xe2\x80\x9d.\n\n(b) Basis of preparation\n\n(i)\n\nBasis of measurement\n\nThe  accompanying  parent-company-only  financial  statements  have  been  prepared  on  a\nhistorical cost basis except for the following items:\n\n1)\n\n2)\n\n3)\n\nFinancial instruments measured at fair value through profit or loss (including derivative\nfinancial instruments);\nFinancial assets measured at fair value through other comprehensive income (Available-\nfor-sale financial assets measured at fair value); and\nNet defined benefit liability measured at present value of defined benefit obligation less\nthe fair value of plan assets.\n\n(ii) Functional and presentation currency\n\nThe  functional  currency  of  the  Company  is  determined  based  on  the  primary  economic\nenvironment in which the Company operates. The Company\xe2\x80\x99s parent-company-only financial\nstatements are presented in New Taiwan dollars, which is the Company\xe2\x80\x99s functional currency.\nExcept when otherwise indicated, all financial information presented in New Taiwan dollars\nhas been rounded to the nearest thousand.\n\n(c)\n\nForeign currency\n\n(i)\n\nForeign currency transactions\n\nForeign currency transactions are translated into the functional currency using the exchange\nrates prevailing at the dates of the transactions. Foreign exchange gains and losses resulting\nfrom the settlement of such transactions and from the translation at exchange rates at the end\nof the period (the \xe2\x80\x9creporting date\xe2\x80\x9d) of monetary assets and liabilities denominated in foreign\ncurrencies are recognized in profit or loss.\n\n(Continued)\n\n\x0cACER INCORPORATED\n\nNotes to Parent-Company-Only Financial Statements\n\n18\n\nNon-monetary assets and liabilities denominated in foreign currencies that are measured at fair\nvalue  are  retranslated  at  the  exchange  rate  prevailing  at  the  date  when  the  fair  value  is\ndetermined.  Exchange  differences  arising  on  the  translation  of  non-monetary  items  are\nrecognized in profit or loss, except for exchange differences arising on the retranslation of non-\nmonetary  items  in  respect  of  which  gains  and  losses  are  recognized  directly  in  other\ncomprehensive income, in which case, the exchange differences are also recognized directly in\nother comprehensive income. Non-monetary items denominated in foreign currencies that are\nmeasured at historical cost are not retranslated.\n\n(ii) Foreign operations\n\nThe assets and liabilities of foreign operations, including goodwill and fair value adjustments\narising from acquisition, are translated into the presentation currency of the Company\xe2\x80\x99s parent-\ncompany-only financial statements at the exchange rates at the reporting date. The income and\nexpenses of foreign operations, excluding foreign operations in hyperinflationary economies,\nare translated into the presentation currency of the Company\xe2\x80\x99s parent-company-only financial\nstatements at the average exchange rates for the period. All resulting exchange differences are\nrecognized in other comprehensive income.\n\nOn the disposal of a foreign operation which involves a loss of control over a subsidiary or loss\nof significant influence over an associate that includes a foreign operation, all of the exchange\ndifferences accumulated in equity in respect of that operation attributable to the shareholders\nof the Company are entirely reclassified to profit or loss.  In the case of a partial disposal that\ndoes  not  result  in  the  Company  losing  control  over  a  subsidiary,  the  proportionate  share  of\naccumulated  exchange  differences  is  reclassified  to  non-controlling  interests.  For  a  partial\ndisposal  of  the  Company\xe2\x80\x99 s  ownership  interest  in  an  associate  or  joint  venture,  the\nproportionate share of the accumulated exchange differences in equity is reclassified to profit\nor loss.\n\nWhen the settlement of a monetary receivable from or payable to a foreign operation is neither\nplanned nor likely to occur in the foreseeable future, the monetary item is, in substance, a part\nof net investment in that foreign operation, and the related foreign exchange gains and losses\nthereon are recognized as other comprehensive income.\n\n(d) Classification of current and non-current assets and liabilities\n\nAn  asset  is  classified  as  current  when  one  of  the  following  criteria  is  met;  all  other  assets  are\nclassified as non-current assets:\n\nIt is expected to be realized, or intended to be sold or consumed in the normal operating cycle;\nIt is held primarily for the purpose of trading;\nIt is expected to be realized within twelve months after the reporting period; or \n\n(i)\n(ii)\n(iii)\n(iv) The asset is cash or a cash equivalent unless the asset is restricted from being exchanged or\n\nused to settle a liability for at least twelve months after the reporting period.\n\nA liability is classified as current when one of the following criteria is met; all other liabilities are\nclassified as non-current liabilities:\n\n(i)\n(ii)\n(iii)\n\nIt is expected to be settled in the normal operating cycle;\nIt is held primarily for the purpose of trading;\nIt is due to be settled within twelve months after the reporting period; or \n\n(Continued)\n\n\x0cACER INCORPORATED\n\nNotes to Parent-Company-Only Financial Statements\n\n19\n\n(iv) The Company does not have an unconditional right to defer settlement of the liability for at\nleast twelve months after the reporting period. Terms of a liability that could, at the option of\nthe  counterparty,  result  in  its  settlement  by  issuing  equity  instruments  do  not  affect  its\nclassification.\n\n(e) Cash and cash equivalents\n\nCash consists of cash on hand, checking deposits, and demand deposits.  Cash equivalents consist of\nshort-term and highly liquid investments that are readily convertible to known amounts of cash and\nare subject to an insignificant risk of changes in value.  Time deposits that meet the aforesaid criteria\nand are not held for investing purposes are also classified as cash equivalents.\n\nBank  overdrafts  that  are  repayable  on  demand  and  form  an  integral  part  of  the  Company\xe2\x80\x99 s  cash\nmanagement  are  included  as  a  component  of  cash  and  cash  equivalents  for  the  purpose  of  the\nstatement of cash flows.\n\n(f)\n\nFinancial instruments\n\n(i)\n\nFinancial assets (applicable commencing January 1, 2018)\n\nFinancial assets are classified into the following categories: measured at amortized cost, fair\nvalue through other comprehensive income (\xe2\x80\x9cFVOCI\xe2\x80\x9d), and fair value through profit or loss\n(\xe2\x80\x9cFVTPL\xe2\x80\x9d). A regular way purchase or sale of financial assets is recognized and derecognized\non a trade-date basis.\n\nThe Company shall reclassify all affected financial assets only when it changes its business\nmodel for managing its financial assets.\n\n1)\n\nFinancial assets measured at amortized cost\n\nA  financial  asset  is  measured  at  amortized  cost  if  it  meets  both  of  the  following\nconditions and is not designated as at FVTPL:\n\n\xef\x82\xb7 it is held within a business model whose objective is to hold financial assets to collect\n\ncontractual cash flows; and\n\n\xef\x82\xb7 its contractual terms give rise on specified dates to cash flows that are solely payments\n\nof principal and interest on the principal amount outstanding.\n\nA financial asset measured at amortized cost is initially recognized at fair value, plus any\ndirectly  attributable  transaction  costs.  These  assets  are  subsequently  measured  at\namortized cost using the effective interest method, less any impairment losses. Interest\nincome, foreign exchange gains and losses, and recognition (reversal) of impairment loss,\nare recognized in profit or loss. Any gain or loss on derecognition is recognized in profit\nor loss.\n\n(Continued)\n\n\x0cACER INCORPORATED\n\nNotes to Parent-Company-Only Financial Statements\n\n20\n\n2)\n\nFinancial assets measured at fair value through other comprehensive income \n\nA debt investment is measured at FVOCI if it meets both of the following conditions and\nis not designated as at FVTPL:\n\n\xef\x82\xb7 it  is  held  within  a  business  model  whose  objective  is  achieved  by  both  collecting\n\ncontractual cash flows and selling financial assets; and\n\n\xef\x82\xb7 its contractual terms give rise on specified dates to cash flows that are solely payments\n\nof principal and interest on the principal amount outstanding.\n\nOn initial recognition of an equity investment that is not held for trading, the Company\nmay  irrevocably  elect  to  present  subsequent  changes  in  the  investment\xe2\x80\x99 s  fair  value  in\nother  comprehensive  income.  This  election  is  made  on  an  instrument-by-instrument\nbasis.\n\nA  financial  asset  measured  at  FVOCI  is  initially  recognized  at  fair  value,  plus  any\ndirectly  attributable  transaction  costs.  These  assets  are  subsequently  measured  at  fair\nvalue. Foreign exchange gains and losses, interest income calculated using the effective\ninterest method, and impairment losses deriving from debt investments, are recognized in\nprofit  or  loss;  whereas  dividends  deriving  from  equity  investments  are  recognized  in\nprofit or loss, unless the dividend clearly represents a recovery of part of the cost of an\ninvestment. Other changes in the carrying amount of financial assets measured at FVOCI\nare  recognized  in  other  comprehensive  income  and  accumulated  in  other  equity  as\nunrealized  gain  (loss)  from  financial  assets  measured  at  fair  value  through  other\ncomprehensive income. On derecognition, gains and losses accumulated in other equity\nof  debt  investments  are  reclassified  to  profit  or  loss.  However,  gains  and  losses\naccumulated  in  other equity of equity investments are reclassified to retained earnings\ninstead of profit or loss.\n\nDividend  income  derived  from  equity  investments  is  recognized  on  the  date  that  the\nCompany\xe2\x80\x99s right to receive the dividends is established (usually the ex-dividend date).\n\n3)\n\nFinancial assets measured at fair value through profit or loss \n\nAll financial assets not classified as measured at amortized cost or at FVOCI described\nas  above  are  measured  at  FVTPL,  including  derivative  financial  assets  and  non-\nderivative financial assets (e.g., convertible bond). On initial recognition, the Company\nmay  irrevocably  designate  a  financial  asset,  which  meets  the  requirements  to  be\nmeasured  at  amortized  cost  or  at  FVOCI,  as  at  FVTPL  if  doing  so  eliminates  or\nsignificantly reduces an accounting mismatch that would otherwise arise.\n\nFinancial  assets  in  this  category  are  initially  recognized  at  fair  value.  Attributable\ntransaction  costs  are  recognized  in  profit  or  loss  as  incurred.  Subsequent  to  initial\nrecognition, they are measured at fair value, any changes therein, including any dividend\nand interest income, are recognized in profit or loss.\n\n(Continued)\n\n\x0cACER INCORPORATED\n\nNotes to Parent-Company-Only Financial Statements\n\n4)\n\nImpairment of financial assets\n\n21\n\nThe Company recognizes loss allowances for expected credit losses on financial assets\nmeasured  at  amortized  cost  (including  cash  and  cash  equivalents,  notes  and  accounts\nreceivable, other receivables, and other financial assets) and contract assets.\n\nThe  Company  measures  loss  allowances  for  accounts  receivable,  contract  assets  and\nother financial assets at an amount equal to lifetime expected credit loss (\xe2\x80\x9cECL\xe2\x80\x9d), except\nfor the following financial assets which are measured using 12-month ECL:\n\n\xef\x82\xb7 debt securities that are determined to have low credit risk at the reporting date; and\n\xef\x82\xb7 other  debt  securities  and  bank  balances  for  which credit risk (i.e. the risk of default\noccurring  over  the  expected  life  of  the  financial  instrument)  has  not  increased\nsignificantly since initial recognition.\n\nLifetime ECLs are the ECLs that result from all possible default events over the expected\nlife of a financial instrument. 12-month ECLs are the portion of ECLs that result from\ndefault events that are possible within the 12 months after the reporting date (or a shorter\nperiod if the expected life of the instrument is less than 12 months).\n\nThe  maximum  period  considered  when  estimating  ECLs  is  the  maximum  contractual\nperiod over which the Company is exposed to credit risk.\n\nWhen determining whether the credit risk of a financial asset has increased significantly\nsince initial recognition, the Company considers reasonable and supportable information\nthat is relevant and available without undue cost or effort. The information includes both\nquantitative and qualitative information and analysis based on the Company\xe2\x80\x99s historical\nexperience and credit assessment, as well as forward-looking information.\n\nECLs  are  probability-weighted  estimate  of  credit  losses  over  the  expected  life  of\nfinancial assets. Credit losses are measured as the present value of all cash shortfalls (i.e.,\nthe  difference  between  the  cash  flows  due  to  the  Company  in  accordance  with  the\ncontract and the cash flows that the Company expects to receive). ECLs are discounted at\nthe effective interest rate of the financial asset.\n\nLoss allowances for financial assets measured at amortized cost are deducted from the\ngross carrying amount of the assets. The recognition or reversal of the loss allowance is\nrecognized in profit or loss.\n\nThe gross carrying amount of a financial asset is written off, either partially or in full, to\nthe extent that there is no realistic prospect of recovery. This is generally the case when\nthe Company determines that the debtor does not have assets or sources of income that\ncould  generate  sufficient  cash  flows  to  repay  the  amounts  subject  to  the  write-off.\nHowever,  financial  assets  that  are  written  off  could  still  be  subject  to  enforcement\nactivities  in  order  to  comply  with  the  Company\xe2\x80\x99s procedures for recovery of amounts\ndue.\n\n(Continued)\n\n\x0c22\n\nACER INCORPORATED\n\nNotes to Parent-Company-Only Financial Statements\n\n5)\n\nDerecognition of financial assets\n\nFinancial assets are derecognized when the contractual rights of the cash inflow from the\nassets  are  terminated,  or  when  the  Company  transfers  substantially  all  the  risks  and\nrewards of ownership of the financial assets to other enterprises.\n\nOn derecognition of a debt instrument in its entirety, the difference between the carrying\namount and the sum of the consideration received or receivable and any cumulative gain\nor  loss  that  had  been  recognized  in  other  comprehensive  income  and  accumulated  in\n\xe2\x80\x9cother equity\xe2\x80\x93unrealized gain (loss) from financial assets measured at fair value through\nother  comprehensive  income\xe2\x80\x9d   is  recognized  in  profit  or  loss,  and  included  in  non-\noperating income and loss.\n\nOn derecognition of a debt instrument other than in its entirety, the Company allocates\nthe  previous  carrying  amount  of  the  debt  instrument  between  the  part  it  continues  to\nrecognize under continuing involvement, and the part it no longer recognizes on the basis\nof  the  relative  fair  values  of  those  parts  on  the  date  of  the  transfer.  The  difference\nbetween the carrying amount allocated to the part that is no longer recognized and the\nsum of the consideration received or receivable for the part no longer recognized and any\ncumulative gain or loss allocated to it that had been recognized in other comprehensive\nincome is recognized in profit or loss, and included in non-operating income and loss. A\ncumulative  gain  or  loss  that  had  been  recognized  in  other  comprehensive  income  is\nallocated between the part that continues to be recognized and the part that is no longer\nrecognized on the basis of the relative fair values of those parts.\n\n(ii) Financial assets (applicable before January 1, 2018)\n\nFinancial  assets  are  classified  into  the  following  categories:  financial  assets  at  fair  value\nthrough profit or loss, loans and receivables, and available-for-sale financial assets. A regular\nway purchase or sale of financial assets is recognized or derecognized on a trade-date basis. \n\n1)\n\nFinancial assets at fair value through profit or loss \n\nFinancial  assets  at  fair  value  through  profit  or  loss consist of financial assets held for\ntrading  and  those  designated  as  at  fair  value  through  profit  or  loss  at  inception.  A\nfinancial  asset  is  classified  in  this  category  if  acquired  principally  for  the  purpose  of\nselling in the short term. Derivatives are also categorized as financial assets at fair value\nthrough  profit  or  loss  unless  they  are  designated  as  hedges.  The  Company  designates\nfinancial assets, other than ones classified as held for trading, as at fair value through\nprofit or loss at initial recognition under one of the following situations:\n\xe2\x80\xa7 Such  designation  eliminates  or  significantly  reduces  a  measurement  or  recognition\ninconsistency  that  would  otherwise  arise  from  measuring  assets  or  liabilities  or\nrecognizing the gains and losses on them on a different basis;\n\xe2\x80\xa7Performance of the financial asset is evaluated on a fair value basis;\n\xe2\x80\xa7A hybrid instrument contains one or more embedded derivatives.\n\n(Continued)\n\n\x0cACER INCORPORATED\n\nNotes to Parent-Company-Only Financial Statements\n\n23\n\nAt  initial  recognition,  financial  assets  carried  at  fair  value  through  profit  or  loss  are\nrecognized at fair value. Any attributable transaction costs are recognized in profit or loss\nas  incurred.  Subsequent  to  the  initial  recognition,  changes  in  fair  value  (including\ndividend  income  and  interest  income)  are  recognized  in  profit  or  loss  and  included  in\nnon-operating income and loss. \n\n2)\n\nLoans and receivables\n\nLoans  and  receivables  are  non-derivative  financial  assets  with  fixed  or  determinable\npayments  that  are  not  quoted  in  an  active  market.  Loans  and  receivables  comprise\naccounts  receivable,  other  receivables  and  investments  in  debt  instrument  without  an\nactive  market.
