At  initial  recognition,  such  assets  are  recognized  at  fair  value  plus  any\ndirectly  attributable  transaction  costs.  Subsequent  to  initial  recognition,  loans  and\nreceivables  other  than  insignificant  interest  on  short-term  receivables  are  measured  at\namortized  cost  using  the  effective  interest  method  less  any  impairment losses. Interest\nincome is recognized as non-operating income in profit or loss.\n\n3)\n\nAvailable-for sale financial assets\n\nAvailable-for-sale financial assets are non-derivative financial assets that are designated\nas available for sale or are not classified in any of the other categories of financial assets.\nAt initial recognition, available-for-sale financial assets are recognized at fair value plus\nany directly attributable transaction costs. Subsequent to initial recognition, these assets\nare  measured  at  fair  value,  and  changes therein, other than impairment losses, interest\nincome  calculated  using  the  effective  interest  method,  dividend  income,  and  foreign\ncurrency differences on monetary financial assets, are recognized in other comprehensive\nincome and accumulated in other equity as unrealized gain (loss) from available-for-sale\nfinancial  assets.  When  the  financial  asset  is  derecognized,  the  gain  or  loss  previously\naccumulated in equity is reclassified to profit or loss. \n\nDividends received from equity investments are recognized as non-operating income on\nthe date of entitlement to receive the dividends (usually the ex-dividend date).\n\n4)\n\nImpairment of financial assets\n\nFinancial assets, other than those carried at fair value through profit or loss, are assessed\nfor indicators of impairment at the end of each reporting period. Those financial assets\nare considered to be impaired when there is objective evidence that, as a result of one or\nmore  events  that  occurred  after  the  initial  recognition  of  the  financial  assets,  their\nestimated future cash flows have been affected. \n\nEvidence  of  impairment  may  include  indications  that  the  debtor  is  experiencing\nsignificant financial difficulty, default or delinquency in interest or principal payments,\nindications  that  the  debtor  or  issuer  will  probably  enter  bankruptcy  or  other  financial\nreorganization, and the disappearance of an active market for that financial asset because\nof  financial  difficulties.  For  available-for-sale  equity  investments,  a  significant  or\nprolonged decline in the fair value of the security below its cost is also evidence that the\nassets are impaired. \n\n(Continued)\n\n\x0cACER INCORPORATED\n\nNotes to Parent-Company-Only Financial Statements\n\n24\n\nIf  the  Company  determines  that  no  objective  evidence  of  impairment  exists  for  an\nindividually  assessed  account  receivable,  whether  significant  or  not,  such  account\nreceivable  is  included  in  a  group  of  accounts  receivable  with  similar  credit  risk\ncharacteristics which are then collectively assessed for impairment.  Objective evidence\nthat receivables are impaired includes the Company\xe2\x80\x99s collection experience in the past,\nan increase of delayed payments, and national or local economic conditions that correlate\nwith arrears of receivables.\n\nAn  impairment  loss  is  recognized  by  reducing  the  carrying  amount  of  the  respective\nfinancial assets with the exception of receivables, where the carrying amount is reduced\nthrough  an  allowance  account.  Except  for  the  write-off  of  uncollectible  receivables\nagainst  the  allowance  account,  changes  in  the  amount  of  the  allowance  account  are\nrecognized in profit or loss.\n\nAn impairment loss in respect of a financial asset measured at amortized cost is measured\nas the excess of the asset\xe2\x80\x99s carrying amount over the present value of the estimated future\ncash  flows  discounted  at  the  financial  asset\xe2\x80\x99 s  original  effective  interest  rate.  If,  in  a\nsubsequent period, the amount of the impairment loss decreases and the decrease can be\nrelated  objectively  to  an  event  occurring  after  the  impairment  was  recognized,  the\npreviously recognized impairment loss is reversed to the extent that the carrying amount\nof the financial assets at the date the impairment loss is reversed does not exceed what\nthe amortized cost would have been had the impairment loss not been recognized.\n\nWhen  an  impairment  loss  is  recognized  for  an  available-for-sale  asset,  the  cumulative\ngains  or  loss  that  had  been  recognized  in  other  comprehensive  income  is  reclassified\nfrom equity to profit or loss. Any subsequent recovery in the fair value of an impaired\navailable-for-sale  equity  security  is  recognized  in  other  comprehensive  income,  and\naccumulated  in  other  equity.  If,  in  a  subsequent  period,  the  fair  value  of  an  impaired\navailable-for-sale debt security increases and the increase can be related objectively to an\nevent  occurring  after  the  impairment  loss  was  recognized,  then  the  impairment  loss  is\nreversed, with the amount of the reversal recognized in profit or loss. \n\nImpairment  losses  and  recoveries  of  accounts  receivable  are  recognized  as  operating\nexpenses.  Impairment  losses  and  recoveries  of  other  financial assets are recognized as\nother gains and losses under non-operating income and loss.\n\n5)\n\nDerecognition of financial assets\n\nFinancial assets are derecognized when the contractual rights of the cash inflow from the\nasset are terminated, or when the Company transfers out substantially all the risks and\nrewards of ownership of the financial assets to other enterprises.\n\nOn derecognition of a financial asset in its entirety, the difference between the carrying\namount and the sum of the consideration received or receivable and any cumulative gain\nor  loss  that  had  been  recognized  in  other  comprehensive  income  and  accumulated  in\n\xe2\x80\x9c other  equity  \xe2\x80\x93   unrealized  gain  (loss)  from  available-for-sale  financial  assets\xe2\x80\x9d   is\nrecognized in profit or loss, and included in non-operating income and loss.\n\n(Continued)\n\n\x0c25\n\nACER INCORPORATED\n\nNotes to Parent-Company-Only Financial Statements\n\nOn  derecognition  of  part  of  a  financial  asset,  the  previous  carrying  amount  of  the\nfinancial asset shall be allocated between the part that continues to be recognized and the\npart that is derecognized, on the basis of relative fair values of those parts on the date of\ntransfer. The difference between the carrying amount allocated to the part derecognized\nand the sum of the consideration received or receivable for the part of the financial asset\nderecognized  and  the  cumulative  gain  or  loss  that  has  been  recognized  in  other\ncomprehensive income allocated to the part derecognized is charged to profit or loss and\nincluded  in  non-operating  income  and  loss.  A  cumulative  gain  or  loss  that  had  been\nrecognized in other comprehensive income is allocated between the part that continues to\nbe recognized and the part that is derecognized, based on the relative fair values of those\nparts.\n\n(iii) Financial liabilities and equity instruments\n\n1)\n\nClassification of debt or equity\n\nDebt or equity instruments issued by the Company are classified as financial liabilities or\nequity  in  accordance  with  the  substance  of  the  contractual  agreement.  An  equity\ninstrument is any contract that evidences a residual interest in the assets of the Company\nafter deducting all of its liabilities. Equity instruments are recognized at the amount of\nconsideration received less the direct issuing cost.\n\nInterest and gain or loss related to the financial liability are recognized in profit or loss\nand included in non-operating income and loss.\n\n2)\n\nFinancial liabilities measured at fair value through profit or loss\n\nA financial liability is classified in this category if it is classified as held for trading or is\ndesignated as a financial liability measured at fair value through profit or loss on initial\nrecognition.  A  financial  liability  is  classified  as  held  for  trading  if  it  is  acquired\nprincipally for the purpose of selling or repurchasing in the short term.  Derivatives are\nalso categorized as financial liabilities at fair value through profit or loss unless they are\ndesignated  as  hedges.    The  Company  designates  financial  liabilities,  other  than  those\nclassified as held for trading, as measured at fair value through profit or loss at initial\nrecognition under one of the following situations:\n\xe2\x80\xa7 Such  designation  eliminates  or  significantly  reduces  a  measurement  or  recognition\ninconsistency  that  would  otherwise  arise  from  measuring  assets  or  liabilities  or\nrecognizing the gains and losses on them on a different basis;\n\xe2\x80\xa7Performance of the financial liabilities is evaluated on a fair value basis; \n\xe2\x80\xa7A hybrid instrument contains one or more embedded derivatives.\nAt  initial  recognition,  the  financial  liability  is  recognized  at  fair  value,  and  any\nattributable  transaction  costs  are  recognized  in  profit  or  loss  as  incurred.  Subsequent\nchanges that are measured at fair value, which take into account any interest expense, are\nrecognized in profit or loss and included in non-operating income and loss.\n\n(Continued)\n\n\x0cACER INCORPORATED\n\nNotes to Parent-Company-Only Financial Statements\n\n26\n\n3)\n\nFinancial liabilities measured at amortized cost\n\nFinancial liabilities not classified as held for trading or not designated as at fair value\nthrough profit or loss, which comprise loans and borrowings, accounts payable, and other\npayables,  are  measured  at  fair  value  plus  any  directly  attributable  transaction  costs  at\ninitial  recognition.  Subsequent  to  initial  recognition,  these  financial  liabilities  are\nmeasured at amortized cost using the effective interest method. \n\n4)\n\nDerecognition of financial liabilities\n\nThe Company derecognizes a financial liability when its contractual obligation has been\nfulfilled or cancelled, or has expired. The difference between the carrying amount of a\nfinancial liability derecognized and the consideration paid (including any non-cash assets\ntransferred  or  liabilities  assumed)  is  recognized  in  profit  or  loss  and  included  in  non-\noperating income and loss.\n\n5)\n\nOffsetting of financial assets and liabilities \n\nFinancial assets and liabilities are presented on a net basis only when the Company has\nthe  legally  enforceable  right  to  offset  and  intends  to  settle  such  financial  assets  and\nliabilities on a net basis or to realize the assets and settle the liabilities simultaneously.\n\n(iv) Derivative  financial  instruments  and  hedge  accounting  (applicable  commencing  January  1,\n\n2018) \n\nThe Company uses derivative financial instruments to hedge its foreign currency and interest\nrate  exposures.  Derivatives  are  initially  measured  at  fair  value.  Any  attributable  transaction\ncosts  thereof  are  recognized  in  profit  or  loss  as  incurred.  Subsequent  to  initial  recognition,\nderivatives are measured at fair value, and changes therein are recognized in profit or loss and\nincluded  in  non-operating  income  and  loss,  unless  the  derivative  financial  instruments  are\ndesignated as effective hedging instruments, in which the timing of the recognition in profit or\nloss depends on the nature of the hedge relationship. If the valuation of a derivative instrument\nresults in a positive fair value, it is classified as a financial asset; otherwise, it is classified as a\nfinancial liability.\n\nEmbedded derivatives are separated from the host contract and accounted for separately if the\neconomic  characteristics  and  risks  of  the  host  contract  that  is  a  non-financial  asset  are  not\nclosely related to the embedded derivatives and the host contract is not measured at FVTPL.\n\nCertain derivatives are designated as either (i) hedges of the fair value of recognized assets or\nliabilities (fair value hedge) or (ii) hedges of highly probable forecast transactions (cash flow\nhedge).  The Group documents, at the inception of the transaction, the relationship between\nhedging instruments and hedged items, as well as its risk management objectives and strategy\nfor  undertaking  various  hedging  transactions.  The  Group  also  documents  its  assessment  of\nwhether the derivatives used in hedging transactions are highly effective in offsetting changes\nin fair value or cash flows of hedged items.\n\nThe  Company  shall  discontinue  hedge  accounting  prospectively  only  when  the  hedging\nrelationship (or a part of a hedging relationship) ceases to meet the qualifying criteria (after\n\n(Continued)\n\n\x0cACER INCORPORATED\n\nNotes to Parent-Company-Only Financial Statements\n\n27\n\ntaking into account any rebalancing of the hedging relationship, if applicable). This includes\ninstances when the hedging instrument expires or is sold, terminated or exercised.\n\n1)\n\nFair value hedge\n\nChanges in the fair value of a hedging instrument that is qualified as a fair value hedge\nare  recognized  in  profit  or  loss  (or  other  comprehensive  income,  if  the  hedging\ninstrument hedges an equity instrument measured at FVOCI). \n\n2)\n\nCash flow hedge\n\nWhen  a  derivative  is  designated  and  qualified  as  a  cash  flow  hedging  instrument,  the\neffective  portion  of  changes  in  the  fair  value  is  recognized  in  other  comprehensive\nincome and accumulated in \xe2\x80\x9cother equity \xe2\x80\x94 gains (losses) on hedging instruments\xe2\x80\x9d, and\nis limited to the cumulative change in fair value of the hedged item from inception of the\nhedge. Any ineffective portion of changes in the fair value of the derivative is recognized\nimmediately in profit or loss, and included in non-operating income and loss.\n\nAmounts  previously  recognized  in  other  comprehensive  income  and  accumulated  in\nequity  are  reclassified  to  profit  or  loss  in  the  same  periods  when  the  hedged  item  is\nrecognized in profit or loss, and are included in the same account in the statements of\ncomprehensive income as the hedged item.\n\n(v) Derivative financial instruments and hedge accounting (applicable before January 1, 2018) \n\nExcept  for  the  following  items,  the  Company  applied  the  same  accounting  policies  as\napplicable commencing January 1, 2018.\n\nEmbedded derivatives are separated from the host contract and accounted for separately if the\neconomic characteristics and risk of the host contract are not closely related to the embedded\nderivatives and the host contract is not measured at FVTPL.\n\nFor all cash flow hedges including hedges of expected transactions recognized in non-financial\nassets  or  non-financial  liabilities,  amounts  previously  recognized  in  other  comprehensive\nincome, and accumulated in equity, are reclassified to profit or loss in the same periods when\nexpected cash flow of hedged items are recognized in profit or loss. In addition, for the cash\nflow  hedge  that  is  discontinuing  before  January  1,  2018,  changes  in  fair  value  of  forward\nposition are recognized in profit or loss.\n\n(g)\n\nInventories\n\nInventories are measured at the lower of cost and net realizable value. Inventories are recorded at\nstandard cost and adjusted to approximate weighted-average cost at the end of the reporting period.\nNet realizable value represents the estimated selling price in the ordinary course of business, less all\nestimated costs of completion and necessary selling expenses.\n\n(h)\n\nInvestments in associates and interests in joint venture\n\nAn  associate  is  an  entity  over  which  the  Company  has  significant  influence  and  that  is  neither  a\nsubsidiary nor a joint venture. Significant influence is the power to participate in the financial and\noperating policy decisions of the investee but is not control or joint control over those policies.\n\n(Continued)\n\n\x0cACER INCORPORATED\n\nNotes to Parent-Company-Only Financial Statements\n\n28\n\nA joint venture is a joint arrangement whereby the Company and other parties that have joint control\nof  the  arrangement  have  rights  to  the  net  assets  of  the  joint  arrangement.  Joint  control  is  the\ncontractually agreed sharing of control of an arrangement, which exists only when decisions about\nthe relevant activities require unanimous consent of the parties sharing control. \n\nThe operating results as well as assets and liabilities of associates and joint venture are incorporated\nin these financial statements using the equity method of accounting. Under the equity method, an\ninvestment in an associate or a joint venture is initially recognized in the balance sheet at cost, and\nadjusted  thereafter,  to  recognize  the  Company\xe2\x80\x99 s  share  of  profit  or  loss  and  other  comprehensive\nincome (loss) of the associate and joint venture, as well as the distribution received. The Company\nalso recognizes its share in the changes in the equities of associates and joint venture.\n\nAny  excess  of  the  cost  of  acquisition  over  the  Company\xe2\x80\x99 s  share  of  the  net  fair  value  of  the\nidentifiable  assets  and  liabilities  of  an  associate  or  a  joint  venture  recognized  at  the  date  of\nacquisition,  is  recognized  as  goodwill,  which  is  included  within  the  carrying  amount  of  the\ninvestment. Any excess of the Company\xe2\x80\x99s share of the net fair value of the identifiable assets and\nliabilities over the cost of acquisition, after reassessment, is recognized immediately in profit or loss.\n\nWhen  necessary,  the  entire  carrying  amount  of  the  investment  (including  goodwill)  is  tested  for\nimpairment as a single asset by comparing its recoverable amount (higher of value in use and fair\nvalue, less, costs to sell) with its carrying amount. Any impairment loss recognized forms part of the\ncarrying amount of the investment. Any reversal of that impairment loss is recognized to the extent\nthat the recoverable amount of the investment subsequently increases.\n\nThe  Company  discontinues  the  use  of  equity  method  from the date when the Company ceases to\nhave significant influence over an associate. When the Company retains an interest in the former\nassociate,  the  Company  measures  the  retained  interest  at  fair  value  at  that  date.  The  difference\nbetween the carrying amount of the associate at the date the equity method was discontinued, and the\nfair value of any retained interest and any proceeds from disposing of a part interest in the associate,\nis  included  in  the  determination  of  the  gain  or  loss  on  disposal  of  the  associate.  In  addition,  the\nCompany shall account for all amounts recognized in other comprehensive income in relation to that\nassociate on the same basis as would be required if the associate had directly disposed of the related\nassets or liabilities. If the Company\xe2\x80\x99s ownership interest in an associate is reduced as a result of\ndisposal,  with  the  investment  continues  to  be  an associate, the Company should reclassify only a\nproportionate amount of the gain or loss previously recognized in other comprehensive income to\nprofit or loss.\n\nWhen the Company subscribes to additional shares in an associate or a joint venture at a percentage\ndifferent  from  its  existing  ownership  percentage,  the  resulting  carrying  amount  of  the  investment\ndiffers from the amount of the Company\xe2\x80\x99s proportionate interest in the net assets of the associate or\njoint  venture.  The  Company  records  such  a  difference  as  an  adjustment  to  investments  with  the\ncorresponding amount charged or credited to capital surplus. If the Company\xe2\x80\x99s ownership interest is\nreduced  due  to  the  additional  subscription  to  the  shares  of  associate  or  joint  venture  by  other\ninvestors,  the  proportionate  amount  of  the  gains  or  losses  previously  recognized  in  other\ncomprehensive income in relation to that associate or joint venture shall be reclassified to profit or\nloss on the same basis as would be required if the associate or joint venture had directly disposed of\nthe related assets or liabilities.\n\n(Continued)\n\n\x0cACER INCORPORATED\n\nNotes to Parent-Company-Only Financial Statements\n\n29\n\nUnrealized  profits  resulting  from  transactions  between  the  Company  and  an  associate  or  joint\nventure  are  eliminated  to  the  extent  of  the  Company\xe2\x80\x99 s  interest  in  the  associate  or  joint  venture.\nUnrealized losses on transactions with associates or joint venture are eliminated in the same way,\nexcept to the extent that the underlying asset is impaired.\n\nAdjustments  are  made  to  associates\xe2\x80\x99   and  joint  ventures\xe2\x80\x99   financial  statements  to  conform  to  the\naccounting polices applied by the Company. \n\n(i)\n\nInvestments in subsidiaries\n\nWhen preparing the parent-company-only financial statements, investment in subsidiaries which are\ncontrolled  by  the  Company  is  accounted  for  using  the  equity  method.  Carrying  amount  of\ninvestments in subsidiaries includes goodwill arising from initial recognition less any accumulated\nimpairment losses, which is recognized as a reduction of carry amount. Under equity method, profit\nor loss and other comprehensive income recognized in parent-company-only financial statement is\nthe  same  as  total  comprehensive  income  attributable  to  shareholders  of  the  Company  in  the\nconsolidated financial statements. In addition, changes in equity recognized in parent-company-only\nfinancial  statement  is  the  same  as  changes  in  equity  attributable  to  owners  of  parent  in  the\nconsolidated financial statements. Changes in a parent\xe2\x80\x99s ownership interest in a subsidiary that do\nnot result in the loss of control are accounted for within equity.\n\nThe Company uses acquisition method for acquisitions of new subsidiaries. Goodwill is measured at\nthe  excess  of  the  acquisition-date  fair  value  of  consideration  transferred  (including  any  non-\ncontrolling interest in the acquiree) over the net of the acquisition-date amounts of the identifiable\nassets acquired and liabilities assumed (generally at fair value). If the residual balance is negative,\nthe  Company  shall  re-assess  whether  it  has  correctly  identified  all  of  the  assets  acquired  and\nliabilities assumed and recognize any additional assets or liabilities that are identified in that review,\nand shall recognize a gain on the bargain purchase thereafter. For each acquisition, non-controlling\ninterest  in  the  acquiree  is  measured  either  at  fair  value  or  at  the  non-controlling  interest\xe2\x80\x99 s\nproportionate share of the fair value of the acquiree\xe2\x80\x99s identifiable net assets.\n\nIn an acquisition of new subsidiary achieved in batches, the previously held equity interest in the\nacquiree  at  its  acquisition  date  fair  value  is  remeasured,  and  the  resulting  gain  or  loss,  if  any,  is\nrecognized in profit or loss. For all amounts recognized in other comprehensive income arising from\nchange in equity of acquiree prior to acquisition date, the Company shall treat it on the same basis as\nif  the  Company  directly  dispose  of  the  previously  held  equity  interest.  If  the  amounts  previously\nrecognized in other comprehensive income shall be reclassified to profit or loss as would be required\nwhile disposal of such interest, the Company shall reclassify it to profit or loss.\n\nIf the initial accounting for an acquisition is incomplete by the end of the reporting period in which\nthe  acquisition  occurs,  provisional  amounts  for  the  items  which  the  accounting  is  incomplete  are\nreported  in  the  financial  statements.  During  the  measurement  period,  the  provisional  amounts\nrecognized at the acquisition date are retrospectively adjusted to reflect new information obtained\nabout facts and circumstances that existed as of the acquisition date. The measurement period shall\nnot exceed one year from the acquisition date.\n\nAcquisition-related costs are expensed as incurred except for the costs related to issuance of debt or\nequity instruments.\n\n(Continued)\n\n\x0cACER INCORPORATED\n\nNotes to Parent-Company-Only Financial Statements\n\n30\n\n(j)\n\nProperty, plant and equipment \n\n(i)\n\nRecognition and measurement\n\nProperty,  plant  and  equipment  are  measured  at  cost  less  accumulated  depreciation  and\naccumulated  impairment  losses.  Cost  includes  expenditure  that  is  directly  attributed  to  the\nacquisition of the asset and bringing the asset to the location and condition necessary for it to\nbe capable of operating in the manner intended by management, the initial estimate of the costs\nof dismantling and removing the item and restoring the site on which it is located, and any\nborrowing  cost  that  is  eligible  for  capitalization.  Purchased  software  that  is  integral  to  the\nfunctionality of the related equipment is capitalized as part of that equipment.\n\nThe  gain  or  loss  arising  from  the  disposal  of  an  item  of  property,  plant  and  equipment  is\ndetermined  as  the  difference  between  the  net  disposal  proceeds,  if  any,  and  the  carrying\namount of the item, and is recognized as non-operating income and loss.\n\n(ii) Reclassification to investment property \n\nA property is reclassified to investment property at its carrying amount when the purpose of\nthe property changes from owner-occupied to investment.  \n\n(iii) Subsequent costs\n\nSubsequent  costs  are  capitalized  only  when  it  is  probable  that  future  economic  benefits\nassociated with the costs will flow to the Company and the cost of the item can be measured\nreliably. The carrying amount of the replaced part is derecognized in profit and loss. All other\nrepairs and maintenance are charged to expense as incurred.\n\n(iv) Depreciation\n\nDepreciation is calculated on the cost of assets less their residual values and is recognized on a\nstraight  line  basis  over  the  estimated  useful  lives.  When  an  item  of  property,  plant  and\nequipment  comprises  significant  individual  components  for  which  different  depreciation\nmethods or useful lives are appropriate, each component is depreciated separately. Land is not\ndepreciated. The depreciation is recognized in profit or loss.\n\nThe estimated useful lives of property, plant and equipment for the current and comparative\nperiods are as follows: buildings\xef\xbc\x8dmain structure - 30 to 50 years; air-conditioning system - 10\nyears;  other  equipment  pertaining  to  buildings  -  20  years;  computer  and  communication\nequipment - 3 to 5 years; and other equipment - 3 to 10 years.\n\nDepreciation  methods,  useful  lives,  and  residual  values  are reviewed at each financial year-\nend, with the effect of any changes in estimate accounted for on a prospective basis.\n\n(Continued)\n\n\x0cACER INCORPORATED\n\nNotes to Parent-Company-Only Financial Statements\n\n31\n\n(k)\n\nInvestment property\n\nInvestment property is property held either to earn rental income or for capital appreciation or for\nboth, but not for sale in the ordinary course of business or for administrative purposes. Investment\nproperty  is  measured  at  cost  on  initial  recognition.    Subsequent  to  initial  recognition,  investment\nproperty  is  measured  at  initial  acquisition  cost  less  accumulated  depreciation  and  accumulated\nimpairment losses.  The methods for depreciating and determining the useful life and residual value\nof investment property are the same as those adopted for property, plant and equipment. \n\nCost includes expenditure that is directly attributable to the acquisition of the investment property,\nbringing the investment property to the condition necessary for intend use, and any borrowing cost\nthat is eligible for capitalization.\n\nAn investment property is reclassified to property, plant and equipment at its carrying amount when\nthe purpose of the investment property has been changed from investment to owner-occupied.\n\n(l)\n\nLeases\n\nLeases  are  classified  as  finance  leases when the Company assumes substantially all the risks and\nrewards incidental to ownership of the assets. All other leases are classified as operating leases.\n\n(i)\n\nThe Company as lessor\n\nLease income from an operating lease is recognized in profit or loss on a straight-line basis\nover the lease term. Initial direct costs incurred in negotiating and arranging an operating lease\nare added to the carrying amount of the leased asset and recognized as expense over the lease\nterm on a straight-line basis. Incentives granted to the lessee to enter into the operating lease\nare  recognized  as  a  reduction  of  rental  income  over  the  lease  term  on  a  straight-line  basis.\nContingent  rents  are  recognized  as  income  in  the  period  when  the  lease  adjustments  are\nconfirmed.\n\n(ii) The Company as lessee \n\nPayments  made  under  operating  leases  (excluding  insurance  and  maintenance  expenses)  are\ncharged to expense over the lease term on a straight-line basis. Lease incentives received from\nthe lessor are recognized as a reduction of rental expense over the lease term on a straight-line\nbasis. Contingent rents are recognized as expense in the period when the lease adjustments are\nconfirmed.\n\n(m)\n\nIntangible assets\n\n(i) Goodwill\n\nGoodwill  arising  from  the  Company  acquiring  subsidiaries  is  included  in  intangible  assets.\nRefer  to  note  4(i)  for  the  description  of  the  measurement  of  goodwill  at  initial  recognition.\nGoodwill arising from acquisitions of subsidiaries and associates are included in the carrying\namount of investments in associates. Goodwill is not amortized but is measured at cost less\naccumulated impairment losses.\n\n(Continued)\n\n\x0cACER INCORPORATED\n\nNotes to Parent-Company-Only Financial Statements\n\n32\n\n(ii) Trademarks\n\nTrademarks  are  measured  at  cost.  Subsequent  to  the  initial  recognition,  trademarks  with\ndefinite  useful  lives  are  carried  at  cost  less  accumulated  amortization  and  accumulated\nimpairment  losses.  Trademarks  with  indefinite  useful  lives  are  carried  at  cost  less  any\naccumulated impairment losses and are tested for impairment annually. The useful life of an\nintangible asset not subject to amortization is reviewed annually at each financial year-end to\ndetermine  whether  events  and  circumstances  continue  to  support  an  indefinite  useful  life\nassessment for the asset. Any change in the useful life assessment from indefinite to definite is\naccounted for as a change in accounting estimate.\n\n(iii) Other intangible assets\n\nOther separately acquired intangible assets are carried at cost less accumulated amortization\nand accumulated impairment losses. Amortization is recognized in profit or loss on a straight-\nline basis over the following estimated useful lives: patents - 4 to 15 years; acquired software -\n1 to 3 years.\n\nThe residual value, amortization period, and amortization method are reviewed at least at each\nfinancial year-end. Any changes shall be accounted for as changes in accounting estimates.\n\n(n)\n\nImpairment of non-financial assets\n\n(i) Goodwill \n\nFor the purpose of impairment testing, goodwill arising from an acquisition of subsidiary is\nallocated to each of the Company\xe2\x80\x99s cash-generating units (CGUs) that are expected to benefit\nfrom the synergies of the combination.  The CGUs with goodwill are tested annually (or when\nthere  are  indications  that  a  CGU  may  have  been  impaired)  for  impairment.  When  the\nrecoverable amount of a CGU is less than the carrying amount of the CGU, the impairment\nloss  is  recognized  firstly  by  reducing  the  carrying  amount  of  any  goodwill  allocated  to  the\nCGU  and  then  proportionately  allocated  to  the  other  assets  of  the  CGU  on  the  basis  of  the\ncarrying amount of each asset in the CGU.  Any impairment loss is recognized immediately in\nprofit or loss. A subsequent reversal of the impairment loss on goodwill is prohibited.\n\n(ii) Other tangible and intangible assets \n\nNon-financial assets other than inventories, deferred income tax assets, and assets arising from\nemployee  benefits  are  reviewed  for impairment at each reporting date to determine whether\nthere is any indication of impairment. When there exists an indication of impairment for an\nasset,  the  recoverable  amount  of  the  asset  is  estimated.  If  the  recoverable  amount  of  an\nindividual asset cannot be determined, the Company estimates the recoverable amount of the\nCGU to which the asset has been allocated. \n\n(Continued)\n\n\x0cACER INCORPORATED\n\nNotes to Parent-Company-Only Financial Statements\n\n33\n\nThe recoverable amount for an individual asset or a CGU is the higher of its fair value less\ncosts to sell or its value in use. In assessing value in use, the estimated future cash flows are\ndiscounted to their present value using a pre-tax discount rate that reflects the evaluation of\ncurrent market on the time values of money and on the risks specific to the asset. When the\nrecoverable amount of an asset or a CGU is less than its carrying amount, the carrying amount\nof the asset or CGU is reduced to its recoverable amount, and an impairment loss is recognized\nin profit or loss immediately. \n\nThe Company assesses at each reporting date whether there is any evidence that an impairment\nloss recognized in prior periods for an asset other than goodwill may no longer exist or may\nhave decreased.  If so, an impairment loss recognized in prior periods for an asset other than\ngoodwill is reversed, and the carrying amount of the asset or CGU is increased to its revised\nestimate of recoverable amount. The increased carrying amount shall not exceed the carrying\namount  (net  of  amortization  or  depreciation)  that  would  have  been  determined  had  no\nimpairment loss been recognized in prior years.\n\nIntangible  assets  with  indefinite  useful  lives  or  those  not  yet  available  for  use  are  tested\nannually  for  impairment.  An  impairment  loss  is  recognized  for  the  excess  of  the  asset\xe2\x80\x99 s\ncarrying amount over its recoverable amount.\n\n(o)\n\nProvisions\n\nProvisions are recognized when the Company has a present obligation (legal or constructive) as a\nresult of a past event, it is probable that the Company will be required to settle the obligation, and a\nreliable estimate can be made of the amount of the obligation.  \n\n(i) Warranties\n\nA provision for warranties is recognized when the underlying products or services are sold.\nThis  provision  reflects  the  historical  warranty  claim  rate  and  the  weighting  of  all  possible\noutcomes against their associated probabilities.\n\n(ii) Others\n\nProvisions  for  litigation  claims  and  environmental  restoration  are  recognized  when  the\nCompany  has  a  present  obligation  (legal  or  constructive)  as  a  result  of  a  past  event,  it  is\nprobable that the Company will be required to settle the obligation, and a reliable estimate can\nbe made of the amount of the obligation.\n\n(p) Treasury stock\n\nCommon stock repurchased by the Company treated as treasury stock (a contra-equity account) is\nreported at acquisition cost (including all directly accountable costs).  When treasury stock is sold,\nthe excess of sales proceeds over cost is accounted for as capital surplus\xef\xbc\x8dtreasury stock.  If the\nsales  proceeds  are  less  than  cost,  the  deficiency  is  accounted  for  as a reduction of the remaining\nbalance  of  capital  surplus\xef\xbc\x8d treasury  stock.  If  the  remaining  balance  of  capital  surplus\xef\xbc\x8d treasury\nstock  is  insufficient  to  cover  the  deficiency,  the  remainder  is  recorded  as  a  reduction  of  retained\nearnings.  The cost of treasury stock is computed using the weighted-average cost of different types\nof repurchase.\n\n(Continued)\n\n\x0cACER INCORPORATED\n\nNotes to Parent-Company-Only Financial Statements\n\n34\n\nIf  treasury  stock  is  retired,  the  weighted-average  cost  of  the  retired  treasury  stock  is  written  off\nagainst the par value and the capital surplus premium, if any, of the stock retired on a pro rata basis.\nIf the weighted-average cost written off exceeds the sum of the par value and the capital surplus, the\ndifference  is  accounted  for  as  a  reduction  of  capital  surplus\xef\xbc\x8d treasury  stock,  or  a  reduction  of\nretained earnings for any deficiency where capital surplus\xef\xbc\x8dtreasury stock is insufficient to cover the\ndifference.  If the weighted-average cost written off is less than the sum of the par value and capital\nsurplus, if any, of the stock retired, the difference is accounted for as an increase in capital surplus\xef\xbc\x8d\ntreasury stock.\n\n(q) Revenue recognition \n\n(i)\n\nRevenue from contracts with customers (policy applicable commencing January 1, 2018)\n\nRevenue is measured based on the consideration to which the Company expects to be entitled\nin exchange for transferring goods or services to a customer. The Company recognizes revenue\nwhen it satisfies a performance obligation by transferring control of a good or a service to a\ncustomer.  The  accounting  policies  for  the  Company\xe2\x80\x99 s  main  types  of  revenue  are  explained\nbelow.\n\n1)\n\nSale of goods\n\nThe  Company  recognizes  revenue  when  control  of  the  products  has  been  transferred,\nbeing when the products are delivered to the customer, the customer has full discretion\nover the channel and price to sell the products, and there is no unfulfilled obligation that\ncould  affect  the  customer\xe2\x80\x99 s  acceptance  of  the  products.  Delivery  occurs  when  the\nproducts have been shipped to the specific location, the risks of obsolescence and loss\nhave been transferred to the customer, and either the customer has accepted the products\nin  accordance  with  the  sales  contract,  the  acceptance  provisions  have  lapsed,  or  the\nCompany has objective evidence that all criteria for acceptance have been satisfied.\n\nThe Company recognizes revenue based on the price specified in the contract, net of the\nestimated volume discounts and rebates. Accumulated experience is used to estimate the\ndiscounts and rebates using the expected value method, and revenue is only recognized to\nthe extent that it is highly probable that a significant reversal will not occur. A refund\nliability  is  recognized  for  expected  sales  discounts  and rebate payable to customers in\nrelation to sales made until the end of the reporting period. No element of financing is\ndeemed present as the sales are made with a credit term from 30 to 90 days, which is\nconsistent with the market practice.\n\nThe  Company\xe2\x80\x99 s  obligation  to  provide  a  refund  for  faulty  goods  under  the  standard\nwarranty terms is recognized as a provision for warranty. Please refer to note 6(o) for\nmore explanation.\n\nA receivable is recognized when the goods are delivered as this is the point in time that\nthe Company has a right to an amount of consideration that is unconditional.\n\n(Continued)\n\n\x0cACER INCORPORATED\n\nNotes to Parent-Company-Only Financial Statements\n\n35\n\n2)\n\nRevenue from service rendered\n\nThe  Company  provides  system  implementation  or  integration  services  to  enterprise\ncustomers. Revenue from providing services is recognized in the accounting periods in\nwhich the services are rendered. For performance obligations that are satisfied over time,\nrevenue is recognized based on the actual service provided to the end of the reporting\nperiod  as  a  proportion  of the total services to be provided. The proportion of services\nprovided is determined based on the portion of the work performed, the time passed by,\nor the milestone reached.\n\nEstimates  of  revenues,  costs,  or  extent  of  progress  toward  completion,  are  revised  if\ncircumstances  change.  Any  resulting  increases  or  decreases  in  estimated  revenues  or\ncosts are reflected in profit or loss in the period in which the circumstances that give rise\nto the revision become known by the management.\n\nIn case of fixed-price contracts, the customer pays the fixed amount based on a payment\nschedule. If the accumulated revenue recognized by the Company exceed the payments, a\ncontract asset is recognized. If the payments exceed the accumulated revenue recognized,\na contract liability is recognized.\n\n3)\n\nFinancing components\n\nThe  Company  does  not  expect  to  have  any  contracts  where  the  period  between  the\ntransfer  of  the  promised  goods  or  services  to  the  customer  and  the  payment  by  the\ncustomer exceeds one year. As a consequence, the Company does not adjust any of the\ntransaction prices for the time value of money. \n\n(ii) Revenue recognition (applicable before January 1, 2018)\n\nRevenue  from  the  sale  of  goods  or  services  is  measured  at  the  fair  value  of  consideration\nreceived or receivable, net of returns, rebates, and other similar discounts.\n\n1)\n\nSale of goods\n\nRevenue  from  the  sale  of  goods  is  recognized  when  all  the  following  conditions  have\nbeen satisfied: (a) the significant risks and rewards of ownership of the goods have been\ntransferred  to  the  buyer;  (b)  the  Company  retains  neither  continuing  managerial\ninvolvement to the degree usually associated with ownership nor effective control over\nthe goods sold; (c) the amount of revenue can be measured reliably; (d) it is probable that\nthe economic benefits associated with the transaction will flow to the Company; and (e)\nthe cost incurred or to be incurred, in respect of the transaction, can be measured reliably.\n\nThe timing of the transfers of risks and rewards varies depending on the individual terms\nof the sales agreement. Revenue is not recognized for the sale of key components to an\noriginal  design  manufacturer  for  manufacture  or  assembly  as  the  significant  risks  and\nrewards of the ownership of materials are not transferred.\n\nRevenue from extended warranty contracts is deferred and amortized as earned over the\ncontract period, ranging from one to three years.\n\n(Continued)\n\n\x0cACER INCORPORATED\n\nNotes to Parent-Company-Only Financial Statements\n\n36\n\n2)\n\nServices\n\nRevenue from services rendered is recognized by reference to the stage of completion at\nthe reporting date.\n\n3)\n\nRental income, interest income, and dividend income\n\nRental income from investment property is recognized over the lease term on a straight-\nline basis. \n\nDividend income from investments is recognized when the shareholder\xe2\x80\x99s right to receive\npayment has been established, provided that it is probable that the economic benefits will\nflow to the Company and the amount of income can be measured reliably. \n\nInterest income is accrued on a time basis, by reference to the principal outstanding and\nat the effective interest rate applicable.\n\n(iii) Contract costs (applicable commencing January 1, 2018)\n\n1)\n\nIncremental costs of obtaining a contract\n\nThe Company recognizes the incremental costs of obtaining a contract with a customer as\nan  asset  if  the  Company  expects  to  recover  those  costs.  The  incremental  costs  of\nobtaining a contract are those costs that the Company incurs to obtain a contract with a\ncustomer that it would not have incurred if the contract had not been obtained. Costs to\nobtain a contract that would have been incurred, regardless of whether the contract was\nobtained,  shall  be  recognized  as  an  expense  when  incurred,  unless  those  costs  are\nexplicitly chargeable to the customer regardless of whether the contract is obtained.\n\nThe  Company  applies  the  practical  expedient  to  recognize  the  incremental  costs  of\nobtaining a contract as an expense when incurred if the amortization period of the asset\nthat the Company otherwise would have recognized is one year or less.\n\n2)\n\nCosts to fulfil a contract\n\nIf the costs incurred in fulfilling a contract with a customer are not within the scope of\nanother  Standard  (for  example,  IAS  2  Inventories,  IAS  16  Property,  Plant  and\nEquipment or IAS 38 Intangible Assets), the Company recognizes an asset from the costs\nincurred to fulfil a contract only if those costs meet all of the following criteria:\n\n\xef\x82\xb7 the costs relate directly to a contract or to an anticipated contract that the Company can\n\nspecifically identify;\n\n\xef\x82\xb7 the costs generate or enhance resources of the Company that will be used in satisfying\n\n(or in continuing to satisfy) performance obligations in the future; and\n\n\xef\x82\xb7 the costs are expected to be recovered.\n\nGeneral and administrative costs, costs of wasted materials, labor or other resources to\nfulfil the contract that were not reflected in the price of the contract, costs that relate to\nsatisfied  performance  obligations  (or  partially  satisfied  performance  obligations),  and\ncosts for which the Company cannot distinguish whether the costs relate to unsatisfied\n\n(Continued)\n\n\x0cACER INCORPORATED\n\nNotes to Parent-Company-Only Financial Statements\n\n37\n\nperformance  obligations  or  to  satisfied  performance  obligations  (or  partially  satisfied\nperformance obligations) are recognized as expenses when incurred.\n\n(r) Government grant\n\nA government grant is recognized only when there is reasonable assurance that the Company will\ncomply with the conditions attached to it and that the grant will be received.\n\nA  government  grant  that  becomes  receivable  as  compensation  for  expenses  or  losses  already\nincurred or for the purpose of giving immediate financial support to the Company with no future\nrelated costs is recognized in profit or loss in the period in which it becomes receivable.\n\nGovernment grant is recognized in other gains and losses.\n\n(s)\n\nEmployee benefits \n\n(i) Defined contribution plans\n\nObligations  for  contributions  to  defined  contribution  pension  plans  are  expensed  during  the\nyear in which employees render services.\n\n(ii) Defined benefit plans\n\nThe liability recognized in respect of defined benefit pension plans is the present value of the\ndefined benefit obligation at the reporting date less the fair value of plan assets. The discount\nrate for calculating the present value of the defined benefit obligation refers to the interest rate\nof high-quality government bonds at the financial reporting date that are denominated in the\ncurrency in which the benefits will be paid and that have terms to maturity approximating the\nterms of the related pension obligation.\n\nThe defined benefit obligation is calculated annually by qualified actuaries using the projected\nunit credit method. When the calculation results in a benefit to the Company, the recognized\nasset is limited to the total amount of the present value of the economic benefits available in\nthe  form  of  refunds  from  the  plan  or  reductions  in  future  contributions  to  the  plan.    The\nminimum funding requirements of any plans applicable to the Company should be taken into\nconsideration  when  determining  the  present  value  of  the  economic  benefits.    An  economic\nbenefit  is  available  to  the  Company  if  it  is  realizable  during  the  life  of  the  plan  or  upon\nsettlement of the plan liabilities.\n\nWhen the benefits of a plan are improved, the expenses related to the increased obligations\nresulting from the services rendered by employees in the past years are recognized in profit or\nloss immediately.\n\nThe remeasurements of the net defined benefit liability (asset) comprise (i) actuarial gains and\nlosses; (ii) return on plan assets, excluding amounts included in net interest on the net defined\nbenefit  liability  (asset);  and  (iii)  any  change  in  the  effect  of  the  asset  ceiling,  excluding\namounts  included  in  net  interest  on  the  net  defined  benefit  liability  (asset).  The\nremeasurements  of  the  net  defined  benefit  liability  (asset)  are  recognized  in  other\ncomprehensive income and reflected in other equity.\n\n(Continued)\n\n\x0cACER INCORPORATED\n\nNotes to Parent-Company-Only Financial Statements\n\n38\n\nThe Company recognizes gains or losses on the curtailment or settlement of a defined benefit\nplan when the curtailment or settlement occurs. The gain or loss on curtailment or settlement\ncomprises any resulting change in the fair value of plan assets and any change in the present\nvalue of the defined benefit obligation. \n\n(iii) Short-term employee benefits\n\nShort-term  employee  benefit  obligations  are  measured  on  an  undiscounted  basis  and  are\nexpensed during the period in which employees render services.  A liability is recognized for\nthe  amount  expected  to  be  paid  under  short-term  cash  bonus  or  profit-sharing  plans  if  the\nCompany has a present legal or constructive obligation to make such payments as a result of\npast service provided by the employees, and the obligation can be estimated reliably.\n\n(t)\n\nShare-based payment\n\nShare-based payment awards granted to employees are measured at fair value at the date of grant.\nThe fair value determined at the grant date is expensed over the period that the employees become\nunconditionally entitled to the awards, with a corresponding increase in equity. The compensation\ncost is adjusted to reflect the number of awards given to employees for which the performance and\nnon-market conditions are expected to be met, such that the amount ultimately recognized shall be\nbased on the number of equity instruments that eventually vested. \n\nThe grant date of options for employees to subscribe new shares for a cash injection is the date when\nthe Board of Directors approves the exercise price and the shares to which employees can subscribe. \n\n(u)\n\nIncome taxes \n\nIncome tax expenses include both current taxes and deferred taxes.  Current and deferred taxes are\nrecognized in profit or loss unless they relate to business combinations or items recognized directly\nin equity or other comprehensive income.\n\nCurrent tax is the expected tax payable or receivable on the taxable income or loss for the year, using\ntax rates enacted or substantively enacted at the reporting date, and any adjustments to tax payable in\nrespect of previous years.\n\nDeferred  income  taxes  are  recognized  in  respect  of  temporary  differences  between  the  carrying\namounts of assets and liabilities for financial reporting purposes and the amounts used for taxation\npurposes.  Deferred taxes are not recognized for:\n\n(i)\n\nTemporary differences on the initial recognition of assets or liabilities in a transaction that is\nnot a business combination and that affects neither accounting nor taxable profit nor loss;\n\n(ii) Temporary differences arising from investments in subsidiaries and joint ventures to the extent\nthat the Company is able to control the timing of the reversal of the temporary differences, and\nit is probable that the differences will not reverse in the foreseeable future; and\n\n(iii) Temporary differences arising from initial recognition of goodwill.\n\nDeferred  tax  assets  are  recognized  for  unused  tax  losses,  tax  credits,  and  deductible  temporary\ndifferences to the extent that it is probable that future taxable profits will be available against which\nthey  can  be  utilized.    Deferred  tax  assets  are  reviewed  at  each  reporting  date  and  reduced  to  the\nextent that it is no longer probable that the related tax benefit will be realized.\n\n(Continued)\n\n\x0cACER INCORPORATED\n\nNotes to Parent-Company-Only Financial Statements\n\n39\n\nDeferred tax is measured based on the expected manner of realization or settlement of the carrying\namount of the assets and liabilities, using tax rates enacted or substantively enacted at the reporting\ndate.\n\nDeferred  tax  assets  and  liabilities  are  offset  when  where  is  a  legally  enforceable  right  to  offset\ncurrent tax assets against current tax liabilities and when the deferred tax assets and liabilities relate\nto income taxes levied by the same tax authority on either the same taxable entity or different taxable\nentities where there is an intention to settle the balances on a net basis.\n\n(v) Earnings per share (\xe2\x80\x9cEPS\xe2\x80\x9d)\n\nThe basic and diluted EPS attributable to stockholders of the Company are disclosed in the financial\nstatements.  Basic  EPS  is  calculated  by  dividing  net  income  attributable  to  stockholders  of  the\nCompany  by  the  weighted-average  number  of  common  shares  outstanding  during  the  year.    In\ncalculating diluted EPS, the net income attributable to stockholders of the Company and weighted-\naverage number of common shares outstanding during the year are adjusted for the effects of dilutive\npotential  common  shares.  The  Company\xe2\x80\x99 s  dilutive  potential  common  shares  include    restricted\nshares of stock issued to employees and profit sharing for employees to be settled in the form of\ncommon stock.\n\n(w) Operating segments\n\nThe Company discloses the operating segment information in the consolidated financial statements.\nTherefore, the Company does not disclose the operating segment information in the parent-company-\nonly financial statements.\n\n5.\n\nCritical Accounting Judgments and Key Sources of Estimation Uncertainty\nThe  preparation  of  the  parent-company-only  financial  statements  in  conformity  with  the  Regulations\nGoverning the Preparation of Financial Reports requires management to make judgments, estimates and\nassumptions  that  affect  the  application  of  the  accounting  policies  and  the  reported  amount  of  assets,\nliabilities, income and expenses. Actual results may differ from these estimates.\n\nThe  estimates  and  underlying  assumptions  are  reviewed  on  an  ongoing  basis.  Revisions  to  accounting\nestimates are recognized in the period in which the estimate is revised and in the future periods affected.\n\nInformation about assumptions and estimation uncertainties that have a significant risk of resulting in a\nmaterial adjustment within the next financial year is included as follows:\n\n(a) Revenue recognition (accrual of sales allowance)\n\nThe  Company  recognizes  revenue  when  the  earning  process  is  completed.  The  Company  also\nrecords a provision for estimated future sales allowances in the same period the related revenue is\nrecorded.  Provision  for  estimated  sales  allowances  is  generally  made  and  adjusted  based  on\nhistorical  experience,  market  and  economic  conditions,  and  any  other  known  factors  that  would\nsignificantly affect the allowance. The adequacy of estimations is reviewed periodically. The fierce\nmarket competition and rapid evolution of technology could result in significant adjustments to the\nprovision made.\n\n(Continued)\n\n\x0cACER INCORPORATED\n\nNotes to Parent-Company-Only Financial Statements\n\n40\n\n(b) Valuation of inventory\n\nInventories are measured at the lower of cost or net realizable value.  The Company uses judgment\nand estimates to determine the net realizable value of inventory at each reporting date.\n\nDue to rapid technological changes, the Company estimates the net realizable value of inventory,\ntaking obsolescence and unmarketable items into account at the reporting date, and then writes down\nthe cost of inventories to net realizable value. The net realizable value of the inventory is mainly\ndetermined  based  on  assumptions  of  future  demand  within  a  specific  time  horizon,  which  could\nresult in significant adjustments. Refer to note 6(h) for further description of inventory write-downs.\n\n(c)\n\nImpairment of goodwill from investments in subsidiaries\n\nThe assessment of impairment of goodwill requires the Company to make subjective judgments to\nidentify cash-generating units, allocate the goodwill to relevant cash-generating units, and estimate\nthe recoverable amount of relevant cash-generating units. Any changes in these estimates based on\nchanged economic conditions or business strategies could result in significant adjustments in future\nyears. Refer to note 6(i) for further description of the impairment of goodwill. \n\n6.\n\nSignificant account disclosures  \n(a) Cash and cash equivalents\n\nCash on hand\nBank deposits \nTime deposits\n\xe3\x80\x80\nFinancial assets and liabilities measued at fair value through profit or loss\n\n$\n\n$\n\n(b)\n\nDecember 31,\n\nDecember 31,\n\n2018\n\n664\n1,155,350\n2,469,140\n3,625,154\n\n2017\n\n659\n3,071,658\n10,636,388\n13,708,705\n\nFinancial assets held for trading\xef\xbc\x8dcurrent:\n\xe3\x80\x80Derivatives\xef\xbc\x8dForeign currency forward contracts\nFinancial assets at fair value through profit or loss\xef\xbc\x8dcurrent:\n\xe3\x80\x80Conversion rights of investments in convertible bonds \n\nFinancial assets mandatorily measured at fair value through  \n    profit or loss:\n\xe3\x80\x80Derivative instruments not used for hedging\n\xe3\x80\x80\xe3\x80\x80Foreign currency forward contracts\n\xe3\x80\x80Non-derivative financial assets\n\xe3\x80\x80\xe3\x80\x80Convertible bonds\n\nDecember 31,\n\n2018\n\nDecember 31,\n\n2017\n\n$\n\n$\n\n$\n\n-\n\n-\n\n255,524\n\n11,427\n266,951\n266,951\n\n55,374\n\n3,033\n\n-\n\n-\n-\n\n58,407\n\n(Continued)\n\n\x0cACER INCORPORATED\n\nNotes to Parent-Company-Only Financial Statements\n\n41\n\nDecember 31,\n\nDecember 31,\n\n2018\n\n2017\n\nFinancial liabilities held for trading\xef\xbc\x8dcurrent:\n(326,006)\n\xe3\x80\x80Derivatives\xef\xbc\x8dForeign currency forward contracts\nConvertible bonds held by the Company were issued by StarBreeze Publishing AB (\xe2\x80\x9cStarBreeze\xe2\x80\x9d).\nStarBreeze  filed  for  reconstruction  with  the  court  due  to  its  shortage  of  liquidity,  and  the  court\napproved the application in 2018. Accordingly, the Company recognized a loss of $255,345 (arising\nfrom the fair value measurement of the convertible bonds) which was presented in other gains and\nlosses in the accompanying parent-company-only statements of comprehensive income.\n\n(183,413)\n\n$\n\nThe  Company  entered  into  derivative  contracts  to  manage  foreign  currency  exchange  risk  arising\nfrom operating activities. While assessing the recoverability of the notes and accounts receivable, the Company consider\nany  changes  in  the  credit  quality  between  the  initial  transaction  date  and  the  reporting  date.  The\nallowance  for  doubtful  receivables  was  assessed  by  referring  to  the  collectability  of  receivables\nbased  on  an  individual  trade  term  analysis,  the  historical  payment  behavior  and  current  financial\ncondition of customers, credit insurance and the provision for sales returns and allowances. Notes\nand accounts receivable that were past due but for which the Company had not recognized a specific\nallowance for doubtful receivables after the assessment were still considered recoverable.\n\nMovements of the allowance for notes and accounts receivable was as follows:\n\nBalance at January 1 (per IAS 39)\nAdjustment on initial application of IFRS 9\nBalance at January 1 (Bluechip)\n\nIn order to strengthen the Group\xe2\x80\x99s connection with upstream and downstream industries of 3C\nproducts, the Company acquired 152 thousand shares of Bluechip, formerly an associate of the\nCompany,  for  a  cash  consideration  of $8,739 on March 14, 2018. After the acquisition, the\nCompany\xe2\x80\x99 s  interest  in  Bluechip  increased  from  30.23%  to  34.52%,  and  the  Group\xe2\x80\x99 s  total\nownership of Bluechip reached 50.58% after taking AOI\xe2\x80\x99s 16.06% interest in Bluechip into\naccount.  The  Company  therefore  became  the  largest  shareholder  of  Bluechip  and  obtained\ncontrol over it since then.\n\nIn accordance with IFRSs, the identifiable assets and liabilities assumed at the acquisition date\nare measured at fair value. Based on the evaluation performed by a specialist, the consideration\npaid for the acquisition and fair value information of assets acquired and liabilities assumed\nfrom the acquisition on the acquisition date are as follows:\n\nPurchase consideration \nAdd: Non-controlling interest in the acquiree (proportionate\n\nshare of the fair value of the identifiable net assets)\nFair value of pre-existing interest in the acquiree\n\nLess: Fair value of identifiable assets acquired and\n\nliabilities assumed\n\n\xe3\x80\x80  Cash and cash equivalents\n\xe3\x80\x80  Accounts receivable, net\n\xe3\x80\x80  Inventories\n\xe3\x80\x80  Other current assets\n\xe3\x80\x80  Financial assets measured at fair value through other\n\ncomprehensive income\xef\xbc\x8dnon-current\n\n\xe3\x80\x80  Property, plant and equipment\n\xe3\x80\x80  Intangible assets\n\xe3\x80\x80  Other non-current assets\n\xe3\x80\x80  Short-term borrowings\n\xe3\x80\x80  Accounts payable\n\xe3\x80\x80  Other current liabilities\n\xe3\x80\x80  Other non-current liabilities\nGain on bargain purchase\n\n$\n\n8,739\n\n105,682\n93,164\n\n$\n\n(213,970)\n(6,385)\n(Continued)\n\n$\n\n7,668\n280,568\n201,195\n14,537\n\n13,157\n5,729\n24,759\n9,676\n(79,409)\n(225,487)\n(19,968)\n(18,455)\n\n\x0cACER INCORPORATED\n\nNotes to Parent-Company-Only Financial Statements\n\n47\n\nThe Company remeasured the fair value of its existing 30.23% ownership of Bluechip at the\nacquisition date, and recognized a loss on disposal of investments of $29,531 accordingly. The plans (covered by\nthe Labor Standards Law) entitle a retired employee to receive a payment based on years of\nservice and average salary for the six months prior to the employee\xe2\x80\x99s retirement.\n\n536,730\n\n$\n\n1)\n\nComposition of plan assets\n\nThe pension fund (the \xe2\x80\x9cFund\xe2\x80\x9d) contributed by the Company is managed and administered\nby the Bureau of Labor Funds of the Ministry of Labor (the Bureau of Labor Funds).\nAccording to the \xe2\x80\x9cRegulations for Revenues, Expenditures, Safeguard and Utilization of\nthe  Labor  Retirement  Fund\xe2\x80\x9d ,  with  regard  to  the  utilization  of  the  Fund,  minimum\nearnings shall be no less than the earnings attainable from two-year time deposits with\ninterest  rates  offered  by  local  banks.  The  Company  also  established  pension  funds  in\naccordance  with  the  \xe2\x80\x9c Regulations  Governing  the  Management,  Investment,  and\nDistribution  of  the  Employees\xe2\x80\x99   Retirement  Fund  Established  by  a  Profit-seeking\nEnterprise\xe2\x80\x9d ,  which  are  funded  by  time  deposits  and  bank  deposits  deposited  in  the\ndesignated  financial  institutions.  The  administration  of  pension  funds  is  separate  from\nthe  Company,  and  the  principal  and interest from such funds shall not be used in any\nform except for the payment of pension and severance to employees.\n\nAs of December 31, 2018 and 2017, the balances of aforementioned pension funds were\n$358,844  and  $350,932,  respectively.  For  information  on  the  domestic  labor  pension\nfund  assets  (including  the  asset  portfolio  and  yield  of  the  fund),  please  refer  to  the\nwebsite of the Bureau of Labor Funds.\n\n(Continued)\n\n\x0cACER INCORPORATED\n\nNotes to Parent-Company-Only Financial Statements\n\n2) Movements in present value of the defined benefit obligations\n\n57\n\nDefined benefit This approach shows the isolated effect of changing one\nindividual assumption but does not take into account that some assumptions are related.\nThe method used to carry out the sensitivity analysis is the same as the calculation of the\nnet defined benefit liabilities recognized in the balance sheets. Under this defined contribution plan,\nthe  Company  has  no  legal  or  constructive  obligation  to  pay  additional  amounts  after\ncontributing a fixed amount to the Bureau of Labor Insurance. 2014. In 2018 and 2017, the Company recalled 1,569 thousand shares and 4,230\nthousand shares, respectively, of restricted stock for certain employees due to their resignation\nand retirement, as well as failing to meet certain vesting conditions. The Board of Directors\nhad approved the capital reductions for retirement of restricted shares issued to employees and\nthe related registration process has been completed.\n\nAs of December 31, 2018 and 2017, the Company had issued 5,858 thousand units and 6,446\nthousand units, respectively, of global depository receipts (GDRs).  The GDRs were listed on\nthe London Stock Exchange, and each GDR represents five common shares.\n\n(Continued)\n\n\x0cACER INCORPORATED\n\nNotes to Parent-Company-Only Financial Statements\n\n62\n\nAs  of  December  31,  2018  and  2017,  the  Company\xe2\x80\x99 s  authorized  shares  of  common  stock\nconsisted  of  3,500,000  thousand  shares,  of  which  3,074,934  thousand  shares  and  3,076,503\nthousand shares, respectively, were issued. The par value of the Company\xe2\x80\x99s common stock is\n$10 per share.  All issued shares were paid up upon issuance.\n\nCertain shares of common stock were not outstanding as they were held by the Company\xe2\x80\x99s\nsubsidiaries  or  were  non-vested  restricted  stock.  The  movements  in  outstanding  shares  of\ncommon stock in 2018 and 2017 were as follows (in thousands of shares): \n\nBalance at January 1\nVested restricted stock\nBalance at December 31\n\n(ii) Capital surplus\n\n2018\n3,026,277\n1,911\n3,028,188\n\n2017\n3,026,277\n\n-\n\n3,026,277\n\n\xe3\x80\x80Paid-in capital in excess of par value\n\xe3\x80\x80Surplus from mergers\n\xe3\x80\x80Surplus related to treasury stock transactions and cash\n\ndividend\n\n\xe3\x80\x80Difference between consideration and carrying amount\n\nof subsidiaries acquired or disposed\n\n\xe3\x80\x80Employee share options\n    Surplus from equity-method investments\n    Restricted stock issued to employees\n\n$\n\n$\n\nDecember 31,\n\n2018\n11,101,376\n16,027,221\n\nDecember 31,\n\n2017\n13,173,098\n16,027,221\n\n340,556\n\n307,802\n\n100,600\n90,000\n253,598\n-\n\n27,913,351\n\n-\n\n90,000\n173,516\n80,547\n29,852,184\n\nPursuant  to  the  Company  Act,  any  realized  capital  surplus  is  initially  used  to  cover\naccumulated deficit, and the balance, if any, could be transferred to common stock as stock\ndividends  or  distributed  by  cash  based  on  the  original  shareholding  ratio.  Realized  capital\nsurplus  includes  the  premium  derived  from  the  issuance  of  shares of stock in excess of par\nvalue and donations received by the Company. In accordance with the \xe2\x80\x9cRegulations Governing\nthe Offering and Issuance of Securities by Securities Issuers\xe2\x80\x9d, distribution of stock dividends\nfrom capital surplus in any one year shall not exceed 10% of paid-in capital.\n\n(iii) Legal reserve, special reserve, and dividend policy\n\nThe Company\xe2\x80\x99s Articles of Incorporation stipulate that at least 10% of annual net income, after\ndeducting  accumulated  deficit,  if  any,  must  be  retained  as  legal  reserve  until such retention\nequals  the  amount  of  paid-in  capital.  In  addition,  a  special  reserve  shall  be  set  aside  in\naccordance  with  applicable  laws  and  regulations.  The  remaining  balance,  together  with  the\nunappropriated  earnings  from  the  previous  years,  after  retaining  a  certain  portion  of  it  for\nbusiness  considerations,  can  be  distributed  as  dividends  to  stockholders.  Except  for  the\ndistribution  of  capital  surplus  and  legal  reserve  in  accordance  with  applicable  laws  and\nregulations, the Company cannot distribute any earnings when there are no retained earnings.\n\n(Continued)\n\n\x0cACER INCORPORATED\n\nNotes to Parent-Company-Only Financial Statements\n\n63\n\nSince  the  Company  operates  in  an  industry  experiencing  rapid  change  and  development,\nearnings are distributed in consideration of the current year\xe2\x80\x99s earnings, the overall economic\nenvironment,  related  laws  and  decrees,  and  the  Company\xe2\x80\x99 s  long-term  development  and\nstability in its financial position. The Company has adopted a stable dividend policy, in which\na cash dividend comprises at least 10% of the total dividend distribution.\n\nAdditionally, according to the Company Act, a company shall first retain 10% of its income\nafter  taxes  as  legal  reserve  until  such  retention  equals  the  amount  of  paid-in  capital.  If  a\ncompany  has  no  accumulated  deficit,  it  may,  pursuant  to  a  resolution  approved  by  the\nstockholders,  distribute  its  legal  reserve  by  issuing  new  shares  or  distributing  cash  for  the\nportion of legal reserve which exceeds 25% of the paid-in capital.\n\nIn  accordance  with  Ruling  No.  1010047490  issued  by  the  FSC  on  November  21,  2012,  a\nspecial reserve shall be retained at an amount equal to the proportionate share of the carrying\nvalue of the treasury stock held by subsidiaries in excess of the market value at the reporting\ndate.  The  special  reserve  may  be  reversed  when  the  market  value  recovers  in  subsequent\nperiods.\n\nIn  accordance  with  Ruling  No.  1010012865  issued  by  the  FSC  on  April  6,  2012,  a  special\nreserve  equal  to  the  total  amount  of  items  that  are  accounted  for  as  deductions  from\nstockholders\xe2\x80\x99   equity  shall  be  set  aside  from  current  and  prior-year  earnings.  This  special\nreserve shall revert to retained earnings and be made available for distribution when the items\nthat  are  accounted  for  as  deductions  from  stockholders\xe2\x80\x99   equity  are  reversed  in  subsequent\nperiods.\n\nOn June 15, 2018, the Company\xe2\x80\x99s shareholders approved an appropriation of legal reserve and\nspecial  reserve  of  $281,559  and  $2,534,028,  respectively.  Additionally,  the  Company\xe2\x80\x99 s\nshareholders decided to distribute cash deriving from the capital surplus of $2,153,552 ($0.7\ndollars per share), of which $32,754 was distributed to the subsidiaries holding the Company\xe2\x80\x99s\ncommon shares.\n\nOn June 21, 2017, the Company\xe2\x80\x99s shareholders approved a decrease in its special reserve, legal\nreserve and capital surplus of $1,306,709, $145,190 and $3,448,397, respectively, to offset the\naccumulated  deficit.  Additionally,  the  Company\xe2\x80\x99 s  shareholders  decided  to  distribute  cash\nderiving from the capital surplus of $1,538,379 ($0.5 dollars per share), of which $23,308 was\ndistributed to the subsidiaries holding the Company\xe2\x80\x99s common shares. Related information is\navailable on the Market Observation Post System website of the Taiwan Stock Exchange.\n\nThe appropriation of 2018 earnings had been proposed by the Company\xe2\x80\x99s Board of Directors\non March 20, 2019, which included the appropriations of legal reserve and special reserve of\n$306,043 and $406,544, respectively, as well as the distribution of cash dividends amounting\nto $2,367,699 (at $0.77 dollars per share).\n\n(Continued)\n\n\x0cACER INCORPORATED\n\nNotes to Parent-Company-Only Financial Statements\n\n64\n\n(iv) Treasury stock\n\nAs  of  December  31,  2018  and  2017,  details  of  the  GDRs  (for  the  implementation  of  an\noverseas employee stock option plan) held by subsidiary AWI and the Company\xe2\x80\x99s common\nstock  held  by  subsidiaries  AWI  (to  maintain  the  Company\xe2\x80\x99 s  shareholders\xe2\x80\x99   equity),  CCI  (to\nmaintain the Company\xe2\x80\x99s shareholders\xe2\x80\x99 equity), and ETEN (resulting from the acquisition of\nETEN) were as follows (expressed in thousands of shares):\n\nCommon stock\nGDRs\n\nCommon stock\nGDRs\n\nNumber of\n\nshares\n21,809\n24,937\n\nNumber of\n\nshares\n21,809\n24,937\n\nDecember 31, 2018\n\nCarrying\namount\n\n945,239\n1,969,617\n2,914,856\n\n$\n\n$\n\nDecember 31, 2017\n\nCarrying\namount\n\n945,239\n1,969,617\n2,914,856\n\n$\n\n$\n\nMarket value \n424,185\n475,167\n899,352\n\nMarket value \n526,687\n558,991\n1,085,678\n\nAccording  to  the  Securities  and  Exchange  Act,  treasury  stock  cannot  be  collateralized.  In\naddition,  treasury  shares  do  not  bear  shareholder  rights  prior  to  being  sold  to  third  parties.\nMoreover,  the  number  of  treasury  shares  shall  not  exceed  10%  of  the  number  of  common\nshares issued. The total amount of treasury stock shall not exceed the sum of retained earnings,\npaid-in capital in excess of par value, and other realized capital surplus.\n\n(v) Other equity items (net after INCORPORATED\n\nNotes to Parent-Company-Only Financial Statements\n\n66\n\n(s)\n\nShare-based payment\n\nDuring their meeting on June 18, 2014, the Company\xe2\x80\x99s shareholders approved a resolution to issue\n50,000  thousand  shares  of  restricted  stock  to  full-time  employees  who  conformed  to  certain\nrequirements.  The  Company  has  filed  an  effective  registration  with  the  Securities  and  Futures\nBureau of the FSC for the issuance. \n\nOn  August  26,  2014,  the  Company  issued  17,460  thousand  shares  of  restricted  stock  to  its\nemployees. The employees who were granted restricted stock are entitled to purchase the shares of\nrestricted stock at the exercise price of $ 0. The vesting period of the restricted stock is 1~4 years\nsubsequent  to  the  grant  date,  and  the  restricted  shares  of  stock  will  be  vested  from  0%  to  25%\nconsidering the Company\xe2\x80\x99s and individual employee\xe2\x80\x99s performance conditions. The restricted stock\nreceived by the employees shall be deposited and held in an escrow account and could not be sold,\npledged,  transferred,  gifted,  or  disposed  of  in  any  other  forms  during  the  vesting  period;\nnevertheless, the rights of a shareholder (such as voting and election at the shareholders\xe2\x80\x99 meeting)\nare the same as the rights of the Company\xe2\x80\x99s shareholders but are executed by the custodian. During\nthe  vesting  period,  the  restricted  shares  of  stock  are  entitled  to  any  earnings  distribution.    The\nCompany will take back the restricted stock from employees and retire those shares when the vesting\nconditions cannot be met.\n\nThe movements in number of restricted shares of stock issued (in thousands) in 2018 and 2017 were\nas follows:\n\n2018\n\n3,360\n(1,449)\n(1,911)\n\n2017\n\n7,500\n(4,140)\n\n-\n\nUnvested shares at January 1\nForfeited during the period\nVested shares \nUnvested shares at December 31\n\n3,360\nThe  fair  value  of  the  restricted  stock  was  $24.15  (in  New  Taiwan  dollars)  per  share,  which  was\ndetermined by reference to the closing price of the Company\xe2\x80\x99s common stock traded on the Taiwan\nStock  Exchange  at  the  grant  date.  For  the  years  ended  December  31,  2018  and  2017,  the\ncompensation cost (reversed) recognized for the restricted stock amounted to $(1,705) and $14,650,\nrespectively, which was reported in the operating expenses.\n\n-\n\n(t)\n\nEarnings per share (\xe2\x80\x9cEPS\xe2\x80\x9d)\n\n(i)\n\nBasic earnings per share\n\nThe basic earnings per share were calculated as the earnings attributable Employees  who  are  entitled  to  receive  the\nabovementioned employee remuneration, in share or cash, include the employees of subsidiaries of\nthe Company who meet certain specific requirements.\n\nFor  the  years  ended  December  31,  2018  and  2017,  the  Company  accrued  its  remuneration  to\nemployees amounting to $163,313 and $121,049, respectively, and the remuneration for directors of\n$6,911 and $4,263, respectively. The said amounts, which were recognized as operating expenses,\nwere  calculated  based  on  pre-tax  net  profit  for  each  year  before  deducting  the  amount  of  the\nremuneration  to  employees  and  directors,  multiplied  by  the  proposed  distribution  ratio  of\nremuneration to employees and directors. The difference between accrual and actual payment, if any,\nwill be treated as change in accounting estimate and recognized in profit or loss in the following\nyear.\n\nThe aforementioned accrued remunerations to employees and directors were same as the amounts\napproved by the Board of Directors on March 20, 2019 and March 21, 2018, respectively, which\nwere paid in cash.\n\nRelated information is available on the Market Observation Post System website of Taiwan Stock\nExchange.\n\n(x) Other operating income and loss \xe2\x80\x93 net \n\nRental income (note 6(o))\nGovernment measured at fair value\n\n1)\n\nFair value hierarchy \n\nThe following financial instruments are measured at fair value on a recurring basis.\n\nThe table below analyzes the financial instruments measured at fair value subsequent to\ninitial recognition, grouped into Levels 1 to 3, based on the degree to which the fair value\nis observable. The different levels have been defined as follows: \n\na)\n\nb)\n\nc)\n\nLevel  1:  quoted  prices  (unadjusted)  in  active  markets  for  identified  assets  or\nliabilities.\n\nLevel 2: inputs other than quoted prices included within Level 1 that are observable\nfor  the  asset  or  liability,  either  directly  (i.e.  as  prices)  or  indirectly  (i.e.  derived\nfrom prices).\n\nLevel 3: inputs for the assets or liabilities that are not based on observable market\ndata (unobservable inputs).\n\n(Continued)\n\n\x0cACER INCORPORATED\n\nNotes to Parent-Company-Only Financial The fair value of foreign\ncurrency  forward  contracts  is  computed  individually  by  each  contract  using  the\nvaluation technique.\n\nThe  fair  value  of  privately  held  stock  without  an  active  market  is  estimated  by\nusing  the  market  approach  and  is  determined  by  reference  to  recent  financing\nactivities, valuations of similar companies, market conditions, and other economic\nindicators.  The  significant  unobservable  input  is  the  liquidity  discount.  No\nquantitative  information  is  disclosed  due  to  the  possible  changes  in  liquidity\ndiscount would not cause significant potential financial impact.\n\n(iv) Offsetting of financial assets and liabilities\n\nThe Company has financial instrument transactions which are set off in accordance with\nparagraph 42 of IAS 32; the related financial assets and liabilities are presented in the\nbalance sheets on a net basis. \n\n(Continued)\n\n\x0c74\n\nACER INCORPORATED\n\nNotes to Parent-Company-Only Financial Statements\n\nThe table below summarizes the related information of
