to  credit  risk,  liquidity  risk,  and  market  risk  (including  currency  risk,\ninterest  rate  risk,  and  other  market  price  risk).  The  Company  has  disclosed  the  information  on\nexposure to the aforementioned risks and the Company\xe2\x80\x99s policies and procedures to measure and\nmanage those risks as well as the quantitative information below. \n\n(Continued)\n\n\x0cACER INCORPORATED\n\nNotes to Parent-Company-Only Financial Statements\n\n75\n\nThe  Board  of  Directors  are  responsible  for  developing  and  monitoring  the  Company\xe2\x80\x99 s  risk\nmanagement  policies.    The  Company\xe2\x80\x99 s  risk  management  policies  are  established  to  identify  and\nanalyze the risks faced by the Company, to set appropriate risk limits and controls, and to monitor\nadherence to the controls.  Risk management policies and systems are reviewed regularly to reflect\nchanges in market conditions and the Company\xe2\x80\x99s operations.\n\nThe  Company\xe2\x80\x99 s  management  monitors  and  reviews  the  financial  activities  in  accordance  with\nprocedures  required  by  relevant  regulations  and  internal  controls.  Internal  auditors  undertake\nreviews of risk management controls and procedures, and the results of which are reported to the\nBoard of Directors on a regular basis.\n\n(i)\n\nCredit risk\n\n1)\n\nThe maximum exposure to credit risk \n\nCredit risk is the risk of financial loss to the Company if a customer or counterparty of a\nfinancial instrument fails to meet its contractual obligations, and arises principally from\nthe  Company\xe2\x80\x99 s  cash  and  cash  equivalents,  derivative  instruments,  receivables  from\ncustomers, and other receivables.  The maximum exposure to credit risk is equal to the\ncarrying amount of the Company\xe2\x80\x99s financial assets. \n\n2)\n\nConcentration of credit risk\n\nThe  Company  primarily  sells  and  markets  its  multi-branded  IT  products  through  its\nsubsidiaries  and  distributors  in  different  geographic  areas.  The  Company  believes  that\nthere is no significant concentration of credit risk due to the Company\xe2\x80\x99s large number of\ncustomers and their wide geographical spread.\n\n3)\n\nCredit risk from receivables\n\nRefer  to  note  6(f)  for  credit  risk  exposure  of  notes  and  accounts  receivable.  Other\nfinancial  assets  at  amortized  cost  includes  other  receivables  (refer  to  note  6(g)),  time\ndeposits (classified as other financial assets), etc. Abovementioned financial assets are\nconsidered  low-credit-risk  financial  assets,  and  thus,  the  loss  allowance  are  measured\nusing 12 months ECL. Please refer to note 4(f) for descriptions about how the Company\ndetermines the credit risk.\n\n(ii) Liquidity risk\n\nLiquidity  risk  is  the  risk  that  the  Company  will  encounter  difficulty  in  settling  its  financial\nliabilities by delivering cash or another financial assets. The Company manages liquidity risk\nby monitoring regularly the current and mid- to long-term cash demand, maintaining adequate\ncash and banking facilities, and ensuring compliance with the terms of the loan agreements. As\nof December 31, 2018 and 2017, the Company had unused credit facilities of $28,740,628 and\n$32,218,342, respectively.\n\nThe  table  below  is  the  maturity  profile  of  the  Company\xe2\x80\x99 s  financial  liabilities  based  on\ncontractual undiscounted payments, including the estimating interest.\n\n(Continued)\n\n\x0cACER INCORPORATED\n\nNotes to Parent-Company-Only changes in market prices, such as foreign exchange rates, interest\nrates,  and  equity  prices,  will  affect  the  Company\xe2\x80\x99 s  income  or  the  value  of  its  financial\ninstruments.  The objective of market risk management is to manage and control market risk\nexposures within acceptable parameters, while optimizing the return.\n\nThe  Company  utilizes  derivative  financial  instruments  to  manage  market  risks  and  the\nvolatility of profit or loss.  All such transactions are carried out within the guidelines set by the\nBoard of Directors. \n\n1)\n\nForeign currency risk\n\nThe  Company  is  exposed  to  foreign  currency  risk  on  sales  and  purchases  that  are\ndenominated  in  a  currency  other  than  the  functional  currencies  of  the  Company.  The\nforeign  currencies  used  in  these  transactions  are  mainly  the  US  dollar  (USD),  Euro\n(EUR), Indian Rupee (INR), Australian Dollar (AUD), Japanese yen (JPY), etc.\n\nThe Company utilizes foreign currency forward contracts to hedge its foreign currency\nexposure with respect to its forecast sales and purchases over the following 12 months.\n\n(Continued)\n\n\x0c77\n\nACER INCORPORATED\n\nNotes to Parent-Company-Only Financial Statements\n\nExposure to foreign currency risk and sensitivity analysis:\n\nThe Company\xe2\x80\x99s exposure to foreign currency risk arises from cash and cash equivalents,\nnotes and accounts receivable (including related-party receivables), notes and accounts\npayable  (including  related-party  payables),  other  receivables  (including  related-party\nreceivables) and other payables (including related-party payables) that are denominated\nin  foreign  currency.  At  the  reporting  date,  the  carrying  amounts  of  the  Company\xe2\x80\x99 s\nsignificant  monetary  assets  and  liabilities  denominated  in  a  currency  other  than  the\nrespective  functional  currencies  of  the  Company  and  their  sensitivity  analysis  were  as\nfollows:\n\nDecember 31, 2018\n\nForeign\ncurrency \n\nExchange\n\nrate\n\nNTD \n\nChange in\nmagnitude\n\n(in thousands)\n\nPre-tax effect\non profit or\n\nloss  \n\n$\n\n81,111\n589,710\n9,600,425\n83,560\n4,015,196\n\n35.2415\n30.7330\n0.4405\n21.6637\n0.2802\n\n2,858,473\n18,123,557\n4,228,987\n1,810,219\n1,125,058\n\n1,790\n1,464,142\n\n35.2415\n30.7330\n\n63,082\n44,997,476\n\n%1\n%1\n%1\n%1\n%1\n\n28,585\n181,236\n42,290\n18,102\n11,251\n\n%1\n%1\n\n631\n449,975\n(in thousands)\n\nDecember 31, 2017\n\nForeign\ncurrency \n\nExchange\n\nrate\n\nNTD \n\nChange in\nmagnitude\n\nPre-tax effect\non profit or\n\nloss  \n\n$\n\n14,541\n990,174\n\n35.8325\n29.8480\n\n521,041\n29,554,714\n\n%1\n%1\n\n5,210\n295,547\n\nFinancial assets\n\xe3\x80\x80Monetary items\n\xe3\x80\x80EUR\n\xe3\x80\x80USD\n\xe3\x80\x80INR\n\xe3\x80\x80AUD\n\xe3\x80\x80JPY\nFinancial liabilities\n\xe3\x80\x80Monetary items\n\xe3\x80\x80EUR\n\xe3\x80\x80USD\n\nFinancial assets\n\xe3\x80\x80Monetary items\n\xe3\x80\x80EUR\n\xe3\x80\x80USD\nFinancial liabilities\n\xe3\x80\x80Monetary items\n\xe3\x80\x80EUR\n\xe3\x80\x80USD\n\n372\n441,107\nWith varieties of foreign currencies, the Company disclosed foreign exchange gain (loss)\non monetary items in aggregate. Please refer to note 6(y) for further information.\n\n37,230\n44,110,747\n\n1,039\n1,477,846\n\n35.8325\n29.8480\n\n%1\n%1\n\n(Continued)\n\n\x0cACER INCORPORATED\n\nNotes to Parent-Company-Only Financial Statements\n\n78\n\n2)\n\nInterest rate risk\n\nThe Company\xe2\x80\x99s short-term borrowing and long-term debt carried floating interest rates,\nand  the  Company  has  not  entered  into  interest  rate  swap  contracts  to  convert  floating\ninterest  rates  to  fixed  interest  rates.  To  manage  the  interest  rate  risk,  the  Company\nperiodically  assesses  the  interest  rates  of  bank  loans  and  maintains  good  relationships\nwith financial institutions to obtain lower financing costs. The Company also strengthens\nthe management of working capital to reduce the dependence on bank loans as well as\nthe risk arising from fluctuation of interest rates.\n\nPlease refer to the note on liquidity risk management for details on interest rate exposure\nof the Company\xe2\x80\x99s financial liabilities. The following sensitivity analysis is based on the\nrisk  exposure  to  non-derivative  financial  instruments  on  the  reporting  date.  The\nsensitivity analysis assumes the liabilities carrying floating interest rates recorded at the\nreporting  date  had  been  outstanding  for  the  entire  period.   The change in interest rate\nreported  to  the  key  management  in  the  Company  is  based  on  100  basis  points  (1%),\nwhich is consistent with the assessment made by the key management in respect of the\npossible change in interest rate.\n\nIf the interest rate had been 100 basis points (1%) higher/lower with all other variables\nheld constant, pre-tax income (loss) for the years ended December 31, 2018 and 2017\nwould have been $33,000 and $60,000, respectively, lower/higher, which mainly resulted\nfrom the borrowings with floating interest rates.\n\n3)\n\nOther market price risk\n\nThe  Company  is  exposed  to the risk of price fluctuation in securities market resulting\nfrom its investment in publicly traded stocks. The Company supervises the equity price\nrisk actively and manages the risk based on fair value. The Company also has strategic\ninvestments in privately held stocks, in which the Company does not actively participate\nin their trading. \n\nAssuming  a  hypothetical  increase  or  decrease  of  5%  in  equity  prices  of  the  equity\ninvestments at each reporting date, the other comprehensive income for the years ended\nDecember  31,  2018  and  2017,  would  have  increased  or  decreased  by  $146,095  and\n$165,579, respectively.\n\n(ab) Capital management\n\nIn consideration of the industry dynamics and future developments, as well as external environment\nfactors, the Company maintains an optimal capital structure to enhance long-term shareholder value\nby managing its capital in a manner to ensure that it has sufficient and necessary financial resources\nto fund its working capital needs, research and development activities, dividend payments, and other\nbusiness  requirements  for  continuing  operations  and  to  reward  shareholders  and  take  into\nconsideration the interests of other stakeholders.  \n\n(Continued)\n\n\x0c79\n\nACER INCORPORATED\n\nNotes to Parent-Company-Only Financial Statements\n\n(ac) Changes in liabilities from financing activities\n\nReconciliation of liabilities arising from financing activities were as follows:\n\nLong-term debts\n\n7. Parent-Company-Only Financial Statements\n\n87\n\n9.\n\nSignificant commitments and contingencies   \n(a) The Company has entered into software and royalty license agreements with Microsoft, IBM, and\n\nother companies. The Company has fulfilled its obligations according to the contracts.\n\n(b)\n\nIn the ordinary course of its business from time to time, the Company received notices from third\nparties  asserting  that  Acer  has  infringed  certain  patents  and  demanded  that  Acer  should  obtain\ncertain patent licenses. Although the Company does not expect that the outcome of any of these legal\nproceedings  (individually  or  collectively)  will  have  a  material  adverse  effect  on  the  Company\xe2\x80\x99 s\nbusiness operations and finance, the litigation is inherently unpredictable. Therefore, the Company\ncould incur judgments or enter into settlements of claims that could adversely affect its operating\nresults or cash flows in a particular period.\n\n(c) As of December 31, 2018 and 2017, the Company had outstanding stand-by letters of credit provided\n\nby the banks totaling $49,978 and $43,319, respectively, for purposes of bids and contracts.\n\n(d) As  of  December  31,  2018  and  2017,  the  Company  had  issued  promissory  notes  amounting  to\n$33,773,827 and $43,410,809, respectively, as collateral for obtaining credit facilities from financial\ninstitutions.\n\n10. 2: The aggregate financing amount shall not exceed 50% of the most recent audited or reviewed net worth of the Company (the amount shown above is based on the net worth as of September 30, 2018), within which\n\nthe short-term financing amount shall not exceed 20% of the most recent audited or reviewed net worth of the Company.\n\n             For an entity which the Company owns more than 50% of its outstanding common shares, the individual financing amounts shall not exceed 10% of the most recent audited or reviewed net worth of the Company.\n            When a subsidiary is directly or indirectly wholly owned by the Company who provides financing to other parties, the aforementioned limitation of aggregate amount and individual financing amount is applied.\nNote 3: The above MOEA, therefore, the amout of US$ 1,645,200 was still included the original investment in JNS Technology Co., Ltd. \nNote 6: T-Conn Precision(Zhongshan) Co., Ltd.,  indirectly invested by AOI, had been dissolved and the related liquidation process has been completed.
